<p>Investments in energy conservation and environmentally adapted ener-<br>gy production, along with the carbon dioxide tax passed by the Riksdag,<br>will make it possible to limit carbon dioxide emissions from housing,<br>services and district heating plants so that they will not exceed current<br>levels in the year 2000.</p>
<p>It is essential to reduce the effects of traffic on the climate. This can be<br>done through public transportation with low carbon dioxide emissions,<br>increased fuel-efficiency in new cars, motor alcohol-fuelled vehicles for<br>urban areas, and reduction of average speeds on highways. Carbon dioxide<br>emissions from aviation and shipping should be limited.</p>
<p>Such measures could make it possible to restrict carbon dioxide emis-<br>sions from traffic so that they do not exceed current levels in the year 2000.<br>As traffic accounts for emissions of other greenhouse gases as well, this also<br>means that the total effect of the traffic sector on the climate can be<br>reduced. The results of these measures will be contingent on economic<br>developments, and on fuel prices. Increases in the price of petrol during<br>the first half of 1990, which was one aspect of the tax reform, helped<br>reduce carbon dioxide emissions from vehicular traffic, following a period<br>with annual increases of 4 — 5%.</p>
<p>Prop. 1990/91:90</p>
<p>19</p>
<p>Improved waste management can help to reduce climate change. One<br>example is energy recovery through combustion of methane from waste<br>landfills, which reduces the need of fossil fuels and has also reduced<br>methane emissions. Methane is a powerful greenhouse gas. Measures in<br>agriculture will represent a significant part of a climate strategy.</p>
<p>Phasing out of CFCs can be extended to other substances with similar<br>effects (halons, carbon tetrachloride, HCFC and others). In addition to<br>decisions already adopted, a number of measures can be taken in view of<br>the intemational situation, for example. These could include limitations<br>on HCFCs, halons, carbon tetrachloride and 1’1’1’ trichlorothane.</p>
<p>Measures of this type can lead to substantial reductions of emissions of<br>climate-changing gases.</p>
<p>Measures to counteract the use of volatile organic compounds (some<br>solvents, for example) are important in terms of reducing climatic effects.</p>
<p>This inter-party agreement on energy policy will mean major investments<br>in energy management and environmentally adapted power generation.<br>The Government is proposing guidelines for energy policy in its bill on<br>Energy Policy.</p>
<p>In this Bill, the Government is recommending the implementation of a<br>number of measures to reduce climatic effects. In the field of traffic, for<br>example, measures will include an enviromental classification system for<br>new vehicles. In the 1991 Govemment Bill on Industrial Growth Policy,<br>major investments in public transport and railways, and further pilot<br>projects using automatic speed limit monitoring are proposed. In its Bill<br>on Energy Policy, the Government is proposing allocations for testing and<br>development of alcohol-fuelled vehicles.</p>
<p>The Govemment is also reporting in this Bill that the plan to phase out<br>ozone-depleting substances is to be extended. The Government is an-<br>nouncing that regulations will be introduced on the recovery and destruc-<br>tion of CFC and halons.</p>
<p>The Government has previously described measures to reduce the envi-<br>ronmental effects of waste management. The on-going restructuring of<br>Swedish agriculture will help reduce effects on the environment. The<br>Govemment is announcing in this Bill that emissions of volatile organic<br>compounds (VOCs) are to be halved in relation to the 1988 level by the<br>year 2000.</p>
<p>These measures will mean a substantial reduction of Swedish inputs to<br>climatic change. However, further investigation of the costs and effects of<br>possible measures is essential. This is particularly true in the case of<br>measures to counteract emissions of greenhouse gases other than carbon<br>dioxide. It is the intention of the Government, in collaboration with the<br>relevant authorities, to present an in-depth analysis of issues on the cli-<br>mate which will form a basis for Swedish policies, both nationally and<br>intemationally.</p>
<p>In late January, 1991, Statistics Sweden reported the 1988 carbon diox-<br>ide emissions, and the preliminary figures for 1989. These statistics indi-<br>cate that emissions were basically unchanged between 1988 and 1989 (62.8<br>million tonnes of carbon dioxide in 1988 and 62.2 million tonnes in 1989).<br>Although 1989 was a much warmer year than 1988, there were only<br></p>
<p>Prop. 1990/91:90</p>
<p>20</p>
<p>marginal reductions in carbon dioxide emissions. This illustrates the diffi- Prop. 1990/91:90<br>culty of keeping to the 1988 emissions levels under normal weather condi-<br>tions. It is emphasized in the inter-party agreement, not least in light of<br>traffic developments, that this interim target will probably be difficult to<br>meet in the coming years.</p>
<h5>2.2 Transboundary air pollutants</h5>
<p>Government proposals: Guidelines for future work are that deposi-<br>tions of sulphur and nitrogen oxides and volatile organic com-<br>pounds are to be limited to levels at which neither the environment<br>nor human health is harmed.</p>
<p>According to the 1988 statement of the Riksdag, Swedish sulphur<br>levels are to be reduced by 80% between 1980 and 2000. According<br>to previous Riksdag statements nitrogen oxide levels are to be<br>reduced by 30% by 1995, in relation to the 1980 level. These emis-<br>sion targets are to serve as guidelines in future work. Extensive<br>measures will have to be implemented to achieve this objective for<br>nitrogen oxides.</p>
<p>Ammonia emissions should be reduced by 25% by 1995. The<br>potential for reducing emissions by 50% in the Southern and western<br>parts of the province of Götaland before the year 2000 is to be<br>examined. There should be a 50% reduction in emissions of volatile<br>organic compounds by the year 2000 in relation to the 1988 levels.</p>
<p>Sweden’s contribution to intemational cooperation in the next<br>few years should be focused mainly on bringing about more strin-<br>gent requirements for vehicle exhaust emissions in Europé. New<br>intemational agreements to reduce emissions of sulphur and nitro-<br>gen oxides are also to be given priority. They should be based on the<br>critical loads the environment can withstand. Sweden is to work<br>towards achieving an agreement on reductions of emissions of vola-<br>tile organic compounds.</p>
<h6>2.2.1 Background</h6>
<p>The soil in southem Sweden has become severely acidified in recent<br>decades. In the regions of Skåne, Halland and southem Småland, soil<br>acidification has reached depths of several meters, and is affecting the<br>groundwater. One effect of this process is that the readily accessible store<br>of nutrients such as calcium and magnesium in the soil has decreased by<br>30 — 70% in southem Sweden. Metals which may be toxic to plants and<br>animals, such as aluminium, are also released from the acidified soil.</p>
<p>Continued acidification of forest soil is an increasing threat to the<br>environment and to the value of our forests. Forest soil in parts of South-<br>ern Sweden is approaching the nitrogen saturation limit. The results of this<br>are soil acidification and nitrogen leaching as well as both a nutrient<br></p>
<p>21</p>
<p>imbalance in the trees in the forests and decreased forest growth. Unless Prop. 1990/91:90<br>nitrogen deposition is reduced, substantial portions of southem Sweden<br>may be nitrogen saturated within 10 to 20 years.</p>
<p>Groundwater affected by acidification was reported, particularly in the<br>Southern part of Sweden, throughout the 1980s. In areas with heavy acid<br>rain, there are substantially raised levels of aluminium in the groundwater.<br>As the pipelines are corroding, copper levels are also sharply raised in the<br>drinking water from many private wells all over Sweden. There is a clear<br>risk that the copper levels in drinking water will increase in step with<br>increasing acidification. Copper and aluminium in drinking water may<br>give rise to health risks.</p>
<p>In the early 1980s, 16,000 of the approximately 85,000 lakes in Sweden<br>were so severely acidified that sensitive species had substantially de-<br>creased in number or died out. In nearly 6,000 of these lakes, treatment<br>with powdered limestone has resulted in improvements in the situation of<br>the plant and animal life. Without liming, acidification would have meant<br>that most forms of life would have been dead in at least one-fourth of the<br>lakes and watercourses downstream of the lakes which have been limed.</p>
<p>During the last 25 years, there have been no substantial changes in the<br>acidification situation in the lakes and watercourses in the provinces of<br>Götaland and Svealand or the Coastal areas of Norrland. However, in the<br>mountains and the adjacent areas, the last 10 to 15 years have seen<br>continuing increased acidification.</p>
<p>Large parts of the Swedish forests are suffering from impaired vitality.<br>Approximately every fifth fir and every seventh pine has lost more than<br>20% of its needles. Deciduous trees, including beech, oak and birch,<br>exhibit more extensive damage, expressed as thinning out and disturbed<br>growth in the crowns, than is found in firs and pines. Increasing soil<br>acidification and the consequent impoverishment of forest soil stand as<br>the greatest long-term threats to the Swedish forests.</p>
<p>Stratospheric ozone provides indispensable protection against hazard-<br>ous ultra-violet radiation. However, ozone at the surface of the earth may<br>harm plant growth and human health. Superficial ozone develops in inter-<br>action with sunlight when the levels of certain air pollutants become too<br>high (photochemical smog).</p>
<p>The superficial levels of ozone in southem Sweden during the summer<br>half of the year are near or above the levels at which health and crops are<br>harmed. In western Sweden, it is estimated that current ozone levels are<br>causing an approximately 10% poorer yield of the crops of spring wheat.<br>Crops such as grazing grass, oats and potatoes are also being negatively<br>affected.</p>
<p>The compounds which contribute most to acidification, nitrogen satura-<br>tion and the formation of photochemical smog are sulphur dioxide, nitro-<br>gen oxides and volatile organic compounds.</p>
<p>Emissions of sulphur in Sweden have decreased substantially since the<br>early 1970s as a result of implemented measures. Emissions from both<br>combustion and industrial processes have been limited, and today they are</p>
<p>22<br></p>
<p>less than half of the 1950 levels. Since 1980, total sulphur emissions have Prop. 1990/91:90<br>decreased by more than 60%.</p>
<p>Sulphur deposition in most of Sweden does, however, exceed the critical<br>load, which is the limit above which it has been scientifically proven that<br>long-term effects on the environment occur. To be brought below this<br>limit, sulphur deposition in south-western Sweden would have to be de-<br>creased by more than 75% of the 1980 level. Simulations indicate that<br>during the 1980s sulphur deposition in all of Sweden decreased by between<br>15 and 25%. Emissions from foreign sources and diffuse emissions for<br>which no country of origin can be determined account for about 90% of the<br>sulphur deposition in Sweden. In 1988, inputs of sulphur from Poland and<br>the then GDR to sulphur deposition in Sweden were of the same order of<br>magnitude as the Swedish inputs, if not larger. Critical loads are being<br>exceeded elsewhere in Northern Europé as well. Thus, in order to bring<br>this deposition down to the critical loads, extensive measures will have to<br>be implemented in Europé. A large number of Western European nations<br>are now working towards decreasing their emissions, pursuant, for in-<br>stance, to agreements in the UN-ECE and the EC. The on-going processes<br>of economic change in eastern Germany, Poland and Czechoslovakia may<br>mean substantial emission reductions, and thus the situation is consider-<br>ably brighter today than when the 1988 Swedish Government Bill on<br>Environmental Policy was presented.</p>
<p>A sulphur tax and an environmental classification system for oil have<br>been introduced in The Energy Tax Act, in order to bring about reductions<br>in sulphur emissions in Sweden. The classification system will lead to<br>substantial reductions in the sulphur content of diesel fuel. In reviewing a<br>number of permit appeals pursuant to the Environment Protection Act,<br>the Government has tightened up sulphur emission requirements. The<br>Government has amended the Ordinance on fuels containing sulphur so<br>that a maximum sulphur level has now been set for all fuels containing<br>sulphur.</p>
<p>Emissions of nitrogen oxides come primarily from various combustion<br>processes, and they increased rapidly in Sweden in the 1950s and 60s.<br>During the 1980s, total emission levels have basically remained constant.<br>Emissions from energy generation plants have decreased by about one-<br>third. Emissions from traffic have increased in the 1980s.</p>
<p>Nitrogen deposition exceeds the critical loads in Southern Sweden and<br>elsewhere. This deposition needs to be decreased by at least 50% in the<br>province of Götaland, primarily in the south-western Coastal areas. Air-<br>borne nitrogen is also a significant source of marine nitrogen pollution. In<br>the region of Skåne and on the Swedish west coast, about 60% of the<br>nitrogen deposition comes from nitrogen oxides and about 40% from<br>nitrogen in ammonia from agriculture. Foreign sources account for 75 -<br>80% of the nitrogen deposition in south-western Sweden. A large propor-<br>tion of ammonia deposition comes from Denmark.</p>
<p>The Riksdag has passed a charge on nitrogen oxide emissions from large<br>combustion plants. It is estimated that this charge will both decrease<br>annual emissions by 3,000 - 5,000 tonnes, and bring forward the imple-<br></p>
<p>23</p>
<p>mentation of environmental improvement measures. On the basis of a Prop. 1990/91:90<br>Government proposal, the Riksdag has also, at the proposal of the Govem-<br>ment, considered exhaust regulations and adopted durability requirements<br>for heavy vehicles. The Govemment has amended the Automobile Ex-<br>haust Ordinance, tightening up the exhaust requirements for light trucks<br>and buses, in accordance with a previous presentation to the Riksdag.</p>
<p>Emissions of volatile organic compounds and nitrogen oxides contribute<br>to the occurrence of high levels of photochemical oxidants (primarily<br>ozone). This is a widespread phenomenon attributable to emissions in<br>large geographic regions. The problem is particularly great on the Europe-<br>an continent, in the triangle formed by Hamburg-Paris-Munich. Ozone<br>levels in Sweden are primarily affected by ozone from the continent.<br>However, local formation of ozone, primarily over urban areas, also leads<br>to substantial raising of the oxidant levels. High levels of photochemical<br>oxidants may harm crops and forests and affect human health. Traffic is<br>the main source of emissions of volatile organic compounds in Sweden.<br>Petrol distribution and the use of solvents are also major contributors.<br>Certain organic compounds, such as chlorinated solvents, also have direct<br>effects on health and the environment. Swedish emissions of volatile<br>organic compounds were approximately 460,000 tonnes in 1988.</p>
<p>In reviewing a number of permit applications pursuant to the Environ-<br>ment Protection Act in November 1988, the Government stated that<br>limitation of solvent emissions should be given higher priority in environ-<br>mental protection work at all levels. Pursuant to this statement, recom-<br>mended safety distances should be observed, and the potential for phasing<br>out the use of solvents entirely should be investigated. This statement has<br>been referred to in a large number of cases reviewed by the Govemment.</p>
<h6>2.2.2 Objectives for transboundary air pollutants</h6>
<p>The overall objective in working with regional air pollutants is to limit<br>their emissions to a level at which no damage to nature occurs and human<br>health is protected. This means that the production capacity of ecosystems<br>is to be maintained, and that the number of naturally occurring species is<br>not to be markedly disturbed. Soil and water are to constitute a chemically<br>and biologically balanced system. It must be possible to use animals and<br>plants as food, at no risk to human or animal health.</p>
<p>These objectives necessitate a 75% reduction in sulphur deposition in<br>south-western Sweden and a 50% reduction in the province of Svealand, in<br>relation to the 1980 levels. Nitrogen deposition must be reduced by 50% in<br>the Southern and western parts of Götaland. Background levels of ozone<br>should be reduced by 10—30%, and the episodically high levels by 50% in<br>Southern and mid-Sweden. Further reductions may be necessary in order<br>to protect the most sensitive types of natural environments.</p>
<p>In the Action Plan to counteract air pollution and acidification adopted<br>in 1985 by the Riksdag, it is stated that Swedish sulphur emissions should<br>be reduced by 65% during the period from 1980 to 1995. Nitrogen oxide<br>emissions should, pursuant to the Riksdag’s decision, be reduced by 30%<br></p>
<p>24</p>
<p>between 1980 and 1995. A 1988 Riksdag statement in response to the Prop. 1990/91:90<br>Government Bill on Environmental Policy stipulated that sulphur emis-<br>sions should be decreased by 80% between 1980 and 2000, and that the<br>potential for decreasing nitrogen oxides by 50% between 1980 and 2000<br>should be investigated.</p>
<p>In the assessment of the Government, the decisions which have been<br>implemented to date should be sufficient to decrease Swedish sulphur<br>emissions by 65% by 1995, in relation to the 1980 level. The measures<br>being stipulated here should make it possible to reduce emissions by 80%<br>by the year 2000.</p>
<p>Nitrogen oxide developments are more problematical, particularly as<br>there has been a greater increase in traffic than was estimated in 1985 when<br>the target value was set. New estimates indicate that emissions from<br>shipping and off-road and utility vehicles are considerably greater than was<br>previously known, and thus a 30% decrease by 1995 poses a greater<br>challenge than was apparent when the target values were set. Extensive<br>measures need to be taken to achieve this target. Sweden is going to work<br>actively for common programmes in EFTA and the EC, in order to reduce<br>deposition to levels at which human health and nature are not harmed.<br>This is the only way to bring levels in Sweden below the critical loads.</p>
<p>In the opinion of the Govemment, the emission target set previously for<br>nitrogen oxides by the Riksdag should remain the guideline for future<br>work. It is technically feasible to reduce inputs of nitrogen oxides from<br>traffic to acidification and eutrophication substantially by the year 2010.<br>The measures being proposed in the present Bill provide a point of depar-<br>ture from which this development can take place. The regulations for air<br>traffic and shipping are internationally rooted, and require the implemen-<br>tation of measures jointly by many nations. An intemational agreement is<br>also necessary for off-road and utility vehicles in order to make the regula-<br>tions more stringent. The establishment of an emission target for the year<br>2000 should therefore, in the opinion of the Government, be postponed<br>until both 30% reduction and acceptance in intemational negotiations<br>have been ensured.</p>
<p>The Govemment considers that measures should be taken to reduce<br>emissions of ammonia. The objective for future work is a 25% reduction of<br>ammonia emissions in Southern Sweden by 1995. The potential for cutting<br>back emissions by half before the year 2000 is being investigated.</p>
<p>The Government is also proposing a new interim objective for emissions<br>of volatile organic compounds, i. e. a 50% reduction by the year 2000, in<br>relation to the 1988 level. The requirements for vehicle exhaust emissions<br>which have already been adopted are a major step towards achieving this<br>objective. Below, the Government presents measures to limit the use of<br>solvents.</p>
<p>A substantial proportion of the sulphur and nitrogen deposition in<br>Sweden comes from foreign sources. Swedish emissions are also dissemin-<br>ated to other countries. For these reasons, a strategy to decrease acidifica-<br>tion and nitrogen saturation must encompass both emission limits in<br>Sweden and intemational cooperation to reduce emissions.</p>
<p>25</p>
<p>A number of measures are presented in this Bill to bring about further Prop. 1990/91: 90<br>reductions of sulphur emissions, particularly from industrial processes,<br>energy generation plants, and fuels. It is the assessment of the Government<br>that the sum of these measures will lead to a more than 80% reduction in<br>total Swedish sulphur emissions by the year 2000, in relation to the 1980<br>level.</p>
<p>An effective strategy to combat nitrogen oxide emissions requires the<br>implementation of additional measures in the traffic sector. Emissions of<br>nitrogen oxides from industries and large combustion plants will also have<br>to be reduced. Below, the Government presents such measures.</p>
<p>The extensive Action Plan being proposed by the Govemment is expect-<br>ed to lead to an approximately 30% decrease in nitrogen oxide emissions<br>by 1998.</p>
<p>Ammonia spreads over shorter distances than sulphur and nitrogen<br>oxides. This means that there will be a greater relative effect of measures<br>taken in Sweden to reduce ammonia deposition here than of correspond-<br>ing measures for sulphur and nitrogen oxides.</p>
<p>Emissions of volatile organic compounds must be reduced by at least<br>50% in most of Europé in order to limit the health and environmental<br>effects of high ozone levels on the surface of the earth. More than 40% of<br>these emissions are attributable to traffic. In addition to existing measures,<br>the measures being proposed by the Government in this Bill for the traffic<br>sector will bring about a reduction of emissions of at least 70% from the<br>traffic sector by the year 2000. Use of certain solvents in industry and in<br>goods and products should also be sharply restricted. It is estimated that<br>the total effect of all such measures would be sufficient to achieve the<br>emission target of a 50% reduction of volatile organic compounds by the<br>year 2000 in relation to the 1988 levels.</p>
<p>In the opinion of the Government, the use of environmentally-hazard-<br>ous organic solvents must cease by 1 January 1995. The chlorinated<br>solvents in widespread use today must, therefore, be phased out, primarily<br>through European cooperation.</p>
<p>In addition to emission limits, liming is needed in the environment as a<br>defense against the deleterious effects of acidification. Liming may also<br>contribute to reducing the levels of mercury and radioactive caesium.<br>Powdered limestone treatment of lakes and watercourses may be necessary<br>for a long period of time. The pilot projects for liming of forest soil and<br>fertilization to improve the vitality of the forests are to be completed.<br>Below, the Government proposes substantial expansion of the liming<br>programme.</p>
<h6>2.2.3 International cooperation</h6>
<p>In the opinion of the Government, there needs to be sharp limitation of<br>transboundary air pollutants all over Northern Europé. This requires<br>intemational cooperation. The forum for intemational cooperation is the<br>European cooperation under the 1979 Convention on Long-Range Trans-<br>boundary Air Pollution. Under the 1979 Geneva Convention, there are<br></p>
<p>26</p>
<p>binding Protocols on reductions of sulphur and nitrogen emissions, which Prop. 1990/91:90<br>Sweden has ratified. The 1985 Sulphur Protocol establishes a minimum<br>30% reduction of sulphur emissions between 1980 and 1993. The 1988<br>Nitrogen Protocol establishes a stabilization of nitrogen oxides at the 1987<br>level no later than in 1994. A large number of West European nations,<br>including Sweden, have made a separate declaration, adopted in conjunc-<br>tion with the 1988 Convention meeting in Sofia, in which they have<br>undertaken to reduce emissions of nitrogen oxides by roughly 30% by<br>1998, with optional baseline years between 1980 and 1985. Work under<br>the Convention is currently focused on amendment of the Protocols on<br>sulphur and nitrogen oxide emissions, and on a new protocol on limitation<br>of emissions of volatile organic compounds. In the opinion of the Govern-<br>ment, in contrast to previous agreements, these target levels must be<br>formulated on the basis of critical loads. This means that new measures<br>implemented to achieve emission reductions will be different for different<br>nations or groups of nations, and that requirements for Northern and</p>
<p>Southern Europé will not have to be the same.</p>
<p>This will make it possible to bring sulphur deposition levels in southem<br>Sweden and Continental Europé down below the critical loads. Estimates<br>indicate that the per capita emissions corresponding to those reached in<br>western Germany would be sufficient to achieve this target, with the most<br>extensive measures needing to be implemented in eastern Germany and<br>Poland. It is anticipated that these reductions will be brought about as a<br>result of economic change, and as a consequence of the discontinuation of<br>subsidies on domestic coal. In Western Europé, Great Britain is the nation<br>which will have to implement more extensive measures than have been<br>planned to date in order to bring levels below the critical loads.</p>
<p>It is the intention of the Government to work towards the signing of a<br>new agreement among the European nations on the limitation of sulphur<br>emissions no later than 1993. Sweden will also work towards the signing of<br>an agreement on volatile organic compounds as soon as possible.</p>
<p>More stringent regulations on vehicle exhaust emissions will be neces-<br>sary throughout Europé in order to limit nitrogen deposition. The Govern-<br>ment intends to continue working towards achieving such agreements.<br>Sweden will work towards the implementation of standards for light and<br>heavy vehicles in the EC and EFTA nations, no later than 1996, corre-<br>sponding to those being implemented federally in the USA in 1994. In<br>Eastern Europé, regulations on emission limits corresponding to those<br>which can be achieved through catalytic exhaust purification need to be<br>implemented. It is necessary to implement measures for tractors and<br>diesel-fuelled railways throughout Europé by the year 2000. Measures on<br>aviation and shipping should also be taken within the framework of<br>intemational agreements.</p>
<p>27</p>
<h5>2.3 The environment in urban areas</h5>
<p>Government proposals: The guideline for future work is that the air<br>quality is to be improved so as to eliminate remaining risks to<br>human health resulting from emission of air pollutants from traffic,<br>industry or energy generation. The valuable cultural environments<br>of our cities are to be maintained.</p>
<p>Municipal planning is to satisfy the need for green belts in and<br>near urban areas.</p>
<p>By the year 2000, the levels of carbon monoxide, nitrogen oxides,<br>sulphur dioxide, soot and particles are to be below the target loads<br>set by the Swedish Environmental Protection Agency. The objective<br>of these target loads is to eliminate acute health effects.</p>
<p>Emissions of carcinogens should be reduced by 90% in urban<br>areas, if the level of long-term health effects is to be reasonable. As<br>an interim goal, they are to be halved by 2005.</p>
<p>Noise in urban areas should be brought below the current guide-<br>lines of the Swedish Environmental Protection Agency.</p>
<h6>2.3.1 Background</h6>
<p>Most of the air pollutants which contribute to global and regional environ-<br>mental problems originate from traffic, industrial processes and energy<br>generation. This extensive concentration of environmentally-disruptive<br>operations to urban areas also leads, in some cases, to local problems<br>owing to air pollution.</p>
<p>In an intemational perspective, the environment in Swedish urban areas<br>is good. Major emissions with health-endangering effects, such as soot and<br>sulphur dioxides, have been substantially reduced since the early 1970s.</p>
<p>Work to reduce emissions from major stationary sources, such as energy<br>generation plants and industries, has been successful. The implementation<br>of district heating systems and electric heating have been important<br>contributing factors. The concomitant increase in transportation has<br>meant that traffic is now the largest remaining source of urban pollution.<br>Emissions per vehicle, particularly of nitrogen oxides and hydrocarbons<br>from passenger cars, have, however, decreased substantially in recent<br>years as a result of the implementation of strict regulations on vehicle<br>exhaust emissions.</p>
<p>In the assessment of the Government, decisions taken to date will lead<br>to decreases in the levels of sulphur dioxide, nitrogen oxides and carbon<br>monoxide in urban areas. Soot levels are low in Swedish urban areas as<br>compared with target loads, but should still be further decreased in light of<br>the risk of cancer.</p>
<p>Many individuals in urban areas, mainly in the large cities, are exposed<br>to levels of air pollution above those which are considered to characterize a<br>good environment. The target loads for air quality set for certain pollu-<br>tants by the Swedish Environmental Protection Agency are being exceeded<br></p>
<p>Prop. 1990/91:90</p>
<p>28</p>
<p>on heavily-trafficked roads in urban areas where large numbers of people Prop. 1990/91:90<br>live and work. Target loads for nitrogen oxides are also being exceeded in<br>whole parts of Göteborg and Sundsvall, for example.</p>
<p>The most severe health risk from air pollution in urban areas, according<br>to current estimates, is the increased risk of cancer. The research being<br>carried out by the Swedish Environmental Protection Agency on the<br>environment in urban areas indicates for instance, that the number of<br>cases of cancer caused by air pollutants is in the order of magnitude of<br>1,000 per year.</p>
<p>Allergies and other types of over-sensitivity have increased in the gener-<br>al population in the last few decades. The reasons for this are uncertain,<br>but it is probable that various environmental factors play a role. Air<br>pollutants constitute one such environmental factor.</p>
<p>Noise from different sources may disturb people’s work, sleep and<br>relaxation, as well as cause psychosomatic disorders. Medical studies<br>indicate that noise can, for instance, affect the cardiovascular system.<br>Traffic accounts for the vast majority of the noise disturbances in urban<br>areas.</p>
<p>Pollution also causes many materials to degenerate rapidly, which leads<br>in turn to corrosion and other damage to buildings and facilities. This also<br>means that cultural monuments of stone, metal and glass are being threat-<br>ened with destruction. For example, several of the porticos on our medi-<br>eval churches, and most of the seventeenth century omamentation on<br>palaces and private homes, were sculpted in sandstone from Gotland. This<br>lime-bound type of sandstone is more sensitive to Chemical corrosion than<br>most types of rock. Despite radical reductions in the level of sulphur<br>dioxide in Swedish urban air in the 1980s, the situation is serious in many<br>urban areas.</p>
<p>The build-up of urban areas sometimes makes it more difficult for<br>people to get to recreational areas. Good physical planning is necessary in<br>order to expand residential areas, service facilities and transportation<br>arrangements and at the same time to preserve both valuable cultural<br>monuments and ensure access to parks, large recreational areas and green<br>belts between different city areas.</p>
<p>Large areas near cities, offering seclusion, even from noise disturbance,<br>and spots of outstanding natural beauty, are to be given long-term protec-<br>tion in municipal and regional planning wherever possible.</p>
<p>The aesthetic, historical and functional properties of buildings should<br>serve as guidelines for municipal planning. Bringing this traditional kind<br>of planning into line with newer, tougher requirements for clean systems<br>will make it possible to create a good living environment in our urban<br>areas.</p>
<h6>2.3.2 Environmental objectives for the urban areas</h6>
<p>The overall environmental objectives for the urban areas are to protect the<br>population from harmful health effects attributable, for instance, to air<br>pollution and noise, and to give all people a good housing, work, traffic<br></p>
<p>29</p>
<p>and recreational environment. Valuable cultural environments are to be Prop. 1990/91:90<br>maintained wherever possible. Waste must be managed expediently and<br>effectively.</p>
<p>It is the opinion of the Government that the guidelines established by<br>the Swedish Environmental Protection Agency for air quality in the next<br>century must be satisfied in all urban areas. A guideline for future work<br>should be the reduction by half of the emission of carcinogens, as a first<br>step.</p>
<p>Municipalities bear a great deal of responsibility for local environments.<br>The guidelines for acceptable air quality established by the Swedish Envi-<br>ronmental Protection Agency are already in use, and are an important<br>planning instrument. In the future, urban planning should, in the opinion<br>of the Government, be more explicitly based on existing environmental<br>regulations. Good planning can, for instance, lead to a decreased need for<br>transportation. Industries which may affect human health should be locat-<br>ed at suitably safe distances from residential areas and public places.<br>Sufficient areas should be earmarked for recreation and outdoor activities.<br>Municipal planning, pursuant to the Planning and Building Act, for exam-<br>ple, will fundamentally determine what kind of environment we will have<br>in our urban areas. Increased use of district-based heating is one effective<br>way of decreasing levels of sulphur dioxide in urban air, and has already<br>produced good results.</p>
<p>Road traffic has increased greatly in the last 10 to 20 years. More<br>stringent exhaust regulations and the introduction of unleaded petrol are<br>improving motor traffic greatly. However, increased amounts of traffic<br>may counteract the anticipated environmental improvements. The Gov-<br>ernment has therefore appointed special negotiators for Stockholm, Göte-<br>borg and Malmö, to find Solutions to the environmental and accessibility<br>problems caused by traffic in these areas. These negotiators have presented<br>their proposals for agreements to implement measures affecting the traffic<br>system and local traffic planning. The proposals are dealt with in terms of<br>industry and trade in the Government Bill on an Industrial Policy for<br>Increased Growth. So that these agreements will be able to attain their full<br>effects, they will be followed up with stricter regulations on vehicles and<br>fuel. For this reason, the Government is proposing a tightening up of<br>regulations on vehicles and fuel in extensive European cooperation, both<br>generally and specifically for urban traffic.</p>
<p>The Government is proposing that the environmental classes of fuel oils<br>be changed to provide even greater incentives to using environment-<br>friendly fuels. Cleaner fuels make the biggest difference in urban areas.<br>Economic incentives will also be implemented to further stimulate the<br>development of clean technologies and of cleaner vehicles.</p>
<p>Noise is primarily a problem in residential areas, where noise distur-<br>bances from different activities have increased successively. Noise-reduc-<br>tion measures implemented at the source alleviate such disturbances.<br>These measures are often cost-efficient, but their disadvantage is that it<br>takes a long time for them to reach full effect. In many existing environ-<br>ments it is not possible to reduce noise from vehicles sufficiently to obtain</p>
<p>30</p>
<p>a good quality environment, using the best available abatement technol- Prop. 1990/91:90<br>ogy. For the foreseeable future, it will therefore be necessary to use other<br>means of preventing noise from reaching residential areas and other sensi-<br>tive areas. Such measures must be considered in light of other pressing<br>environmental improvement measures, and will have to be carried out<br>with the existing financial resources. The authorities should be given<br>broader sectoral responsibility for noise reduction. All sectors must, in the<br>opinion of the Government, go on working to prevent and minimize noise<br>disturbance.</p>
<p>Particulate levels have decreased in recent years, but are still relatively<br>high in urban areas. The readings that are available indicate that current<br>levels are equivalent to the proposed target loads. As particles are the<br>bearers of carcinogens and can also cause allergies, it is vital to further<br>decrease their levels in urban air. For this reason, it is the opinion of the<br>Government that the guideline for future work should, as a first step, be to<br>achieve a 50% reduction of emissions by 2005.</p>
<p>The measures now being proposed by the Government to improve the<br>urban environment will take full effect in the late 1990s and at the begin-<br>ning of the next century. For the next 10 to 20 years, road traffic is going to<br>have a decisive effect on air quality in urban areas. The guidelines on air<br>quality (carbon monoxide, nitrogen oxides, soot and particles) established<br>by the Swedish Environmental Protection Agency will probably be attain-<br>able early in the next century on the basis of the measures now being<br>proposed.</p>
<p>The most difficult target to attain will be a substantial reduction of<br>particulate emissions. It will be possible, however, with more stringent<br>regulations on both exhaust purification and diesel fuel. City planning,<br>improvements in public transportation and traffic planning will also en-<br>able the implementation of further measures.</p>
<p>Waste management is a particular problem in urban areas. Measures<br>already taken by the Government have made it possible to initiate inven-<br>tory and planning work at the municipal level not only for domestic waste,<br>but for all types of waste. The ultimate objective is to increase municipal<br>responsibility for waste management. Further municipal measures need to<br>be taken, especially with regard to separation and collection of different<br>waste fractions, and for recycling and other suitable management of waste<br>products.</p>
<p>Increased reuse and recycling will be necessary to achieve better re-<br>source management and reduce waste quantities. Sometimes, too, waste<br>contains toxins which, if they are leached out into the natural system, can<br>severely disturb the environment. Waste landfills also pose actual spatial<br>and aesthetic problems in the landscape, and often stand in conflict with<br>other types of land use, particularly in and around urban areas.</p>
<p>The aquatic environment in urban areas has been improved in recent<br>decades. Almost all cities in Sweden near lakes or watercourses or along<br>the coasts have good or excellent opportunities for outdoor bathing. There<br>may be a need for further regulations on effluent treatment in some areas.</p>
<p>31</p>
<h5>2.4 Natural resources and nature conservation</h5>
<p>Government proposals: The following guidelines are to apply to use<br>of natural resources and conservation of the natural environment:</p>
<p>Renewable resources are to be used within the framework pro-<br>vided by the production capacity of the ecosystem. Use of non-<br>renewable resources is to be characterized, even more than at pre-<br>sent, by responsible management.</p>
<p>Biological diversity and genetic variation are to be ensured. Ani-<br>mal and plant communities are to be maintained so that species of<br>plants and animals occurring naturally in Sweden have the potential<br>to survive in their natural habitats and in quantities that will ensure<br>their continued procreation.</p>
<p>Foreign species or organisms subjected to genetic mutation are<br>only to be introduced with great restriction, and under satisfactory<br>conditions to ensure that the conditions required by the indigenous<br>flora and fauna are not jeopardized.</p>
<p>In addition to guidelines, the Govemment is also proposing<br>amendment of the Nature Conservation Act. Resources for care and<br>maintenance of nature reserves and for work with threatened spe-<br>cies will be allocated an additional SEK30 million for the coming<br>budget year.</p>
<h6>2.4.1 Background</h6>
<p>Sweden is a wealthy nation in many respects, for instance in terms of the<br>great availability of natural resources. Our forests are part of our culture,<br>and give many of the inhabitants of Sweden important opportunities to<br>enjoy nature. The forests shape the landscape, and occupy half the land<br>area of Sweden. Agriculture accounts for production of most of our food,<br>and contributes to variation in the cultural and natural landscapes.</p>
<p>The welfare of the nation is highly dependent on natural resources<br>associated with the soil, hydropower, and other aspects of the physical<br>environment. These include, for example, agricultural land, lakes and<br>watercourses which are also of interest for tourism and recreation, and<br>conservation of the cultural (i.e. man-modified) landscape. Every effort is<br>to be made to achieve multifaceted use of these resources wherever possi-<br>ble. The Natural Resources Act contains stipulations as to how priorities<br>are to be decided when there are conflicts of interest between preservation<br>and exploitation.</p>
<p>Our forests are among our most vital natural resources, as they form the<br>basis of a large proportion of Sweden’s industrial production and exports.<br>The long-term production capacity of the forests is, however, under threat<br>from acidification and excess fertilization. Production from forestry and<br>agriculture, in tum, affects the ecosystems of lakes and watercourses, for<br>example through nutrient leaching.</p>
<p>One internationally adopted objective in terms of management of the<br></p>
<p>Prop. 1990/91:90</p>
<p>32</p>
<p>natural resources of the world and nature conservation is to maintain Prop. 1990/91:90<br>biological diversity and genetic variation, and facilitate long-term preser-<br>vation of species and ecosystems. This strategy has been formulated jointly<br>by the International Union for the Conservation of Nature and Natural</p>
<p>Resources (IUCN), UNEP and the World Wildlife Fund.</p>
<p>The interaction between nature conservation and environmental protec-<br>tion work has become increasingly distinct in recent years, as new facts<br>about the sensitivity of ecosystems to various types of disturbances have<br>become available. The maintenance of a large number of well-functioning<br>ecosystems is a long-term prerequisite for human survival.</p>
<p>The Swedish landscape is basically a product of man’s way of managing<br>nature through the centuries. Cultivation of the land brought variation in<br>its wake, and this led to an increase in the numbers of species. Agricultural<br>developments in recent decades, with the trend towards large-scale pro-<br>cesses and intensified use of Chemicals has led to losses in this variation,<br>and the disappearance of small living environments (biotopes) valuable to<br>biological diversity. This has resulted in the situation today, where many<br>species are being threatened with extinction. The new agricultural policy<br>will break this trend.</p>
<p>Three million hectares of wetlands in the cultivated landscape of South-<br>ern and mid-Sweden have been drained since the early nineteenth century.<br>A large proportion of the threatened species of animals and plants in<br>Sweden are directly dependent on wetland biotopes. The drainage of<br>wetlands is also one of the major causes of nitrogen leaching to the seas,<br>and contributes directly to threatening the survival of many species of<br>animals and plants. In some regions up to 90% of the wetlands have been<br>drained.</p>
<p>Pursuant to the intentions underlying the Natural Resources Act, large<br>areas which have remained relatively unaffected by exploitation and other<br>types of interference in the environment are to be maintained. The unex-<br>ploited rivers enjoy special protection pursuant to this Act.</p>
<p>In order to guarantee the long-term production capacity of the soil and<br>retain biological diversity, external effects from pollution and elsewhere<br>must cease and the pulp and paper industry and agriculture must shoulder<br>their responsibility. Methods which increase potential for adapting to the<br>ecological systems to geological and other local conditions must be devel-<br>oped in order to retain biological diversity. Increased replacement of<br>nutrients and minerals will be necessary if farmland is not to be depleted in<br>the long term.</p>
<p>Nature conservation work is an important task in all sectors of society if<br>we are to adapt better to the ecological systems. Conscientious use of the<br>landscape and awareness of biological diversity are needed not only to<br>maintain the beauty of the landscape or its cultural and historical value.<br>They are also significant factors in the long-term production goals for<br>agriculture and forestry. Intensive efforts have been initiated to bring<br>about such developments. These include extensive investments in training<br>in the pulp and paper industry to increase awareness of ecological relation-<br>ships, and of the natural and cultural value of our forests. &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;33<br></p>
<p>3 Riksdagen 1990/91. 1 saml. Nr 90. Main proposals</p>
<p>Nature conservation in our countryside is closely associated with safe- Prop. 1990/91:90<br>guarding the cultural environment. For example, from the point of view of<br>expenses, it is vital that work on the natural and cultural environments be<br>coordinated.</p>
<p>To date in Sweden, the availability of clean water has not been markedly<br>limited by environmental disturbances. With very few exceptions, Swe-<br>den’s groundwater storage system is not interlinked. Owing to the geologi-<br>cal conditions, the natural reservoirs are often small, which means that the<br>spread of pollution can be limited.</p>
<p>Some 15% of the population of Sweden is dependent upon private water<br>supply, with water which is sometimes of poorer quality than the water<br>supplied publicly. Generally speaking, the groundwater quality is good,<br>but problems have arisen in recent years, for example as a result of acid<br>deposition.</p>
<p>In some parts of Sweden, primarily in Coastal areas where wells have<br>been drilled in the bedrock, salt water seeps into the well water. This<br>occurs partly because of unsuitable methods of water extraction, for exam-<br>ple excessive water removal, and also because wells are incorrectley sited.</p>
<p>In 1988, the Riksdag established objectives for future nature conserva-<br>tion work, pursuant to the proposal of the Government in the 1988 Bill on<br>Environmental Policy. According to these goals, the survival of representa-<br>tive areas of all types of natural environments must be ensured, natural<br>environments such as virgin forest, wetlands and certain aspects of the<br>cultural landscape must be safeguarded, and priority given to areas for<br>outdoor recreation, particularly in and near cities.</p>
<p>A central Action Plan for threatened species has been drawn up by the<br>Swedish Environmental Protection Agency. Today, 121 species of verte-<br>brates are threatened or require extra consideration, as compared with 105<br>species in 1980. Thirty-eight of the 475 species of vertebrates in Sweden<br>and 284 of the approximately 2,000 species of wild flowers and fems in the<br>cultivated landscape are threatened.</p>
<p>During the three-year period from 1988 to 1990, sizeable proportions of<br>the natural environment deemed especially worth saving, particularly<br>virgin forest, have been secured. A total of 75% of the remaining first-class<br>virgin forest in Sweden is or will be safeguarded in some way.</p>
<p>A total of 100,000 hectares of productive forest land has been secured<br>below the forest cultivation line, plus an additional approximately 530,000<br>hectares of forest in areas adjacent to the mountains. At least a further<br>250,000 hectares of forest land adjacent to mountain areas cannot be<br>felled, owing to extremely severe reforestation problems.</p>
<h6>2.4.2 Objectives for nature conservation and management of natural<br>resources</h6>
<p>Work on the management of our natural resources must be carried out on<br>many levels. Physical planning is one of the central instruments for affect-<br>ing long-term land and water use. The use of environmental impact assess-<br></p>
<p>34</p>
<p>ments, for instance, as is being proposed by the Govemment in this Bill, Prop. 1990/91: 90<br>will facilitate the carrying out of nature conservation work and other<br>efforts for better management of natural resources.</p>
<p>In order to achieve sustainable development, public authorities and<br>industries in all sectors of society bear the responsibility for and the<br>expenses associated with environmental protection work as a natural as-<br>pect of their operations. It is the intention of the Government to allocate<br>greater responsibility to the sectors for this work. One of their joint goals<br>should be, pursuant to the intentions of the Natural Resources Act, to<br>safeguard biological diversity and utilize natural resources in a way that<br>makes them sustainable in the long term.</p>
<p>In order to fulfil the objectives of nature conservation work it is neces-<br>sary, for instance, to concretize the goals for ensuring the survival of<br>threatened and vulnerable species in order to maintain biological diversi-<br>ty. As the national environmental authority, the Swedish Environmental<br>Protection Agency must see to it that these goals are drawn up. The<br>sectoral authorities for agriculture, forestry and fisheries are responsible<br>for drawing up sectoral interim targets and implementing measures.</p>
<p>The cultural landscape is to receive priority and be utilized so as to<br>maintain a rich variety of natural environments, biotopes and species. The<br>aims of the new agricultural policy, with deregulation and allocation of<br>considerable funds for nature conservation, include safeguarding the vari-<br>ety and wealth of the cultivated landscape, and preserving biological<br>diversity.</p>
<p>It is the opinion of the Government that subsidies for protection of the<br>landscape is a suitable instrument for contributing to the maintenance of<br>the collective values of society associated with the cultivated landscape.</p>
<p>This subsidy system is to be used primarily for aspects of the cultivated<br>landscape of special natural and cultural value which are being threatened<br>by altered land use in agricultural and forestry. Pursuant to the intentions<br>underlying the Natural Resources Act, areas of local value, as described in<br>the municipal master plans, are also to be safeguarded through municipal<br>involvement.</p>
<p>A Swedish parliamentary committee for assessment and review of for-<br>estry policy has recently begun its work. Its directives are to emphasize<br>environmental issues, and thus its tasks include the formulation of an<br>environmental objective for forestry.</p>
<p>In the area of fishing, the goal is the maintenance and survival of<br>healthy, naturally-reproducing stocks of fish, shellfish and the organisms<br>on which they feed. Aquatic species in Sweden requiring special protective<br>measures include naturally-reproducing salmon, wels and crayfish.</p>
<p>Pits, quarries and mines may be stressful to the environment, and<br>destroy the living environments of animals and plants. There is a limited<br>availability of materials excavated from pits, such as natural gravel and<br>peat, and there is also a shortage of minerals. Non-renewable natural<br>resources are to be used with caution, so that natural resources will also be<br>available for future generations. In areas mentioned in the municipal<br>master plans as being of national nature conservation interest, or of<br></p>
<p>35</p>
<p>interest in terms of the cultural landscape or recreation, permits to break Prop. 1990/91:90<br>peat are to be issued restrictively. Gravel management plans are to be<br>drawn up for areas where there are material supply problems or land use<br>conflicts. In such areas, material supply should primarily be concentrated<br>on rock quarries and other materials altemative to gravel.</p>
<p>The on-going work to protect threatened species and natural environ-<br>ments includes making more facts and figures available by making inven-<br>tories of various areas deemed worthy of protection, through conservation<br>and preservation of areas of natural interest, etc.</p>
<p>In the opinion of the Government, work on surveying threatened species<br>should continue, and the inventories of specific valuable biotopes should<br>be completed. These inventories are meant to provide a basis for subse-<br>quent determination of the need to safeguard additional areas with the<br>support of the Nature Conservation Act.</p>
<p>In this Bill, the Government is proposing tightening up of the Nature<br>Conservation Act to include new protective stipulations for certain valu-<br>able small biotopes and greater stringency in the regulations for land use.<br>These regulations will be an important aspect of future nature conserva-<br>tion work.</p>
<p>The main efforts in work to safeguard environments worth protecting in<br>the coming three-year period are to be concentrated on forest land, wet-<br>lands, and parts of the cultivated landscape. The Swedish Environmental<br>Protection Agency has reported that an additional area of over 100,000<br>hectares of particularly valuable forest biotope needs to be protected. This<br>will include protection of large parts of the particularly valuable wetland<br>biotopes as well. In light of the increased expense for conservation and<br>administration of nature reserves, etc. and the need to extend efforts to<br>protect threatened species, the Government is proposing increased alloca-<br>tions for these purposes of SEK26 and 4 million, respectively, for the<br>coming budget year.</p>
<p>Land and water areas of great natural value and especially sensitive<br>ecological areas are to be exempted from exploitation wherever possible.<br>The necessity of having undisturbed areas to satisfy the needs of man,<br>animals and plants is to be satisfied when, for instance, the laws relating to<br>the Natural Resources Act are applied.</p>
<p>The Government assumes that the municipalities are taking advantage<br>of the opportunity they have been given, pursuant to the Planning and<br>Building Act, to draw up master plans to serve as strategic instruments in<br>making municipal developments compatible with the requirements for a<br>good environment and long-term management of natural resources. It is<br>the task of the County Administrative Boards to see to it that important<br>areas of natural value are drawn attention to in the municipal master<br>plans.</p>
<p>Rapid development of genetic engineering has brought an increased<br>need for monitoring, testing and control in its wake. There must be<br>detailed analyses of the ecological risks involved when organisms subject-<br>ed to genetic mutations are released into the environment. Today, we have<br>very little knowledge of these risks. Finding an ethically acceptable balance<br></p>
<p>36</p>
<p>between ecology and various applications of genetic engineering in, for Prop. 1990/91:90<br>example, agriculture and industry is a delicate task. During the spring of</p>
<p>1990, the Govemment appointed a parliamentary commission on issues<br>relating to genetic engineering. Their task includes reviewing the available<br>facts on ecological risks associated with the release of organisms subjected<br>to genetic mutations, the ethical principles to be applied when genetic<br>engineering is used, and the organization of compulsory notification pro-<br>cedures and testing of these activities.</p>
<p>Since 1 April 1990, anyone growing plants developed through genetic<br>mutation in greenhouses or outdoors must have a permit to do so. In<br>reviewing permit applications, special attention is to be paid to the fact<br>that such cultivation must not imply risks to the immediate or greater<br>environment or a risk of depletion of genetic diversity.</p>
<h6>2.4.3 International cooperation</h6>
<p>By forceful intemational action, Sweden is to work towards the fulfilment<br>of the intemational objective of nature conservation and management of<br>natural resources.</p>
<p>Intensified cooperation with the Nordic nations is being initiated, with<br>the aim of developing a Nordic Action Plan for nature conservation and<br>the management of natural resources. Agreements are, if possible, to be<br>entered into with regard to the division of labour amongst the Nordic<br>nations with a view to working effectively.</p>
<p>Cooperation with Eastern and Central Europé is to focus on prevention<br>of undue exploitation of natural resources in conjunction with the antici-<br>pated modernization of agriculture and forestry, and to ensure that this<br>process does not take place at the expense of the areas of great natural<br>value associated with wetlands, lakes and watercourses, forests or the<br>traditional cultural landscape in these nations. This cooperation should<br>also strive to facilitate the transfer of environmentally adapted technology.</p>
<p>The purpose of the Bem Convention on the Conservation of European<br>Wildlife and Habitats is to protect European species of wild animals and<br>plants and their habitats. Particular emphasis is placed on the protection<br>of species which are threatened and vulnerable. The main aim of the Bonn<br>Convention on migrant wild animals is to protect species which regularly<br>cross national borders. The Ramsar Convention is aimed at the global<br>protection of wetlands of intemational importance, particularly as habi-<br>tats for aquatic birds. The Washington Convention regulates intemational<br>trade in species of plants and animals threatened with extinction. These<br>Conventions have entailed an improved and integrated exchange of infor-<br>mation between nations. The establishment of a Swedish data bank of<br>species is one important prerequisite for our intemational undertakings.</p>
<p>In preparation for the 1992 UN Conference on Environment and Devel-<br>opment, the general issue of maintenance of biological diversity is being<br>studied. The aim of this UN work is to achieve legally binding global<br>agreements on biological diversity. Sweden is participating actively in this<br></p>
<p>37</p>
<p>work as part of our efforts to satisfy the objectives of intemational nature Prop. 1990/91:90<br>conservation work.</p>
<h5>2.5 Waters and the seas</h5>
<p>Government proposals: The guidelines applicable to future work are<br>to be to ensure the survival of healthy, balanced populations of<br>naturally occurring species in the seas and other waters. Pollution is<br>not to limit the use of water, either from lakes and watercourses or<br>from groundwater, as water supplies.</p>
<p>Restoration of the Baltic will be given priority in upcoming Inter-<br>national cooperation. Sweden will work actively towards the draw-<br>ing up and implementation of concrete Action Plans for all the<br>nations bordering on the Baltic.</p>
<p>Waterborne anthropogenic emissions of nitrogen are to be halved<br>between 1985 and 1995.</p>
<p>The long-term target is that there will be no persistent organic and<br>environmentally-harmful substances in the environment. Emissions<br>of toxic persistent organic compounds are eventually to cease alto-<br>gether. Emission of chlorinated organic compounds from pulp and<br>paper industries are to be given priority.</p>
<p>Emissions of mercury, cadmium and lead are to be reduced by<br>70% so that, by the turn of the century, they are at a level which does<br>not harm the environment. Emissions of other important metals are<br>to be reduced by 50% during the same period.</p>
<p>The use of environmentally-harmful substances is to be strictly<br>limited.</p>
<h6>2.5.1 Background</h6>
<p>Overgrowth, oxygen depletion, and fish death were three of the environ-<br>mental problems in Swedish lakes and watercourses to which attention was<br>drawn at an early stage. These were caused primarily by emission of<br>oxygen-consuming substances and nutrients from industries and commu-<br>nities. Major investments in plants to treat municipal waste water and<br>industrial effluents and the use of environmentally adapted technology<br>have led to significant improvements. Today, the problem of eutrophica-<br>tion of lakes is limited to water systems in densely-populated areas with<br>proportionately large amounts of farmland. However, these are also the<br>areas where the easily affected water catchment and recreational areas are<br>located. The most important substance in terms of eutrophication of lakes<br>is phosphorous. Nitrogen may be a problem in parts of Southern Sweden,<br>where there is extensive deposition of nitrogen compounds and substantial<br>runoff from agricultural and forest land. Other problems include transport<br>of humus and sludge, and erosion.</p>
<p>The groundwater is also affected by pollutants, which may make it<br>unusable as drinking water. Nitrogen leaching from agriculture may lead<br></p>
<p>38</p>
<p>to increased levels of nitrates in the groundwater in some farming areas, Prop. 1990/91:90<br>particularly where the soil is light. Owing to the long period of time which<br>passes before pesticides reach the groundwater, the occurrence of pesti-<br>cides in the groundwater is expected to pose future problems. Other<br>threats to good or unchanged groundwater quality include, for example,<br>pollution from waste landfills, polluted soil and gravel pits, underground<br>oil cisterns, airports and polluted urban storm water.</p>
<p>Eutrophication of the marine environment has had effects such as mass<br>algae blooms, oxygen depletion, killing of the seabed fauna, toxic algae<br>blooms and ruined fisheries. These effects have been locally frequent in<br>some areas, such as the bays at Laholm, Skälderviken and Hanöbukten.<br>The situation was particularly grave in 1988, when there were extensive<br>algae blooms, particularly in the North Sea.</p>
<p>The conditions along the Baltic coast of the Baltic nations, Poland and<br>eastern Germany are particularly severe. There are also indications of<br>eutrophication in the open seas of the Baltic and the Kattegat. Emissions<br>of nitrogen and phosphorous are the dominant cause of eutrophication.<br>Background levels are 5 to 10 times higher today than at the beginning of<br>this century. The total nitrogen load in the Baltic must be further reduced,<br>perhaps by 60 - 70%, if the ecological balance in the Baltic is to be restored.</p>
<p>Substances not naturally occurring in the environment and which de-<br>grade very slowly, such as DDT and PCB, occur to some extent in all<br>aquatic environments. Although the levels of these substances in living<br>organisms has decreased since their use was banned, the levels in Swedish<br>waters are still raised. We still have only limited knowledge of the total<br>dissemination of organic environmental toxins and their effects. Emissions<br>of persistent organic compounds must eventually cease altogether.</p>
<p>Valuable natural and recreational areas may be disturbed for long per-<br>iods of time by acute oil spills. Our ability to combat large oil spills has<br>improved over time, not least in close cooperation with other nations<br>around the Baltic and North Sea. There is on-going development of meth-<br>ods to combat oil spills under difficult conditions and of systems for<br>effective aerial monitoring. The aerial monitoring and other measures<br>implemented to date have already resulted in considerable reductions of<br>intentional oil discharges at sea throughout Northern Europé.</p>
<p>Diffuse, continuous emissions account, however, for substantially great-<br>er inputs of oil and other hydrocarbons to the seas. As the effects of such<br>emissions are more chronic, and do not become evident until they have<br>long been influential, they may be difficult to discover. The greatest source<br>of inputs of oil and other hydrocarbons to the marine environment is, by<br>far, transport from rivers and airborne pollution. Examples of major point<br>sources include petrol stations, discharges of storm water, municipal<br>sewage treatment plants, ships and oil rigs. Refmeries and other industries<br>also account for inputs of oil to the sea.</p>
<p>Emissions of nutrients and metals increased from the early part of this<br>century, continuing until only a couple of decades ago. Since that time<br>emissions of metals have decreased considerably. Since the mid-twentieth</p>
<p>39<br></p>
<p>century the same development has applied to persistent organic com- Prop. 1990/91:90<br>pounds.</p>
<p>Sweden and the surrounding seas are also subject to pollution originat-<br>ing in other countries. These pollutants may be transported, via the atmo-<br>sphere and the sea currents, over long distances. In most cases, the pollu-<br>tant load from other countries is often greater than the load from Sweden.</p>
<p>In the 1988 Govemment Bill on Environmental Policy, the Govemment<br>stated the focus of measures to counteract pollution of the seas. The<br>Riksdag adopted this report. The primary thrust of the measures is to be to<br>limit eutrophication and accumulation of organic compounds which de-<br>grade very slowly, particularly chlorinated organic compounds from the<br>pulp and paper industry. The objectives established were that nutrient<br>emissions should be halved between 1985 and 1995 in the areas suffering<br>the worst effects and that emissions of persistent organic substances are to<br>cease entirely in the long term. For the forestry industry, which is the<br>dominant source of emissions of chlorinated organic compounds, mea-<br>sures to reduce these emissions by 60 - 70% were to be implemented before<br>the end of 1992. Emissions of mercury and cadmium, were also to be be<br>reduced by half between 1985 and 1995.</p>
<p>Of the total nitrogen load on the seas from Sweden, approximately half<br>comes from natural land runoff, and half from anthropogenic activities.</p>
<p>Agriculture is a major source of nutrient emissions. Measures have been<br>implemented to limit nutrient leaching, particularly from livestock hus-<br>bandry and fertilization. Pursuant to the 1988 Government Bill on Specif-<br>ic Measures to Improve the Environment in Agriculture, which the Riks-<br>dag adopted, the objective is to reduce nitrogen leaching by half during<br>this century in some areas. There are still substantial inputs of nutrients<br>from land-based sources. Measures to reduce nitrogen by at least half are<br>being implemented at sewage treatment plants located near severely affect-<br>ed Coastal zones.</p>
<p>A large proportion of the nitrogen entering the seas falls via the atmo-<br>sphere. In Southern Sweden most of the nitrogen precipitation comes from<br>agriculture, when ammonia evaporates in the use and storage of farmyard<br>manure. Some 60% of the total nitrogen deposition in Sweden comes from<br>nitrogen oxides, and approximately 40% comes from ammonia from agri-<br>culture. Thus measures implemented to limit emissions of nitrogen oxides<br>will also have a major impact on improvements of the marine environ-<br>ment.</p>
<p>Strict regulations on emissions of chlorinated organic compounds have<br>been imposed upon all plants manufacturing chlorine-bleached sulphate<br>pulp, in conjunction with permit reviews pursuant to the Environment<br>Protection Act. In the assessment of the Government, it will thus be<br>possible to reduce these emissions to the level stipulated by the Riksdag. It<br>is the opinion of the Government that these emissions should be further<br>limited, in light of their environmental effects, using the measures de-<br>scribed below.</p>
<p>Measures implemented to reduce emissions of metals since the adoption<br>of the Environment Protection Act have been effective. It is the assessment<br></p>
<p>40</p>
<p>of the Government that the guidelines established by the Riksdag will thus Prop. 1990/91:90<br>be able to be satisfied through these measures.</p>
<p>However, additional measures must be taken if the ultimate effects of<br>metals on the environment are to be reduced to an acceptable level. The<br>metals which should initially be limited are mercury and cadmium, as they<br>have the most severe health and environmental effects.</p>
<h6>2.5.2 Environmental objectives for waters and the seas</h6>
<p>The focus of the environmental objectives for waters and the seas is that<br>the survival of healthy, balanced populations of naturally occurring species<br>must be maintained. Quality goals must be established for lakes and<br>watercourses on the basis of which decisions can be made as to measures to<br>be implemented and future planning in the catchment area. Emissions<br>which must initially be limited to achieve this include nutrients, persistent<br>organic compounds and heavy metals, primarily mercury, cadmium, and<br>acidifying substances.</p>
<p>The Govemment is proposing that the objective of a 50% reduction of<br>nitrogen emissions previously adopted by the Riksdag now be extended to<br>cover all anthropogenic emissions to the seas along the entire west and<br>south coast, up to and including the Stockholm archipelago. Priority is to<br>be given to measures limiting emissions to the Baltic.</p>
<p>Measures being presented by the Government in this Bill to achieve<br>limitation of the nitrogen load include both agricultural measures and<br>measures to limit emissions of nitrogen oxide. Goals and strategies to limit<br>emissions of nitrogen dioxide have previously been described. Measures<br>adopted to date for agriculture, in conjunction with the restructuring of<br>agriculture passed by the Riksdag, will lead to a substantial decrease in<br>nitrogen leaching. Additional measures are described below. Wetlands<br>also contribute to suppressing nitrogen leaching, and there will therefore<br>be more extensive wetland recovery than in the past.</p>
<p>The level of ambition must also be raised for the large coast-based<br>sewage treatment plants along the Southern coasts of Sweden.</p>
<p>It is the assessment of the Govemment that application of the current<br>measures will make it possible to halve water-borne anthropogenic emis-<br>sions of nitrogen to the seas by 1995.</p>
<p>The Govemment believes that application of the current measures will<br>make it possible to reduce emissions of toxic, persistent organic com-<br>pounds by half between 1985 and 1995. Emissions from the pulp and<br>paper industry will be limited by 60 - 70% during the same period. The<br>Govemment is proposing additional measures to reduce these emissions.<br>The objective is that emissions of persistent organic compounds will<br>eventually cease altogether.</p>
<p>It is the assessment of the Government that emissions of heavy metals<br>must be further limited in order to reach levels that do not endanger the<br>environment. The Govemment is proposing that emissions of mercury,<br>cadmium and lead be given priority, and be reduced by 70% between 1985<br></p>
<p>41</p>
<p>and 1995. Emissions of other important metals will be halved during the<br>same period.</p>
<p>Mercury and cadmium are the most hazardous heavy metals from the<br>point of view of health and the environment. In the opinion of the<br>Government, all use which may imply their dissemination in the environ-<br>ment is to be phased out gradually. Special phase-out programmes for the<br>use of mercury, cadmium and lead are to be established.</p>
<p>The measures described here will, in the assessment of the Government,<br>make it quite possible to fulfil the objectives for metals, if such measures<br>are implemented together with a review of the permit conditions for<br>environmentally-hazardous operations.</p>
<p>Measures have been taken to decrease the risks associated with shipping<br>and oil extraction at sea. It is vital that these efforts be pursued. In<br>intemational negotiations, Sweden should work towards application of the<br>same environmental requirements for extraction and transportation of oil<br>applicable in the Baltic today also to the North Sea, through intemational<br>agreements. On the basis of its overall environmental objectives, the<br>Swedish Environmental Protection Agency has formulated quality object-<br>ives for lakes and watercourses. The Swedish Environmental Protection<br>Agency has also devised criteria for determining the main metals in fresh<br>water. These quality objectives should be integrated with the facts and<br>figures reviewed by County Administrative Boards before they make their<br>decisions, in order to attain and maintain good water quality in Sweden.</p>
<p>By breaking down the national quality objectives into goals applicable at<br>regional and local levels for different water catchment areas, it will be<br>possible to begin preventive work and better implement measures. The<br>regional environmental analyses made by the County Administrative<br>Boards will thus serve as important contributions to factual information<br>when priority must be given to certain measures, and in municipal plan-<br>ning.</p>
<h6>2.5.3 International cooperation</h6>
<p>The general intemational cooperation on protection of the seas of North-<br>ern Europé takes place within the framework of a number of marine<br>conventions. The Helsinki Convention regulates protection in the Baltic<br>area, the Paris Convention regulates emissions from land-based sources<br>into the North Sea and the North Atlantic, and the Oslo Convention<br>regulates dumping and incineration of waste at sea in those areas. The<br>Ministers of the Environment from the nations around the North Sea have<br>held three North Sea Conferences, at which they have adopted joint Action<br>Plans for limitation of pollution in the North Sea. In addition, there are a<br>large number of agreements on more limited aquatic areas, many of which<br>are significant to the Baltic and the North Sea, such as the agreements on<br>the Rivers Rhine and Elbe, and the Sound.</p>
<p>Sweden has also undertaken, in intemational agreements, to reduce<br>emissions of nutrients, persistent organic compounds and certain metals<br>by approximately 50% between 1985 and 1995.</p>
<p>Prop. 1990/91:90</p>
<p>42</p>
<p>At the Third North Sea Conference, the level of ambition was raised in<br>relation to the agreement from the other North Sea Conferences. Total<br>emissions of mercury, cadmium and lead are to be decreased by 70% or<br>more between 1985 and 1995. It is anticipated that the measures imple-<br>mented to date and those now being proposed will make it possible for<br>Sweden to live up to her intemational commitments. These include chlor-<br>inated solvents, metals and their compounds, some twenty different pesti-<br>cides.</p>
<p>Future intemational cooperation should focus on implementing the<br>plans adopted to date and finding working forms for follow-up. Increased<br>cooperation will also be necessary to monitor the environmental status of<br>the sea. The most important measures will be effective support to Eastern<br>Europé so as to implement substantial emission reductions into the Baltic<br>as rapidly as possible.</p>
<p>Work is under way to amend the Helsinki, Paris and Oslo Conventions.<br>The contracting nations are now considering the possibility of merging the<br>Paris and Oslo Conventions into a joint Convention on the North Sea and<br>the North-East Atlantic.</p>
<p>In November 1990, the Intemational Maritime Organization hosted an<br>intemational conference in London on oil pollution in a global perspec-<br>tive. The participating nations agreed upon a Convention text on prepar-<br>edness, contingency measures and cooperation in cases of pollution from<br>oil spills. The Swedish Government has decided to ratify this Convention,<br>and will later be proposing this ratification to the Riksdag for approval.</p>
<p>Issues about the marine environment will be important at the 1992 UN<br>Conference on Environment and Development. Regional Convention<br>work to protect sensitive sea areas needs to be strengthened in many<br>places. The question of supplementing the global Conventions, which only<br>apply to certain types of emissions, with a more complete global mecha-<br>nism will be considered in this context.</p>
<p>3 The strategies and instruments of environmental<br>policy</p>
<p>Legislation and different types of economic instruments provide the basis<br>upon which to implement the intentions of environmental policy. Since<br>environmental problems have changed in character in recent years, the<br>strategies and instruments applied need to be reviewed and to be made as<br>effective as possible. At the same time, Swedish regulations must be<br>adapted to intemational regulations insofar as is possible. This will facili-<br>tate intemational cooperation.</p>
<p>Individuals and individual lifestyles will play an increasingly important<br>role in the avoidance of future environmental problems. Environmental<br>education at all levels is one of the prerequisites to facilitate responsible<br>management of natural resources.</p>
<p>The goals and strategies proposed by the Government in Chapter 2 are<br></p>
