<p>Prop. 1990/91:90</p>
<p>43</p>
<p>related to the State of the environment. This requires highly effective Prop. 1990/91:90<br>monitoring and follow-up of the State of the environment.</p>
<h5>3.1 International cooperation</h5>
<p>The most serious environmental problems in Sweden are caused directly<br>or indirectly by operations in other countries. Pollution is transported by<br>air and water across large areas. Goods and products are transported<br>between different countries as a result of increased intemational trade.<br>Climatic change concems the entire world. Other global environmental<br>problems, such as the spread of the deserts, deforestation and protection of<br>the world’s seas and fresh water assets are of great significance to the<br>development of many countries. International cooperation is therefore<br>increasing in importance.</p>
<p>Sweden should, insofar as is possible, apply strategies and instruments<br>in environmental policy that facilitate intemational coordination.</p>
<p>In pace with the increasing significance of environmental issues, par-<br>ticularly in the industrialized nations, cooperation between States has been<br>strengthened. Most of the established inter-governmental organizations<br>now have environmental questions on their agendas. An extensive net-<br>work of conventions and other agreements has been negotiated.</p>
<p>Sweden took the initiative for the UN Conference on Environment and<br>Development in Brazil in June 1992, and has worked from the very<br>beginning for environmental issues to be discussed from a broad develop-<br>mental point of view. The Government is seeking to turn this into an<br>action-oriented conference which will establish concrete Action Plans with<br>precise goals, timetables for achieving these goals and means of financing<br>them. The Government is also working for the 1992 Conference to adopt,<br>among other things, legally binding conventions on the forests, climatic<br>change and biological diversity. One of the purposes of the latter is to<br>coordinate the work which takes place under other environmental protec-<br>tion conventions, in areas such as wetlands, and to strengthen the national<br>environmental protection work among the countries of the world.</p>
<p>Within the overall goal of foreign aid to developing nations — i. e. to<br>raise the living standards of the poorer nations — the environmental goals<br>supplement and support the other goals of Swedish development aid. The<br>environmental problems of the developing nations are closely associated<br>with fundamental development problems. Poverty itself is one of the<br>greatest threats to the environment in these countries. In order to satisfy<br>their food and fuel needs, the poor are forced to over-exploit the natural<br>resources upon which future development depends.</p>
<p>In order to be able to manage their own environments and their own<br>natural resources in a sustainable manner, while also taking measures to<br>contribute to global environmental improvements, it is essential that the<br>developing nations receive increased technical and financial aid from the<br>industrialized nations. The transfer of resources must be performed in a<br>manner that best serves the needs of the developing nations.</p>
<p>The UN development programme UNEP will, together with the intema-<br></p>
<p>44</p>
<p>tional financing bodies, play an important part in multilateral cooperation Prop. 1990/91:90<br>in the field of environmental development. The importance of the finan-<br>cial institutions depends both on their extensive fmancial transfers and on<br>their increased advisory capacity in the field of the environment.</p>
<p>The current negotiations on a European Economic Area (EEA) also<br>include environmental issues. Within the framework of the EEA, Sweden<br>will have new potential for playing an active part in environmental<br>cooperation in Western Europé, and thereby for achieving positive envi-<br>ronmental impact. Sweden should, therefore, together with the EFTA<br>countries and the EC, try insofar as is possible to work out joint plans and<br>Solutions, particularly in areas of importance to intemational trade. In the<br>light of Sweden’s earlier work in the area of the environment, it is natural<br>that we should play a leading role in this work.</p>
<p>Sweden considers that environmental cooperation with other countries<br>with similar social and economic development is vital. The work of the<br>OECD Environmental Committee, for example, is firmly aimed at sup-<br>porting the environmental policies of member nations through experience<br>exchanges, influence and coordination. Sweden is making every effort to<br>persuade other countries to increase their efforts in terms of environmen-<br>tal policy. Success in this work will lead to a reduction in the pollutant load<br>on the Swedish environment. Another reason for influencing other coun-<br>tries is to prevent their industries from gaining competitive advantage<br>through the introduction by their governments of requirements that are<br>less cost-intensive than in our country. Sweden’s economy is extremely<br>dependent on other countries, and our competitive ability is therefore of<br>particular importance.</p>
<p>Nordic cooperation has played a major part in Sweden’s intemational<br>environmental work. The Nordic countries usually pursue joint demands<br>in intemational fora, and this has had a considerable impact. The increase<br>in intemational work means that the Nordic countries should, to a greater<br>extent, divide measures among themselves on the basis of joint principles.<br>In the light of the major political changes in Europé, it is quite natural for<br>Nordic cooperation to be placed in a broader European perspective.</p>
<p>In order to shape Swedish environmental policy and participate in<br>intemational environmental cooperation, it will be increasingly important<br>to monitor carefully the way in which environmental issues are treated in<br>other countries and inter-governmental organizations. Two posts as envi-<br>ronmental attachés are therefore to be established.</p>
<p>It is also essential to improve information to other countries concerning<br>Swedish environmental policy. The Government will therefore be drawing<br>up a special information programme.</p>
<p>The Government is also proposing that SEK2 million be allocated as<br>support for the intemational activities of non-profit making organizations.</p>
<p>45</p>
<h5>3.2 Monitoring the State of the environment</h5>
<p>Summary:</p>
<p>The Government is proposing that a new programme be introduced<br>with the purpose of monitoring the environmental situation in the<br>country. The Govemment is also proposing that resources for envi-<br>ronmental monitoring be increased by SEK75 million over a three-<br>year period in order to promote a new and more effective pro-<br>gramme.</p>
<p>Initially, the programme will be designed to meet national and<br>intemational information needs concerning the State of the environ-<br>ment. The programme will subsequently be developed at a regional<br>level to provide support for County Administrative Boards and<br>municipalities in their work on environmental issues.</p>
<p>It will be possible to include local programmes in the new moni-<br>toring system, for monitoring particularly polluted areas or the<br>quality of the air in urban areas, for instance.</p>
<h6>3.2.1 Introduction</h6>
<p>Successful monitoring of the State of the environment is an important<br>prerequisite for work on improving the environment, as is access to geo-<br>logical information, and other information about the land. It will help to<br>provide good material upon which to base decisions and to establish<br>environmental goals, as well as to stipulate the necessary precautions and<br>measures and follow up their effects. This applies both in a national and in<br>an intemational perspective.</p>
<p>Extensive monitoring of environmental quality and inspection of condi-<br>tions in various affected areas are already carried out today. A large<br>number of authorities, institutions and companies are involved. The<br>Swedish Environmental Protection Agency is responsible for the pro-<br>gramme for monitoring environmental quality (PMK). The emphasis of<br>the programme is on the monitoring of environments without any local<br>pollution. The programme consists of sections which have been decided at<br>a national level and sections which are included in intemational coopera-<br>tion.</p>
<p>Examples of monitoring efforts of a more specific nature consist of the<br>Swedish Environmental Protection Agency programme for following up<br>liming activities, the groundwater observation network of the Swedish<br>Geological Survey, the forest site survey by the Swedish University of<br>Agricultural Science, and the National Board of Forestry’s follow-up of<br>forest damage. The observation network of the Swedish Meteorological<br>and Hydrological Institute for climate, hydrology and oceanography also<br>comes into this category.</p>
<p>Monitoring of the State of the environment is primarily carried out at<br>county level in the form of coordinated inspection of receiving waters and<br>regional monitoring of air quality. These programmes are often conducted<br></p>
<p>Prop. 1990/91:90</p>
<p>46</p>
<p>through air and water associations in which authorities and industry are Prop. 1990/91:90<br>represented. For water inspection in particular, activities are largely con-<br>trolled through the application of the provisions of the Environment<br>Protection Act with respect to the impact on their surroundings of envi-<br>ronmentally disruptive operations. The county administrative boards play<br>an active part in drawing up programmes and have in several cases<br>participated in appropriate environmental monitoring at county level.<br>Many municipalities have successively developed their own monitoring<br>programmes. These are primarily aimed at the quality of air in urban<br>areas.</p>
<p>There is room for improvement in the coordination of the different<br>programmes at national, regional and local levels. Today there are difficul-<br>ties in performing the comprehensive evaluation of environmental devel-<br>opments that is becoming increasingly important to successful environ-<br>mental work. Moreover, the resources allocated for evaluation are often<br>inadequate, at the same time as major administrative efforts are required<br>in order to implement special regional monitoring programmes.</p>
<h6>3.2.2 International cooperation</h6>
<p>Environmental monitoring is one of the cornerstones of intemational<br>environmental work. Some of the important bodies in this context are as<br>follows:</p>
<p>• Under the ECE Convention on Long-range Transboundary Air Pollu-<br>tion environmental monitoring work in the form of direct measure-<br>ments of pollutants in precipitation and in the atmosphere is carried<br>out. Activities also include monitoring of damage to forests, soil and<br>water changes, corrosion and the impact of air pollution on crops.<br>Sweden is participating actively in this on-going programme and has<br>special responsibility for the areas of the programme which are aimed at<br>assessing the impact on the environment of the measures taken within<br>the framework of the Convention. The programme will provide some of<br>the material for the coming revision of protocols on the limitation of<br>sulphur and nitrogen emissions, since this work will be based on critical<br>loads.</p>
<p>• Within the framework of the Helsinki Convention on the Protection of<br>the Marine Environment of the Baltic area, and the Oslo and Paris<br>Conventions for the Protection of the Environment in the North-East<br>Atlantic and the North Sea, including the Skagerrak and Kattegatt,<br>extensive cooperation is under way in drawing up and implementing<br>monitoring programmes for the sea areas concerned. In addition to this,<br>certain measurements of air pollution are being performed in order to<br>make it possible to calculate the total deposition of airborne pollutants<br>into the seas.</p>
<p>• One of the aims of the North Sea Conference is to increase scientific<br>understanding of the environment in the North Sea through research<br>and monitoring. The environmental monitoring programme is also<br></p>
<p>47</p>
<p>being conducted by a special working group set up jointly by the Oslo Prop. 1990/91:90<br>and Paris Conventions, together with the International Council for the</p>
<p>Exploration of the Sea.</p>
<p>• The European Environmental Agency is to commence work during this<br>year. One of the main initial aims is to build up a European network for<br>environmental information and observation. The Agency is open to<br>cooperation with the EFTA countries and Eastern Europé. Sweden, like<br>other EFTA nations, has declared its intention to participate in the<br>European Environmental Agency.</p>
<p>• Within the framework of the Nordic Council of Ministers, work is under<br>way on the coordination of environmental monitoring in the Nordic<br>Area. The Council of Ministers has initiated a large number of different<br>projects which together form a Nordic plan for monitoring the State of<br>the environment. By 1992, a coordinated report on the State of the<br>environment in the Nordic Area is to be presented.</p>
<p>• Increased use of information from various satellites can be expected in<br>the field of environmental monitoring and research. Sweden is playing<br>an active part in intemational cooperation aimed at satisfying the<br>requirements in the environmental field.</p>
<h6>3.2.3 The purpose of environmental monitoring</h6>
<p>The purpose of environmental monitoring is to follow fluctuations in the<br>State of the environment and to identify changes resulting from human<br>activities. Monitoring is to provide the data required in order to identify<br>and demonstrate environmental problems, both on a local and on a global<br>scale. The results are to be used to set targets for the environmentally<br>sound development of society, both in Sweden and in the surrounding<br>world, to draw up priorities and decide on measures, as well as to follow up<br>the effects of such measures.</p>
<p>The current programme of environmental monitoring covers air quality,<br>the land environment, fresh water, sea water and environmental toxins. In<br>the opinion of the Government, the programme should be augmented to<br>include the impact of land use and effects on health. Physical planning and<br>continued environmental protection work will increasingly be based on<br>targets for different geographical regions, species, biotopes and ecosys-<br>tems. The natural environment is under serious pressure and the situation<br>must be followed up through methodical monitoring.</p>
<p>The need for coordination is increasing as environmental monitoring<br>measures become more comprehensive. The Government is working to<br>achieve intemational coordination in areas where such coordination is<br>lacking. This will lead to better utilization of resources and promote a<br>holistic approach in the environmental field. Better integration of environ-<br>mental monitoring activities will make it increasingly possible to follow<br>the impact both of the pollutant load and of other measures which influ-<br>ence the environment, such as changes in the use of land. This will increase<br>our knowledge of the interplay between various measures taken to prevent<br>depletion of the environment. &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;48</p>
<p>Environmental monitoring is by its very nature a long-term activity. The Prop. 1990/91:90<br>Government believes, therefore, that monitoring must be allocated ade-<br>quate resources in order to guarantee continuity and stability, while being<br>sufficiently flexible that it can be adapted to changes in the amount of data<br>available and the nature of the problems.</p>
<p>Environmental monitoring as a whole is already generating large quanti-<br>ties of data which, however, cannot be utilized adequately because of a<br>lack of coordination among the different systems. At the same time,<br>decision-makers at all levels of society urgently need compiled and evalu-<br>ated information. The Government also believes that the general public<br>has an obvious right to be given better information on the State of the<br>environment.</p>
<p>The Govemment is therefore proposing that the current programme be<br>replaced by a better-structured system, at the same time as improving<br>coordination. PMK, the coordinated inspection of receiving waters and<br>the programmes for different water and air protection associations are<br>therefore being rearranged and integrated in a new coordinated monitor-<br>ing system. The structure and approach of future environmental monitor-<br>ing will thus be more suited to their purpose.</p>
<p>As a common basis, there will be a national monitoring programme<br>which meets the needs both of national information and reporting to<br>intemational organizations. The programme should provide data for regu-<br>lar surveys of the State of the environment. This will mean that different<br>sectors of society will be responsible for monitoring environmental devel-<br>opments. The Government is also proposing that the County Administra-<br>tive Boards be made responsible for the regional monitoring programmes<br>which are successively being developed in each county. These programmes<br>are to provide the necessary data conceming regional conditions and<br>constitute the basis for municipal and regional planning and environmen-<br>tal impact assessments. The regional programmes should be coordinated<br>with the national programme insofar as is possible. The current inspection<br>of receiving waters in the vicinity of individual sources of effluent should,<br>where possible, be coordinated with regional monitoring. Special pro-<br>grammes, along the general lines of the present structure, should exist for<br>monitoring air quality in urban areas where required.</p>
<p>Special marine centres for research on the marine environment have<br>been set up in conjunction with the universities of Stockholm, Göteborg<br>and Umeå. These centres should also be used for monitoring environmen-<br>tal change in the seas. The Govemment is proposing that County Adminis-<br>trative Boards in counties with marine centres be allocated extra resources<br>in order to enable them to produce information effectively and to carry out<br>other measures in conjunction with acute threats to the marine environ-<br>ment, such as algae blooms, Chemical spills, etc. A duty centre is to be set<br>up at the Swedish Meteorological and Hydrological Institute in order to<br>facilitate environmental monitoring.</p>
<p>The Government is proposing that the new programme for monitoring<br>the State of the environment be financed with State funds. It is therefore</p>
<p>4 Riksdagen 1990/91. 1 saml. Nr 90. Main proposals<br></p>
<p>proposing that resources for environmental monitoring be augmented by Prop. 1990/91: 90<br>SEK75 million over a three-year period.</p>
<h5>3.3 Economic instruments</h5>
<p>Summary:</p>
<p>Sweden is at the intemational forefront when it comes to the appli-<br>cation of economic instruments in environmental policies.</p>
<p>Certain new environmental taxes were introduced in conjunction<br>with the Swedish tax reform. These include the carbon dioxide tax,<br>the sulphur tax and a differentiation of the oil tax. At the same time,<br>VAT was imposed on energy.</p>
<p>On 1 January 1992, environmental charges will be introduced on<br>nitrogen oxide emissions from major combustion plants.</p>
<p>The Govemment considers that economic instruments should be<br>used to an increasing extent in the future. Such instruments should<br>be introduced for nickel-cadmium batteries. An environmental clas-<br>sification system is to be introduced for new vehicles. Increased tax<br>differentiation is also proposed for leaded and unleaded petrol.</p>
<h6>3.3.1 Introduction</h6>
<p>Clean air and clean water are collective resources. There is no price on<br>them, and there is therefore no economic incentive for individual actors in<br>a market economy to consider the environmental damage which their<br>activities can cause.</p>
<p>One task of environmental policy is to ensure that the cost in the form of<br>environmental damage is taken into account when companies and house-<br>holds choose different courses of action. This can, in principle, be achieved<br>through environmental charges, taxes or subsidies. These can be used to<br>avoid the poor production structure and deficient handling of resources<br>which arise if the cost of pollution is not charged to the operations or<br>households which cause it.</p>
<p>According to the intemationally accepted principle that the polluter<br>pays, environmental taxes or charges should be used rather then environ-<br>mental subsidies.</p>
<p>In certain cases, however, environmental motives may justify instru-<br>ments which include different types of subsidy, such as subsidies for the<br>installation of catalytic converters in older cars or for investments in<br>public transport.</p>
<h6>3.3.2 Brief background</h6>
<p>The Environment Protection Act, which was introduced in the late 60s,<br>was designed to regulate emissions from large and relatively few point<br>sources, which at that time were the major sources of pollution. Individual<br></p>
<p>50</p>
<p>consideration of permit applications and supervision according to the Prop. 1990/91:90<br>Environment Protection Act have also been cornerstones of environmen-<br>tal control. During the 70s, the consideration of permit applications was<br>combined with subsidies for environmental investments in industry and at<br>municipal treatment plants.</p>
<p>Environmental problems have, however, changed in nature. Diffuse<br>emissions from a large number of small sources have increased in impor-<br>tance. This means that there is an increased need to approach the problem<br>from a more general angle.</p>
<p>The Act on Chemical Products makes it possible to take action against<br>Chemical substances and products, as well as against goods that contain<br>such products, if they are considered to be a danger to health and the<br>environment. PCB, cadmium, asbestos, and lead in petrol are examples of<br>substances which have been regulated under the Act on Chemical Pro-<br>ducts.</p>
<p>Other examples of general regulation aimed at reducing environmental<br>effects are the Automobile Exhaust Act, which requires purification of car<br>exhaust emissions, the Sulphur Act and the Ordinance on Fuels Contain-<br>ing Sulphur, which State the highest permissible levels of sulphur in fuel oil<br>and diesel oil.</p>
<p>These forms of regulation have increasingly been combined with eco-<br>nomic instruments, in the field of energy, for example. The objective of<br>energy taxes has, among other things, been to provide incentives to trans-<br>fer to more environmentally sound sources of energy.</p>
<p>Another example is the differentiated point tax on petrol. The tax on<br>unleaded petrol is lower than on other types of petrol, and thus gives the<br>customer an incentive to start using unleaded petrol on cars that can be run<br>on both types of petrol, or to exchange his car sooner to one that can run on<br>unleaded petrol.</p>
<p>In order to encourage earlier transfer to cars with exhaust purification,<br>the excise tax on cars was reduced for 1987 and 1988 models if they met<br>the stricter emission requirements which were to come into force from the<br>1989 model year. This is an example of how regulation can be supplement-<br>ed with economic instruments in the form of subsidies in order to bring<br>forward and thus increase the impact.</p>
<p>Since 1989 there has been an environmental tax on domestic air travel<br>amounting to SEK 12/kg of nitrogen oxides and hydrocarbons. The tax has,<br>among other things, prompted Linjeflyg AB (the domestic Swedish airline)<br>to change the combustion chambers of its Fokker F28 engines. This has<br>reduced hydrocarbon emissions by about 90%.</p>
<p>The charges on fertilizers and pesticides are, like the packaging tax,<br>other examples of economic instruments that mean the user must pay at<br>least a part of the environmental cost the use entails.</p>
<p>In pace with the changing character of environmental problems, there is<br>a growing need to design and test new instruments to supplement or<br>replace existing ones.</p>
<p>51</p>
<h6>3.3.3 International developments &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Prop. 1990/91:90</h6>
<p>Many other countries have also introduced environmental charges. In<br>general they have not been introduced as instruments, but in order to<br>finance certain types of activity. In certain cases, the charges have still had<br>the effect of an instrument. This applies, for instance, to the environmen-<br>tal charges on water pollution in Germany and the Netherlands.</p>
<p>In recent times, certain countries have also introduced charges and taxes<br>with the express purpose of exercising environmental control. The Nether-<br>lands, Germany and Greece have, with good results, introduced differenti-<br>ated sales taxes in order to encourage the purchase of cars with lower levels<br>of exhaust emissions. Tax differentiation between leaded and unleaded<br>petrol is applied by a large number of countries and has contributed to<br>greater availability and higher sales of unleaded petrol. Other examples are<br>environmental charges on CFCs in Denmark and on non-biodegradable<br>plastic bags in Italy.</p>
<p>In the USA, systems of transferable emission quotas are used, making it<br>possible to apply regulations to particular regions or substances. The<br>viability of such a system must be studied before it could be introduced in<br>Sweden. The increased efficiency at corporate level would have to be<br>considered in the light of administrative problems and the need for equi-<br>table application of the system.</p>
<p>The possibility of using economic instruments as a part of environmen-<br>tal policy has attracted great intemational interest during recent years.<br>Important intemational organizations such as the UN and the OECD have<br>expressed support for the increased use of economic instruments in envi-<br>ronmental policy.</p>
<p>The 1990 Bergen Conference, on the theme of Action for a Common<br>Future, passed a resolution that taxes and charges should be used to a<br>greater extent on environmentally damaging activities and products, in-<br>cluding emissions. At the same time, it was said that subsidies to resource-<br>intensive and environmentally damaging activities should be reduced or<br>discontinued.</p>
<p>The Environmental Ministers of the member countries of the OECD<br>decided in January 1991 that economic instruments should be used to a<br>greater extent as a complement to or replacement for other instruments,<br>such as regulations. The Ministers also adopted certain guidelines for the<br>application of economic instruments.</p>
<p>The Environmental Ministers of the EC nations issued a statement at a<br>Council meeting in the autumn of 1990 to the effect that economic instru-<br>ments must be considered if sustainable development is to be achieved;<br>companies and consumers must be given reason to avoid wasteful and<br>environmentally harmful processes and products, so that resource-con-<br>serving technologies and production processes can be favoured. The Com-<br>mission was given the task of proposing guidelines and concrete applica-<br>tions of economic instruments in environmental policy. The climate,<br>water pollution, waste and agriculture were cited as priority areas.</p>
<p>This proposal also means, in terms of other products that the member<br></p>
<p>52</p>
<p>nations have the right to retain existing taxes or introduce new ones, Prop. 1990/91:90<br>particularly for environmental reasons, on the conditions that such taxes<br>neither be levied at the time of import nor lifted at the time of export, and<br>that they do not give rise to border Controls.</p>
<p>Sweden is negotiating, together with other EFTA countries, on coopera-<br>tion with the EC through an EEA agreement. It has already been stated<br>that an agreement of this sort will not include indirect taxes. Following the<br>decision of the Riksdag at the end of 1990, it is likely that Sweden will<br>apply for membership of the EC. In the light of this, it is important to<br>monitor developments in the EC with regard to taxes and economic<br>instruments. New taxes and instruments must be designed so not to<br>impede integration with the EC.</p>
<h6>3.3.4 New economic instruments in Sweden</h6>
<p>In conjunction with the 1988 Bill on Environmental Policy, the Govern-<br>ment announced a Commission on economic instruments in environmen-<br>tal policy, and subsequently appointed the Government Commission on<br>Environmental Taxes. The Commission has submitted proposals for envi-<br>ronmental charges, which have provided the basis for the Governmenfs<br>earlier decisions and current proposals.</p>
<p>These increased environmental taxes and charges must, consequently,<br>serve as financing for other tax reductions, which means that they provide<br>no new leeway for public expenditures.</p>
<p>By virtue of the recent reform of the tax system, a total of SEK18,000<br>million is being transferred from income tax to different types of energy<br>and environmental tax. This transfer of tax revenue is important from the<br>point of view of energy and environmental policies, since it contributes to<br>lower energy use and a better environment. The most important aspects of<br>this are that a carbon dioxide tax and a sulphur tax are introduced at the<br>same time as point taxes are reduced somewhat.</p>
<p>At the same time, a decision was taken on differentiation of the oil tax in<br>order to stimulate the use of environmentally superior grades of diesel oil.<br>The main environmental taxes were introduced on 1 January 1991. The<br>Riksdag has also, at the proposal of the Government, passed an environ-<br>mental charge on emissions of nitrogen oxides from large combustion<br>plants as of 1 January 1992. All these environmental taxes and charges<br>have a regulatory effect since the environmental costs are taken into<br>consideration when companies and households make economic choices.</p>
<p>The carbon dioxide tax is imposed on oil, coal, natural gas, LPG and<br>petrol, and corresponds to 25 öre/kg of carbon dioxide emitted. A corre-<br>sponding charge on carbon dioxide has been integrated in the environmen-<br>tal tax on domestic air travel.</p>
<p>The sulphur tax corresponds to SEK30/kg of sulphur emitted and is<br>imposed on coal, peat and oil.</p>
<p>The reorganization of taxes and increase in total energy taxation have<br>encouraged different forms of energy-saving and are stimulating the in-<br>creased use of renewable fuels, which entails lower environmental cost.</p>
<p>53</p>
<p>The carbon dioxide tax provides an incentive to transfer to types of energy &nbsp;&nbsp;Prop. 1990/91:90</p>
<p>with lower carbon dioxide emissions. The sulphur tax entails a transfer<br>from high-sulphur to lower-sulphur grades of oil and other types of energy,<br>together with the adoption of purification measures. Since the sulphur tax<br>proposal was presented, the availability of low-sulphur oils has increased<br>so that heavy oil is now available with extremely low sulphur content.</p>
<p>The charge on nitrogen oxide emissions from energy generation plants,<br>which is to be introduced from 1992, will be the first charge in Sweden<br>based on measurement of actual emissions. Since the installation of meas-<br>urement equipment cannot be required of smaller energy plants, the<br>charge is limited to the two hundred or so plants that have an input of at<br>least 10 MW and generate more than 50 gigawatt hours per year. The<br>charge amounts to SEK40 per kg of nitrogen dioxide emitted.</p>
<p>To avoid unfair competition in relation to companies outside the system<br>and to promote more efficient energy production, the income from the<br>charge is to be refunded collectively to those required to pay the tax,<br>according to the amount of energy produced in each case. This avoids<br>discrimination against large plants, which are often preferable from the<br>environmental point of view since they are more energy-efficient and meet<br>higher purification standards.</p>
<p>The environmental taxes and charges that have been adopted will lead to<br>a reduction in annual emissions of sulphur by 10,000 - 25,000 tonnes by<br>the end of the 1990s. Carbon dioxide emissions will be 5 - 10 million<br>tonnes lower per year than they otherwise would have been at the end of<br>the 1990s. Annual nitrogen oxide emissions will also decline by 3,000 -<br>5,000 tonnes.</p>
<p>The Government intends to raise the environmental charge on encased<br>nickel-cadmium batteries considerably as of 1992. Incentives are to be<br>introduced in order to promote the retum of used nickel-cadmium batter-<br>ies. Fixed re-chargeable batteries are also to be included in the system.</p>
<p>Environmental classes are to be introduced on new vehicles in combina-<br>tion with economic instruments as of the 1993 models. The tax difference<br>between unleaded and other types of petrol is to be increased.</p>
<p>Charges on pesticides and fertilizers should be re-devised in conjunction<br>with the discontinuation of the price control charges. An environmental<br>tax on cadmium in fertilizers should also be considered in this context. An<br>environmental tax on chromium and arsenic in wood impregnation agents<br>is to be considered in order to supplement the regulations recently issued<br>by the Chemicals Inspectorate in cases where the regulations alone fail to<br>achieve the desired effect. It is also being proposed that the municipalities<br>be given increased scope to differentiate their waste collection charges in<br>order to encourage source separation and reduce waste.</p>
<p>By virtue of the environmental charges and taxes passed by the Riksdag<br>in June 1990 and now partially introduced, as well as the environmental<br>charges and taxes proposed by the Government in this Bill, important<br>steps are being taken towards renewing the instruments applied under<br>environmental policies and making them more effective.</p>
<p>Economic instruments must be adapted according to changes in the<br></p>
<p>54</p>
<p>environmental situation. New methods must be developed in order to take Prop. 1990/91:90<br>the environment into account in the case of diffuse dissemination from<br>many small pollutant sources. In this context, economic instruments are<br>well suited to realizing the goals of environmental policy as rationally and<br>cost-effectively as possible.</p>
<p>Economic instruments should be tailored to different requirements and<br>should yield satisfactory results in terms of environmental and economic<br>policy, as well as in administrative and intemational terms. If these re-<br>quirements can be met, economic instruments can frequently offer a<br>suitable alternative or complement to other instruments of environmental<br>policy. A further point to be taken into account is that if the environmental<br>damage in Sweden were to arise in consequence of the consumption of<br>environmentally hazardous goods in Sweden, and if — for administrative<br>or other reasons — it were only possible to tax production in Sweden, then<br>environmental taxes or charges would be less suitable if their main effect<br>were that production would be transferred from Sweden to other coun-<br>tries. Such charges and taxes on production in Sweden would be more<br>suitable if the environmental damage were to be determined by production<br>in Sweden, even if such taxes and charges might lead to some areas of<br>production being transferred to another country. In such cases, other<br>countries also have the corresponding ability to introduce environmental<br>taxes and charges for environmentally hazardous production.</p>
<p>Economic instruments have many advantages in that they provide the<br>incentive to reduce emissions and thus stimulate on-going technical devel-<br>opment. This also provides the polluter with the flexibility to choose how a<br>pollutant is to be limited and to select the method by which the emissions<br>can be reduced at the lowest possible cost. Economic instruments also tend<br>to be increasingly effective as time goes on, since they affect the choice<br>between different products and the development of technology. Compared<br>with quantitative instruments, for example, economic instruments are<br>often preferable from the trade policy point of view.</p>
<p>In the light of this, the Govemment considers that economic instru-<br>ments should be used increasingly in environmental policy. They must,<br>however, meet stringent requirements in various respects in order to<br>constitute a successful and lasting factor in Swedish environmental policy.</p>
<p>Swedish experience in this area can lead the way for future intemational<br>cooperation.</p>
<p>55</p>
<h5>3.4 A new Environmental Code</h5>
<p>Summary:</p>
<p>A parliamentary committee was appointed in May 1989 in order to<br>review environmental legislation. The future work of the committee<br>will be to aim at bringing the various environmental laws, i. a. the<br>Natural Resources Act, the Environment Protection Act, the Act on<br>Chemical Products and the Nature Conservation Act, together into<br>an Environmental Code.</p>
<p>The point of departure for environmental legislation is to be<br>concern for human health and the environment. Legislation is also<br>to include provisions concerning conscientious management of our<br>common resources.</p>
<p>The regulations concerning permitted limits are to be tightened<br>up. Regulation of environmental issues related with traffic is to be<br>harmonized with other environmental legislation. The relationship<br>between Sweden’s intemational undertakings and Swedish environ-<br>mental legislation is to come under particular scrutiny.</p>
<h6>3.4.1 Introduction</h6>
<p>The Environment Protection Act came into force in 1969 and was de-<br>signed to meet the requirements at that time. Its purpose was to regulate<br>environmental disruptions arising from fixed facilities. The Environment<br>Protection Act has enabled authorities to work on sharply reducing dis-<br>charges from industries and other point sources. Several different Acts of<br>major environmental importance, such as the Act on Chemical Products,<br>have followed the Environment Protection Act. All these Acts were adapt-<br>ed to developments in their respective areas and to the specific problems<br>they were intended to solve. The Government has found that the work has<br>been successful to a great extent, but that there is now good reason to<br>perform an overall review, both of environmental legislation and of the<br>activities of the various authorities in the environmental field.</p>
<p>It was in the light of this that the Government appointed a parliamen-<br>tary committee in May 1989 to review environmental legislation. The<br>purpose of this committee is to draw up proposals for legislation intended<br>to promote environmental consideration throughout all sectors of society.<br>One way in which this is to be achieved is through the coordination of<br>legislation.</p>
<p>The committee has now submitted a statement of principles. The Gov-<br>ernment considers that future work should follow the original directives,<br>and that points of departure for the committee’s future work should be as<br>follows.</p>
<h6>3.4.2 Coordination ofenvironmental legislation</h6>
<p>The function of legislation is to ensure that the objectives of environmen-<br>tal policy are attained.</p>
<p>Prop. 1990/91:90</p>
<p>56</p>
<p>Future environmental legislation must be drawn up on the basis of the Prop. 1990/91:90<br>environmental problems known today, and must be realistic in its ap-<br>proach to the concrete handling of the problems. All laws whose intention<br>is to preserve, protect and improve the State of the environment, to<br>guarantee citizens the right to a clean and healthy environment and to<br>ensure that natural resources are utilized with awareness are therefore to<br>be brought together in an Environmental Code.</p>
<p>Provisions corresponding to the Natural Resources Act, which is gener-<br>ally seen as the principal Act, should cover the activities dealt with in the<br>Code. This will also provide a natural connection between different con-<br>tradictory interests in terms of environmental awareness and exploitation.<br>This conflict of interests has always existed in the background for all<br>legislation aimed at safeguarding the environment.</p>
<p>The Environment Protection Act, the Health Protection Act, the Act on<br>Chemical Products and the Refuse Collection Act are all laws of a protec-<br>tive nature. These Acts coincide in terms of the areas they protect and also,<br>to a great extent, in terms of the supervisory authorities. The Marine<br>Dumping Prohibition Act, the Act on Fuels Containing Sulphur and the<br>Use of Pesticides on Forest Land Act also have the same protective sphere.<br>There is now considerable coordinative advantage to be gained by bringing<br>these Acts together with other more limited Acts in an Environmental<br>Code. Standards could be coordinated and possible contradictions in the<br>Acts could be eliminated.</p>
<p>The Nature Conservation Act contains special regulations which are<br>closely associated with the interests of environmental conservation. Here<br>too, there would be good reason to include the Act in a comprehensive<br>Environmental Code. This is further highlighted by the strengthening of<br>environmental interests proposed in this Bill in the form of changes to the<br>Nature Conservation Act. The changes to the Nature Conservation Act<br>now being proposed should not be seen as an obstacle to future coordina-<br>tion.</p>
<p>The Govemment considers that the Act on Chemical Products should<br>also be included in an Environmental Code. This is of fundamental impor-<br>tance when it comes to stressing how important it is that products should<br>already be made environmentally sound in manufacture. The Government<br>considers that the substitution principle, i. e. the principle that a Chemical<br>product should be replaced by another, less hazardous to health and the<br>environment, when a substitute is available on the market, should be given<br>greater force. In principle, such a system should be based on the classifica-<br>tion of the danger to the environment presented by a product, in the same<br>way as is done today when it comes to health hazards.</p>
<p>Traffic legislation is to be harmonized with other legislation. The possi-<br>bility of increasing the influence of local bodies on the traffic environment<br>is to be looked into by the committee.</p>
<p>57</p>
<h6>3.4.3 Stricter environmental requirements</h6>
<p>Regulations stating permitted levels should be made more strict in new<br>environmental legislation in order to make it quite clear that all activities<br>which risk affecting their surroundings are to be assessed in the light of<br>human health and the environment. More emphasis is to be placed on<br>environmental awareness. The review is also to look into the way in which<br>environmental quality standards can be taken into account in legislation.</p>
<p>Like all permit consideration, the regulations for permit reviews should<br>be drawn up on the basis that all discharges from industries and other<br>major activities should be reduced to such levels that people and the<br>environment come to no harm. The committee is to consider whether the<br>regulations for permit reviews need to be changed.</p>
<p>The possibility of issuing regulations of a general nature is very limited<br>under today’s Environment Protection Act. However, this legislative tech-<br>nique characterizes the Act on Chemical Products and other related laws<br>and regulations in legislation on Chemicals. This also applies to work<br>environment legislation. The Government considers that in a new, com-<br>prehensive Environmental Code, a considerable amount of extra space<br>should be devoted to general regulations. The introduction of general<br>regulations can serve a useful purpose, particularly for activities which<br>exist in large numbers and are technically similar.</p>
<p>Individual consideration of permits for extensive activities which pre-<br>sent an environmental hazard is to remain, however, and there is good<br>reason to take local conditions into account. This is the only way, more-<br>over, to ensure that individual interests are able to influence the outcome<br>of a case.</p>
<p>General regulations concerning protective measures should mainly be<br>used for activities for which permits are not required. The general regula-<br>tions represent minimum requirements which can be tightened up in<br>individual cases in conjunction with the consideration of permit applica-<br>tions. In certain special cases, it should be possible to issue general regula-<br>tions for operations whose permits have already been granted.</p>
<h6>3.4.4 International coordination</h6>
<p>Increased intemational cooperation and different intemational agree-<br>ments have accentuated the need for coordination of legislative rules.<br>When drawing up proposals for an Environmental Code, particular atten-<br>tion should be paid to how the proposals reläte to environmental legisla-<br>tion in other countries, as well as to current product requirements in the<br>other Nordic countries and the EC.</p>
<p>In certain countries, an intemational agreement automatically becomes<br>a part of the internal legal system as soon as it comes into force. A different<br>procedure is applied in Sweden and the other Nordic nations, however,<br>requiring a national law to be passed in order for the provisions of the<br>agreement to be incorporated in the internal legal system and thus to be<br>applicable at national level. This also applies to the sphere of environmen-<br></p>
<p>Prop. 1990/91:90</p>
<p>58</p>
<p>tal policies. The review of legislation should examine whether Swedish Prop. 1990/91:90<br>legislation embraces the content of conventions in the field of environ-<br>mental law to which Sweden is a signatory, or if supplementary laws are<br>required.</p>
<p>The relationship between Swedish environmental legislation and Inter-<br>national undertakings is also highlighted in the context of the harmoniza-<br>tion of laws which will result from closer ties to the EC. Even if the level of<br>environmental requirements remains intact, certain adaptation of legisla-<br>tion may be necessary.</p>
<p>From the legal point of view, EC harmonization requires the same work<br>as other harmonization to intemational undertakings. This means that the<br>legislative work does not fall naturally into the committee’s sphere, and the<br>committee is therefore freed from this task.</p>
<h5>3.5 Building a good environment in Sweden</h5>
<p>Summary:</p>
<p>The Government is proposing that environmental impact assess-<br>ments be included in the planning and decision-making system.</p>
<p>The application of the Natural Resources Act is to be followed up<br>in planning and decision-making. Environmental considerations are<br>to receive greater emphasis in municipal planning work.</p>
<p>Legal questions concerning the utilization and distribution of<br>groundwater for individual water supplies are to be studied by a<br>Commissioner.</p>
<p>The restructuring of the energy supply will be facilitated by devel-<br>opment of municipal and regional energy supply plans, placing<br>particular emphasis on the increasing importance of bio-fuels and<br>wind power.</p>
<p>The growing problem of noise is to be looked into by the authori-<br>ties concerned. Noise and other environmental disruptions are to be<br>taken into account in the planning of main roads, industrial areas<br>and residential areas.</p>
<h6>3.5.1 Introduction</h6>
<p>In the planning and decision-making process concerning the use of land<br>and water and the physical environment in general, conflicts may arise<br>between those who wish to maintain the present utilization of natural<br>resources and those who want change. There have long been regulations on<br>how interests and wishes are to be weighed against each other in such<br>situations. Regulations in this respect are to be found in the Natural<br>Resources Act and a number of other Acts. The resource management<br>provisions of the Natural Resources Act provide common ground for other<br>laws in determining competitive issues in conjunction with decisions on<br></p>
<p>59</p>
<p>the use of land and water resources. To date, however, experience suggests Prop. 1990/91:90<br>that the resource management provisions of the Natural Resources Act<br>have not been applied to the extent intended when the Act was passed.</p>
<p>The responsibility for many of the necessary decisions required to im-<br>plement environmental policy has been delegated to the County Adminis-<br>trative Boards and municipalities. The County Administrative Boards<br>have submitted reports on the most important environmental problems in<br>each county in the regional environmental analyses. The municipalities<br>are completing municipal master plans pursuant to the Planning and<br>Building Act. A functioning planning process constitutes an important<br>part of decentralized environmental work. In addition to this, feedback is<br>required on how the State of the environment is affected. This will be made<br>possible by more efficient environmental monitoring as described above.</p>
<h6>3.5.2 Environmental impact assessments</h6>
<p>As a step in the work of protecting the environment, managing natural<br>resources and tackling current environmental damage, an environmental-<br>ly-adapted decision-making technique is to be developed and applied to an<br>increasing extent. This means that decisions are to be based on a study of<br>the environmental impact of the measure in question. This is to apply to<br>measures which, separately or in conjunction with other measures, are of<br>major significance to the enviroment, health and the management of<br>natural resources.</p>
<p>More systematic use of environmental impact assessments could also<br>help to promote management of natural resources in line with the basic<br>goals of welfare policies. The introduction of environmental impact assess-<br>ments also constitutes an adaptation to the EC.</p>
<p>The Government is proposing that environmental impact assessments<br>be made a part of the Swedish planning and decision-making system, that<br>methods be developed for regional environmental analyses and that natu-<br>ral resources and environmental aspects be given greater importance in<br>physical planning.</p>
<p>Provisions concerning environmental impact assessments are to be in-<br>corporated in the Natural Resources Act. The provisions of the Environ-<br>ment Protection Act concerning what a permit application should contain<br>are to be extended to require environmental impact assessments. The<br>same applies to the Municipal Energy Planning Act. The Government, or<br>the authority appointed by the Govemment, may ordain that an environ-<br>mental impact assessment be drawn up in any case coming under any of<br>the laws related to the Natural Resources Act. An environmental impact<br>assessment should make it possible to obtain an overall impression of the<br>impact of a planned plant or measure on the environment, on human<br>health and on the management of natural resources.</p>
<p>60</p>
<h6>3.5.3 Planning for a better environment&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Prop. 1990/91:90</h6>
<p>The provisions of the Natural Resources Act concerning the management<br>of land and water are of great importance in preventive environmental<br>work. The regulations are to be applied when considering development<br>pursuant to the Planning and Building Act and a number of other Acts,<br>such as the Road Act and the Environment Protection Act. The municipal<br>master plan is an important implement for putting the objectives of the<br>Natural Resources Act into practice. Authorities which must reach deci-<br>sions concerning the changed use of land and water are to draw their<br>information from the municipal master plans.</p>
<p>During the first half of 1991 most of the country’s municipalities will<br>have adopted their master plans. The plans are to State the public interests<br>that should be taken into account when reaching decisions on the use of<br>land and water areas and the development of built-up areas. They are also<br>to State the way in which the municipalities intend to meet national<br>interests pursuant to the Natural Resources Act.</p>
<p>The Govemment considers physical planning to be a tool for determin-<br>ing the use of land and water as well as the physical development of the<br>community in such a way as to take into account the Govemmenfs<br>objectives as regards the management of natural resources and the envi-<br>ronment and economic growth. The Planning and Building Act has given<br>the municipalities independent responsibility for the continued develop-<br>ment of the local environment. The responsibility of the national authori-<br>ties is primarily restricted to monitoring national interests, inter-munici-<br>pal interests and questions relating to health and safety. The interplay<br>between State and municipality often constitutes an important part in<br>plans to develop the infrastructure. Such issues often need to be viewed in<br>a regional perspective.</p>
<p>The Govemment considers that the link between national environmen-<br>tal goals and regional and local planning and decision-making should be<br>made clearer. The regional environmental analyses provide valuable mate-<br>rial for municipalities and County Administrative Boards in this respect,<br>both in their preventive work on the environment and in decisions con-<br>cerning individual measures.</p>
<p>Development work should take place in close cooperation with national<br>authorities. The measures presented by the specially-appointed environ-<br>mental delegations should be followed up by the County Administrative<br>Boards concerned in future environmental work.</p>
<p>The recently adopted Natural Resources Act and Planning and Building<br>Act have given the County Administrative Boards something of a new role<br>with the emphasis on long-term planning questions. Important aspects of<br>this changed system consist of increased decentralization to the municipal-<br>ities and extended responsibility on the part of the sectoral authorities to<br>take environmental and resource management interests into account in<br>their own activities. An important task for the National Board of Housing,<br>Building and Planning and the Swedish Environmental Protection Agency<br>is to strengthen the role played in physical planning by questions concern-<br></p>
<p>61</p>
<p>ing natural resources and the environment, through feedback of experi- Prop. 1990/91:90<br>ence, methods development and training. The National Board of Antiqui-<br>ties and other relevant organizations should also participate in this work.</p>
<h6>3.5.4 Built-up areas and traffic</h6>
<p>The connection between built-up areas and traffic is playing an increasing-<br>ly important part in the work of the municipal and State authorities<br>towards a better environment. This will provide a basis for the measures<br>required for, among other things, the development of a society which is<br>less dependent upon automobile transport. The trend towards increased<br>dependence on transport, resulting from extensive housing areas being<br>built peripherally, for instance, must therefore be reversed. The develop-<br>ments in the retail trade towards large-scale external shopping centres and<br>the concentration of workplaces have also brought a considerable increase<br>in car travel.</p>
<p>The plans now being considered for investments in railways, roads and<br>airports will require extensive coordination between the build-up of the<br>infrastructure and physical planning. The Govemment is proposing, in the<br>Government Bill on Industrial Policy for Growth, that investments in<br>railways, roads and major cities are to double during the 1990s. One of the<br>purposes of this is to reduce environmental problems. The Government<br>has given the National Board of Housing, Building and Planning the task<br>of reporting not later than September 1991 on the consequences of traffic<br>investments on the management of natural resources and on the develop-<br>ment of built-up areas.</p>
<p>When it comes to the siting of built-up areas in the vicinity of environ-<br>mentally disruptive activities, special consideration should be taken of the<br>risk of local disturbances in the form of noise, air pollution, etc. In this<br>respect the distance to housing is often of great importance. The Swedish<br>Environmental Protection Agency has, together with the former National<br>Board of Physical Planning and Building and the National Board of Health<br>and Welfare, drawn up recommendations for minimum safety distances to<br>different types of industrial plants. The Government considers that these<br>recommendations should receive close attention in municipal planning,<br>and that they should normally be applied when considering permit appli-<br>cations pursuant to the Planning and Building Act and the Environment<br>Protection Act. The municipalities should therefore apply recommended<br>safety distances to a greater extent and avoid residential building closer to<br>established industrial sites, or environmentally-disruptive activities being<br>allowed to come closer to established residential areas.</p>
<h6>3.5.5 The use and protection of water resources</h6>
<p>The regional environmental analyses provide support for the municipal-<br>ities in handling questions relating to water management. The national<br>environmental goals for fresh water worked out by the Swedish Environ-<br>mental Protection Agency should be developed into regional goals that can</p>
<p>62</p>
<p>serve to guide municipal work on the use and protection of water re- Prop. 1990/91: 90<br>sources. The municipalities should also be able to present an account in<br>their master plans of how good quality is to be maintained in both surface<br>and ground water.</p>
<p>It is up to the County Administrative Boards to show, in a regional<br>perspective, how good water quality can be attained and maintained. The<br>municipalities should, when planning built-up areas and infrastructure,<br>pay increasing attention to the water supply and the possibility of environ-<br>mentally sound Solutions to the question of sewage.</p>
<p>Compared with many other countries, Sweden is rich in water. Because<br>of our country’s specific climatic and land conditions, however, a large<br>proportion of the country’s surface and groundwater is sensitive to the<br>impact of pollution.</p>
<p>The work being carried out by the authorities for the long-term protec-<br>tion of groundwater should be coordinated. The forms which such coordi-<br>nation should take should be considered jointly by the authorities con-<br>cerned.</p>
<p>The quality of groundwater is deteriorating in certain Coastal areas,<br>among other places, because of the seepage of salt water, which in turn<br>depends on excessive extraction of water and incorrectly sited wells. The<br>individual property owner has the right to draw water for household<br>requirements subject to the limitations of the Water Act regarding due care<br>and attention. In order to secure access to groundwater of good quality,<br>better regulation is required than is possible with current legislation. The<br>Government therefore intends to appoint a special commissioner to study<br>the question of how the right to clean groundwater is to be assured<br>through, among other things, regulating the extraction of water from<br>individual wells by law. The responsibility of authorities is also to be<br>reviewed in this context.</p>
<h6>3.5.6 Energy</h6>
<p>Renewable energy sources will play a greater part in the future, particularly<br>in the production of electricity. One characteristic of wind power and<br>biofuels is that they require a large amount of space and that the potential<br>for generating energy varies from region to region. Physical planning<br>should be designed so that the optimum use can be made of these energy<br>sources and so that they conflict as little as possible with other land<br>requirements. The municipal master plans are of great importance in<br>achieving these goals.</p>
<p>At regional level, it is an important task for the County Administrative<br>Boards to support the municipalities and power companies in utilizing<br>regional energy assets in a manner that is correct from the point of view of<br>the environment and the management of resources.</p>
<p>63</p>
<h6>3.5.7 Noise</h6>
<p>Prop. 1990/91:90</p>
<p>Noise represents a considerable environmental problem aflecting a large<br>number of people in our country. Many are exposed to noise both at work<br>and in their homes and the surrounding areas. Noise of various sorts also<br>occurs frequently in our recreational areas.</p>
<p>All County Administrative Boards State in their regional environmental<br>analyses that noise is a major environmental problem. An increasing<br>number of people in our society are affected by noise to such an extent that<br>their health is threatened. Noise is mainly caused by road traffic, air traffic<br>and industrial facilities. Locally, shooting ranges and motor racing tracks<br>can also be perceived as a disturbance.</p>
<p>The traffic authorities have presented their view of the noise problem in<br>their environmental analyses, and propose certain measures on the basis of<br>their own goals. It is up to the authorities concerned to draw up action<br>programmes which can be carried out in stages, so that the most exposed<br>residential areas and workplaces are dealt with first.</p>
<p>In a corresponding manner, the municipalities should deal with noise<br>problems in their master plans and in their health and environmental<br>protection programmes.</p>
<p>Future work should be aimed at reducing noise to levels that can be<br>considered good from the point of view of environmental quality.</p>
<p>One problem that should be given particular attention is the need for<br>completely noise-free environments, in the mountain and archipelago<br>areas, for instance. The Government will therefore be giving the Swedish<br>Environmental Protection Agency, in consultation with the National<br>Board of Housing, Building and Planning, the task of submitting proposals<br>for measures to tackle noise in such areas. The goal should be that it should<br>continue to be possible to experience silence in certain natural environ-<br>ments.</p>
<p>64</p>
<h5>3.6 The organization ofenvironmental protection</h5>
<p>Summary:</p>
<p>In future work on the environment, the environmental responsibil-<br>ity of the sectoral authorities will increase. Decentralization of the<br>work of the environmental authorities has been started and will<br>continue. The role of the municipalities in environmental work is to<br>be successively increased.</p>
<p>The national environmental goals that have been formulated are<br>to be transferred to sectoral targets and action plans by the sectoral<br>authorities for different sectors of society. The national goals are to<br>be broken down for different geographical areas. This will make it<br>easier to determine priorities and to carry out the measures required<br>to improve the environment.</p>
<p>The role of the central environmental authorities in coordinating<br>and following up measures in the different sectors is to be clarified.</p>
<p>The work of the environmental authorities is to be made more<br>efficient. The organization of the Swedish Environmental Protec-<br>tion Agency is to be reviewed, as is that of the National Board of<br>Health and Welfare as regards the protection of health. The respon-<br>sibility of the regional authorities is to be strengthened in conjunc-<br>tion with the reorganization of the County Administrative Boards.</p>
<h6>3.6.1 Introduction</h6>
<p>The County Administrative Boards and the municipalities have an impor-<br>tant role to play in work on planning, the consideration of permit applica-<br>tions and supervision pursuant to the different environmental laws. De-<br>centralization of environmental protection work was introduced in the<br>1988 Government Bill on Environmental Policy. The municipal environ-<br>mental and health protection boards were given compulsory supervision<br>responsibility pursuant to the Environment Protection Act. The respon-<br>sibility of the municipalities in the field of waste has also been increased.<br>The County Administrative Boards took on greater responsibility for the<br>consideration of permit applications for environmentally disruptive ac-<br>tivities, as well as increased resources. At the same time, it was clearly laid<br>down that all sectors of society are responsible for the environment in their<br>own areas of activity. Both the County Administrative Boards and the<br>environment and health protection boards have, since 1973, held compre-<br>hensive supervisory responsibility pursuant to the Act on Products Haz-<br>ardous to Health and the Environment and the Act on Chemical Products.</p>
<p>Activities in practically all sectors of society affect the State of the<br>environment. Now that clearer environmental goals are being formulated,<br>the potential for different sectors to re-formulate general environmental<br>goals as sectoral goals will increase. This will bring a further strengthening<br>of sectoral responsibility, at the same time as improving the potential to<br>implement environmental policies.</p>
<p>Prop. 1990/91:90</p>
<p>65</p>
<p>5 Riksdagen 1990/91. 1 saml. Nr 90. Main proposals</p>
<p>Likewise, environmental goals must also be broken down into concrete Prop. 1990/91: 90<br>goals and action plans for different geographical areas, in order to facilitate<br>the work of regional and local authorities.</p>
<h6>3.6.2 Sectoral responsibility and decentralization</h6>
<p>In certain areas there are administrative authorities whose work concen-<br>trates on the administrative application of legislation, on performing stud-<br>ies and on the promotion of research and development. In other areas<br>there are public service corporations whose work is more in the nature of<br>business and which carry out a certain activity. Several State authorities<br>represent a combination of the two.</p>
<p>Sectoral responsibility for the environment and for the protection of<br>natural resources implies taking responsibility both for trade and industry<br>and for public service corporations to adapt to the environmental goals<br>that have been laid down.</p>
<p>Traffic is an example of an area in which a more clearly pronounced<br>sectoral responsibility has been introduced. All the traffic authorities have,<br>as instructed by the Government, submitted environmental analyses for<br>their activities and for the expansion plans that exist for the different types<br>of traffic. These environmental analyses will constitute an important part<br>of the decision-making material for future traffic planning. Sectoral re-<br>sponsibility will also be clarified through, for instance, the implementation<br>of on-going measures for shipping, aviation and road traffic. Another<br>example of sectoral responsibility is that the National Board of Agricul-<br>ture, which has been responsible for issuing regulations for the handling of<br>manure since 1 July 1989, is to ensure that disturbances to the extemal<br>environment are limited. The Government also intends to strengthen the<br>environmental responsibility of the sectoral authorities further by includ-<br>ing this responsibility in the instructions issued to, among others, the<br>traffic authorities, the national agriculture and fishery authorities and the<br>forestry organization. Sectoral responsibility should also take cultural val-<br>ues into account in the environments affected by the activities of the<br>sectoral body concemed. It should also include working out sectoral plans<br>and action programmes with specific goals for protection of nature and the<br>environment which implement goals laid down for the nation as a whole in<br>the most cost-effective manner. The Swedish Environmental Protection<br>Agency and the Chemicals Inspectorate, as the central authorities in the<br>area of environmental protection, have a responsibility to take the lead,<br>and should therefore take part in the work of drawing up the sectoral plans.</p>
<p>In order to promote environmental protection efforts, work on increased<br>decentralization of responsibility among the environmental protection<br>authorities was initiated in conjunction with the 1988 Government Bill on<br>Environmental Policy. At the same time, the authorities were given in-<br>creased resources for supervisory work.</p>
<p>Supervisory activities have thereby increased sharply. The County Ad-<br>ministrative Boards performed 3,600 visits or inspections during 1986. A<br>study has been carried out by the Swedish Environmental Protection</p>
<p>66</p>
<p>Agency which shows that about 2,700 surveys or inspections were carried Prop. 1990/91: 90<br>out by the County Administrative Boards during the second half of 1989,<br>representing 5,400 surveys or inspections per year. The number of people<br>at the County Administrative Boards working on permit applications and<br>supervision has increased sharply during the past three-year period. This<br>increase is, however, greatest among the municipal environment and<br>health and safety agencies, which have built up their supervisory activities<br>in accordance with the Health Protection Act and the Environment Pro-<br>tection Act since 1989.</p>
<p>It is still too early to evaluate the result of this change. The consideration<br>of permit applications and supervisory activities is an important aspect of<br>future work on restricting discharges from industry and other point<br>sources to such levels that the environment is not harmed. In the opinion<br>of the Govemment, there is good potential for carrying out the planned<br>review of priority activities.</p>
<p>The Government considers that work on improving the extemal envi-<br>ronment should be carried out in conjunction with efforts to improve work<br>environments. The Government will therefore be giving the National<br>Board of Occupational Safety and Health, the Swedish Environmental<br>Protection Agency and the Chemicals Inspectorate the task of studying the<br>conditions for closer coordination of supervisory activities.</p>
<h6>3.6.3 The national environmental authorities</h6>
<p>If increased sectoral responsibility and decentralization are to lead to<br>successful environmental protection the national environmental authori-<br>ties must serve as coordinators, making facts and statistics available to be<br>used as the basis for decisions, and drawing up general guidelines and<br>regulations for various operations.</p>
<p>The Swedish Environmental Protection Agency is the central authority<br>in the field of the environment. The core of the Swedish environmental<br>protection organization includes, in addition to the Swedish Environmen-<br>tal Protection Agency, the Chemicals Inspectorate, and the National Fran-<br>chise Board for Environment Protection, together with the County Admin-<br>istrative Boards and the municipalities. Another group of authorities with<br>important functions in terms of environmental protection includes the<br>National Board of Housing, Building and Planning, the National Food<br>Administration, the National Board of Health and Welfare, the Swedish<br>Customs Department, the National Rescue Services Board, and the Cen-<br>tral Board of National Antiquities. Many other authorities also perform<br>important tasks in conjunction with health care and environmental protec-<br>tion. The National Board of Housing, Building and Planning has special<br>responsibility to promote good, long-term management of natural re-<br>sources.</p>
<p>In the 1988 Supplementary Budget Bill, the Government reported the<br>guidelines for a transition to more long-term control of national oper-<br>ations. The intention underlying the new budget process is to achieve more<br>result-oriented control and greater national dialogue on the budget. The<br></p>
<p>67</p>
<p>methods for doing this include subjecting authorities and operations to Prop. 1990/91:90<br>detailed review of permit applications every third year.</p>
<p>The Swedish Environmental Protection Agency, the Chemicals Inspec-<br>torate, and the National Franchise Board for Environmental Protection<br>presented in-depth budget allocation requests on 1 September 1990.</p>
<p>The role played by The Swedish Environmental Protection Agency in<br>environmental protection work has changed over the years. As the nation-<br>al environmental authority, the Swedish Environmental Protection Agen-<br>cy must have an extensive contact network with the other main environ-<br>mental protection organizations. The Swedish Environmental Protection<br>Agency is also the coordinating body, both nationally and intemationally,<br>in Swedish work for an environmentally-adapted society. One of the main<br>tasks of the Swedish Environmental Protection Agency is to aid County<br>Administrative Boards and municipalities in their work on environmental<br>issues.</p>
<p>In the Bill on Environmental Policy for the 1990s, the Government<br>emphasized the key role of the Swedish Environmental Protection Agency<br>in environmental work. Its central tasks were described as developing<br>strategies, action plans and advice and guidelines in the field of the<br>environment.</p>
<p>The shifting distribution of responsibility and changes in the focus of<br>environmental work have led to a number of organizational reviews of the<br>work of the Swedish Environmental Protection Agency. The present orga-<br>nization will apply, pursuant to a Government decision, until 30 June<br>1991.</p>
<p>On 1 November 1990, the Government decided to appoint a special<br>Commissioner to study the future work and organization of the Swedish<br>Environmental Protection Agency. The point of departure for this study is<br>to strengthen the key role of the Swedish Environmental Protection Agen-<br>cy in the overall work on the environment, and to make the organization of<br>the Agency result-oriented, adapted to greater decentralization and integ-<br>ration of environmental work in various sectors of society.</p>
<p>The Chemicals Inspectorate is the central administrative organization<br>for cases relating to health and environmental risks with Chemical sub-<br>stances and products. The Chemicals Inspectorate has the overall responsi-<br>bility for monitoring Chemical products.</p>
<p>The objectives and focus of the work of the Chemicals Inspectorate are<br>based on three fundamental presuppositions. One is that companies and<br>importers bear the main responsibility for the Chemical products they<br>supply which means, for instance, that they are responsible for investigat-<br>ing the properties of the Chemicals and distributing information about the<br>associated risks of damage, and the necessary preventive measures from<br>the point of view of health and the environment. A second presupposition<br>is the necessity of intemational cooperation, and its strategic importance<br>in terms of monitoring the use of Chemical products, and the third presup-<br>position is that the users of Chemical products, be they companies, public<br>authorities or individual consumers, acknowledge and shoulder their re-<br>sponsibility for monitoring the use of Chemical products.</p>
<p>68</p>
<p>The Chemicals Inspectorate is to ensure that anyone manufacturing, Prop. 1990/91:90<br>importing or supplying a Chemical product takes his responsibility, and<br>knows the effects of the product on health and the environment. Measures<br>being taken to improve the availability of information on Chemical pro-<br>ducts include the introduction of a system of prior notification of new<br>Chemical substances, and expansion of the product register. The Chemi-<br>cals Inspectorate, in cooperation with the Swedish Environmental Protec-<br>tion Agency, has initiated work on a systematic survey of Chemicals which<br>may have deleterious effects on the environment, with a view to bringing<br>about the phasing out of such substances.</p>
<p>The Government is now proposing that the Chemicals Inspectorate be<br>allocated additional funds of SEK.8.6 million to expand their work, par-<br>ticularly in terms of the system of prior notification of new Chemical<br>substances and the continued build-up of the product register, as well as a<br>systematic inventory of environmentally hazardous Chemicals, and to<br>extend intemational cooperation.</p>
<p>The work of the National Franchise Boardfor Environment Protection is<br>determined entirely by the tasks designated to it pursuant to the Environ-<br>mental Protection Act. The on-going survey of environmental legislation<br>may lead to long-range changes in the responsibilities of the Board, but its<br>operations are anticipated to be unchanged during the coming three-year<br>period.</p>
<h6>3.6.4 Regional and Local Environmental Work</h6>
<p>The new County Administrative Board organization which takes force as<br>of 1 July 1991 will mean that expertise and resources at the regional level<br>will be coordinated by the County Administrative Boards. This improves<br>the prerequisites for well-integrated environmental work.
