The County<br>Administrative Boards are now responsible for ensuring that regional<br>development takes forms which are compatible with a good environment<br>and long-term management of natural resources.</p>
<p>The County Administrative Boards both implement measures and<br>coordinate environmental work at the county level. The activities and<br>organization of the County Administrative Boards are currently being<br>reviewed in order to better coordinate the county administrations.</p>
<p>The results of the review of the work and organization of the Swedish<br>Environmental Protection Agency begun pursuant to a decision of the<br>Government on 1 November 1990 will, of course, also affect the County<br>Administrative Boards. One of the underlying objectives of this study is<br>the decentralization of environmental work. This places special demands<br>on the regional authorities in their work with the environment and man-<br>agement of natural resources. If decentralization is to be successful, Coun-<br>ty Administrative Boards and municipalities must shoulder increased<br>responsibility for these issues.</p>
<p>The importance of regional assessments in environmental work was one<br>of the factors emphasized in the 1988 Govemment Bill on Environmental<br>Policy. Examples of such regional assessments include regional environ-</p>
<p>69</p>
<p>mental analyses and the appointment of regional environmental delega-<br>tions for some areas.</p>
<p>These delegations have been assigned the task of initiating measures to<br>make their regions substantially cleaner in ten years. Delegations have<br>been appointed for the areas of: Göteborg, Dalälven, western Skåne and<br>Sundsvall-Timrå. All the delegations have presented their final reports,<br>with the exception of the Dalälven delegation. Their proposals affect all<br>levels of society.</p>
<p>The Government considers this delegation work to have been very<br>positive. The delegations have shown that intensive concentration on a<br>specific area for a short time can generate trans-sectoral proposals, win<br>widespread acceptance with the general public, industry, research insti-<br>tutes and local and regional organizations, and make it possible to initiate<br>measures. Some of the proposals in this Bill are based on the results of the<br>delegations’ work, and many of the delegations’ proposals will result in<br>decisions at regional and local levels.</p>
<p>As of 1 July 1989, responsibility for monitoring all activities for which<br>permits are not required pursuant to the Environmental Protection Act<br>has been delegated to the municipal health and environmental protection<br>committees, thus giving the municipalities a more active role in environ-<br>mental protection work. The municipalities will now be a valuable re-<br>source in environmental protection work. The environmental expertise<br>and responsibilities of the municipalities have also made them better able<br>to plan their environmental work. In many municipalities, monitoring<br>work is still at the organizational stage. In conjunction with the 1990<br>Government Bill on the Budget, the Riksdag allocated increased munici-<br>pal responsibility for waste management. Most municipalities have raised<br>their levels of ambition for environmental work, including traffic planning<br>and preventive measures for municipal operations. If these operations are<br>to be built up quickly, there must be competent personnel available.</p>
<p>Prop. 1990/91:90</p>
<p>70</p>
<h5>3.7 Environmental awareness and education</h5>
<h6>Summary</h6>
<p>Education is one of the most important measures for enabling<br>environmental awareness to permeate all types of activities.</p>
<p>Environmental issues are to be integrated into basic education at<br>all levels, and to be added to the curricula used in compulsory and<br>upper secondary schools. The Government is appointing a curricu-<br>lum committee to review the structure of environmental education.</p>
<p>Environmental issues are also to be given increasing emphasis in<br>all basic higher education. Funds are being earmarked for further<br>education for teachers and for developing teaching materials. The<br>National Board of Colleges and Universities is being authorized to<br>appoint a special reference group to initiate and follow this work.<br>The relationship between the work environment and the external<br>environment should be discussed in courses for occupational health<br>and safety officers and others.</p>
<p>The Government is now proposing that the number of students<br>accepted into the program offered at the University of Umeå leading<br>to the degree of Bachelor of Science in Environmental Health and<br>Safety be expanded from 62 to 90 as of the 1991/92 budget year. The<br>Government is also proposing that the one-year supplementary<br>program for natural scientists and technologists be offered for three<br>more years, beginning in the 1991/92 budget year, with a total of 90<br>students accepted per year.</p>
<h6>3.7.1 Introduction</h6>
<p>It is a great challenge to succeed in attaining a fundamentally environmen-<br>tally-adapted and long-term sustainable development. Trends will have to<br>be broken, and habits changed. This will place great demands on each of<br>us, personally. As a society and as individuals, we must take responsibility<br>even for the negative environmental effects of development.</p>
<p>Education and training are among the prime prerequisites for bringing<br>about lasting changes in attitude and behaviour. A basic knowledge and<br>understanding of cycles, cause-and-effect relationships and environmental<br>impact must be available to all.</p>
<p>To a large extent, environmental problems have both moved closer to<br>the individual, and become more difficult to solve. As the picture of the<br>problem alters, so must the possible Solutions. If we are to be able to weigh<br>our options and move developments in the right direction, we must have<br>access to correct information on environmental effects. Eco-labelling, now<br>being introduced on a Nordic basis, listing the ingredients on products<br>from an environmental point of view, and labelling of products hazardous<br>to health and the environment will serve as basic tools for making the facts<br>available.</p>
<p>Manufacturers and importers are responsible for making facts about the<br></p>
<p>Prop.1990/91:90</p>
<p>71</p>
<p>environmental properties of their various products available. Designers Prop. 1990/91:90<br>and product developers must begin to assume that they must assess the<br>hazardous nature of various components from the design phase onwards.</p>
<p>As was proposed by the environmental delegation for the western part of<br>the region of Skåne, funds have been allocated to carry out a special project<br>in 1991, focussing on raising the public awareness of environmental issues.</p>
<p>Research increases the availability of information on how various activi-<br>ties affect the environment. The 1990 Government Bill on Research Policy<br>strengthened the position of both basic and sectoral research on the envi-<br>ronment. The aim of both these types of research is to facilitate the process<br>of restructuring for better environmental adaptation of agriculture and<br>forestry, a society that minimizes waste production, and environmentally-<br>sound Solutions to transportation and energy problems. This Bill also<br>stated that environmental issues should play a key role in all research, and<br>that environmental impact is to be analyzed and reported on.</p>
<h6>3.7.2 Education</h6>
<p>All citizens shall be offered basic facts on environmental issues. The school<br>system must mediate a basic awareness of the relationship between man<br>and the environment. This implies that a general education on the envi-<br>ronment must be integrated into pre-school and compulsory school educa-<br>tion. Special training will also have to be given to various vocational<br>groups which play important roles in production process and product<br>development. Such education must be made available at upper secondary<br>schools and in higher education. Economists, lawyers, engineers, natural<br>scientists and environmental and health and safety officers will play key<br>roles in environmental work, but the environment must be included as an<br>aspect of other programmes as well.</p>
<p>Extensive reform of the educational system is in progress. In addition to<br>changing the regulations for the use of resources, the curricula will also be<br>amended. The points of departure for the objectives to be expressed in the<br>curricula may be found in chapter. 1 section 2 of the Education Act:<br>“Activities in school shall be formulated in agreement with basic democ-<br>ratic values. All those who work in the schools are to promote respect for<br>the unique value of each individual and respect for our common environ-<br>ment.”</p>
<p>This means that schools must no longer see environmental issues as<br>separate from other activities, but integrate them in all school work.<br>Environmental issues will be prominent in the new upper secondary school<br>curriculum and in adult education. This change in the role of the school<br>will place great demands both on teacher training and on further education<br>for trained teachers.</p>
<p>Environmental issues will also be given greater weight in basic higher<br>education. Special courses and further education courses should, in the<br>opinion of the Government, be offered for teachers at institutes of higher<br>education. A working group will be appointed by the Government to<br>actively monitor work in this field.</p>
<p>72</p>
<p>Special courses will also have to be offered on the subject of waste. Issues Prop. 1990/91:90<br>of waste and recycling are an aspect of overall environmental problems. It<br>is particularly important that issues of waste and recycling be included in<br>undergraduate courses in technology in the fields of both design and<br>production.</p>
<p>Increasing demand in recent years for specialists on the environment —<br>particularly in industry — has led to a shortage, particularly of municipal<br>environmental and health and safety officers. The number of students<br>accepted into the program for environmental and health and safety officers<br>offered at the University of Umeå is therefore being expanded from 62 to<br>90, beginning in the 1991/92 budget year.</p>
<p>The Government is proposing that the one-year supplementary pro-<br>gramme for natural scientists which has begun in Kalmar, Stockholm and<br>Göteborg should continue, and be expanded into a course for natural<br>scientists and technologists. This one-year supplementary programme will<br>be offered for three more years, beginning in the 1991/92 budget year, with<br>a total of 90 students accepted annually.</p>
<p>Free, voluntary populär education, is an extremely good platform for<br>reaching widespread parts of the population with factual information. All<br>eleven of the Swedish adult education study organizations and some thirty<br>of the folk high schools in Sweden offer short and/or longer courses in<br>aspects of environmental studies.</p>
<h6>3.7.3 Environmental issues in working life</h6>
<p>Promoting health and safety in the work environment is a central aspect of<br>the policy for a living environment. Efforts in this area have been highly<br>successful in Sweden, owing to the participation of both individual em-<br>ployees and the trade unions.</p>
<p>In the opinion of the Government, there is good reason to increase<br>cooperation efforts for improvement of the work environment and the<br>external environment, not least in light of our common objective of<br>protecting human health and enhancing human well-being. In June 1990,<br>the ILO adopted a resolution calling on the Governments of the member<br>nations, in cooperation with the parties on the labour market, to draw up<br>and implement integrated policies for clean air and a healthy environ-<br>ment.</p>
<p>In the opinion of the Government, it is essential that employees and<br>their trade unions be given the opportunity to contribute actively to efforts<br>to cut down industrial process inputs and phase out hazardous Chemicals,<br>for example, which would also better enable simultaneous solution of<br>problems in the work environment and the external environment.</p>
<p>Extensive training programs are available today for industrial safety<br>officers, foremen, technical planners and others who help to shape the<br>work environment. The Swedish Work Environment Fund subsidizes<br>these courses, with grants to the parties on the labour market, branch<br>federations and other corporate associations.</p>
<p>The details of each course are worked out by the organization offering it,<br></p>
<p>73</p>
<p>and thus courses can be adapted to specific, relevant aspects of the work Prop. 1990/91:90<br>environment. Trade union courses emphasize prevention in the work<br>environment, concentrating for example on measures which can be imple-<br>mented in local planning and decision-making at a given workplace. In<br>recent years, issues of the changing work environment in conjunction with<br>computerization and the new technologies have become a natural aspect of<br>trade union courses for industrial safety officers. Special courses organized<br>by trade unions and branch federations have also facilitated the transition<br>to the use of paints and varnishes containing no solvents. This transition is<br>justified from the point of view of both the environment and human<br>health.</p>
<p>In the opinion of the Govemment, it is valuable to discuss the relation-<br>ship between the work environment and the extemal environment in<br>courses for industrial safety officers and in other training courses on the<br>work environment.</p>
<p>The National Institute of Occupational Health organizes further educa-<br>tion courses for personnel in occupational health services, including com-<br>pany physicians, nurses, and occupational safety engineers. The occupa-<br>tional health services are important supportive organizations for employ-<br>ers and employees, for instance when it comes to operational planning and<br>changes, and choice of products. Personnel in occupational health services<br>also often possess considerable expertise on the effects of products and<br>substances on human health.</p>
<p>Issues about the external environment are included in all further train-<br>ing courses for personnel in occupational health services offered at the<br>Institute. The Institute also offers special courses in, for example, Chemical<br>product monitoring and pesticide management.</p>
<p>In the opinion of the Govemment, the competence available among<br>personnel in occupational health services should be considered an asset<br>and utilized as such.</p>
<p>4 Measures in specific areas</p>
<h5>4.1 The environment and economic development</h5>
<p>Welfare, social security, and a fair distribution of wealth are comerstones<br>in the structure of Swedish society. It has been possible to extend the social<br>security systems and increase material welfare in step with economic<br>growth. Rapid growth is a central objective of any economic policy aimed<br>at greater welfare and social security and a good environment.</p>
<p>Today’s environmental situation calls for fundamental changes in our<br>attitude toward life. In the longer perspective, both material growth and<br>our general welfare are being threatened by the on-going environmental<br>degradation. Consumption at the expense of investment gives rise to long-<br>term problems of both an economic and an environmental nature.</p>
<p>Economic growth must be weighed against other political objectives.<br>Growth implies an increased capacity to manufacture goods and provide<br></p>
<p>74</p>
<p>services. Increased production of goods and services at the expense of Prop. 1990/91:90<br>deteriorating health or a degenerating environment is not a desirable<br>development in a welfare society.</p>
<p>A short-term view of growth, which does not take environmental effects<br>into account, has an undermining long-term effect on growth potential,<br>since it leads to the consumption of resources and increases the expense of<br>rectifying environmental damage at a later stage.</p>
<p>To ensure long-term growth potential, we must preserve the resources of<br>society, including the natural resources. Applying this view, sustainable<br>development is defmed as development which secures a national wealth<br>for future generations, at least as great as that we have today.</p>
<p>At times it has seemed doubtful that it would be possible to reconcile the<br>ambition of economic growth with the objective of a good living environ-<br>ment. Today, however, experience indicates that substantial environment-<br>al improvements have been achieved thanks to the resources economic<br>growth has made available.</p>
<p>Increased demands for environmental protection have been successfully<br>met to date by implementing new production or treatment technology, and<br>industrial production has increased at the same time as emissions have<br>declined. Economic growth and environmental requirements trigger in-<br>vestments in environmentally-sound production, energy and transport<br>technologies, etc. which are essential if we are to move towards a more<br>environment-friendly society.</p>
<p>We must, furthermore, not see environmental regulations in too narrow<br>a perspective. Environmental protection is more than just purification<br>technologies in production processes. Now that we have better treatment<br>technologies, we must focus on environmental and resource management<br>at all stages, from raw materials to final waste. As we have previously<br>stated, future environment problems will be increasingly related to the<br>contents and design of products, and to consumption.</p>
<p>Economic growth is an important aspect of our ability to solve environ-<br>mental problems. Thus it is important that we safeguard the potential for<br>economic growth by taking measures to encourage development and re-<br>newal, particularly in trade and industry. In its Bill on Industrial Policy for<br>Growth, the Government presents a policy to encourage further growth.<br>Long-term planning, predictability and time for adjustment will be central<br>in this context, since the effects of higher levels of ambition in environ-<br>mental policy and industrial policy are reciprocal.</p>
<p>In order to keep restructuring costs at a reasonable level, industry and<br>other actors need sufficient time to carry out the necessary investments<br>and to develop new, environmentally-sound technology, processes or pro-<br>ducts. Longer adjustment times also make it possible to impose more<br>stringent environmental requirements. Other important factors, discussed<br>in chapter 3.1 above, are that the ambitions expressed in our environmen-<br>tal policy do not to create obstacles in relation to trade policy, and that<br>they are compatible with working toward intemational harmonization of<br>environmental requirements.</p>
<p>One long-term goal is for all production to be clean from the outset. But<br></p>
<p>75</p>
<p>for the foreseeable future, in energy generation and elsewhere, investments Prop. 1990/91:90<br>in post-production treatment processes will remain necessary. This also<br>makes it vital to place increasing emphasis on imposing treatment require-<br>ments at the point where the costs of the treatment will be lowest.</p>
<p>Good economic growth requires that the economy adapt to new circum-<br>stances and altered conditions. Inefficient operations must make way for<br>the new, effective production being demanded. Thus economic policies<br>formulated to facilitate structural transformation and pave the way for<br>positive growth will also be of considerable importance in improving the<br>environment. The possibility cannot be excluded, however, that future<br>environmental regulations may lead to considerable expense for specific<br>companies or branches of industry, which will have to re-adapt, and make<br>structural transformations to environmentally friendly operations. For<br>this reason, our ambition must be to attempt to minimize such expenses.</p>
<p>Our definition of welfare, which measures economic growth in terms of<br>changes in the GDP, needs to be enlarged. The concept of welfare should<br>be represented more holistically, and should express other qualitative<br>factors which cannot easily be expressed in traditional economic terms.</p>
<p>In order to make use of the wider concept of the national wealth, new<br>methods must be developed to assess the value of natural resources.<br>Furthermore, statistics on the basis of which economic decisions are made<br>should reflect and take account of changes in the environment and the<br>utilization of natural resources. In light of all this, the Government has<br>appointed a Commissioner to study the question of with what information<br>the national accounts can be supplemented. The intention is that the<br>national accounts should then constitute a better point of departure for<br>emphasizing the environment in economic decision-making. The Com-<br>mission on Environmental Accounting (MIR) will present the results of its<br>study by 1 April 1991.</p>
<p>Environmental awareness must permeate all sectors of society, and a<br>good foundation must be laid for sustainable growth. In its draft budget for<br>this year, the Govemment has emphasized that our economic policy must<br>contribute to conversion of production and consumption in order to<br>ensure the balance between economic growth and the environment.</p>
<p>76</p>
<h5>4.2 Agriculture and forestry</h5>
<p>Summary:</p>
<p>During the spring of 1990 the Govemment established its new<br>agricultural policy. Price Controls and export subsidies will be lifted.<br>One of the objectives of the reform is to improve the environment.<br>The environmental objective of the new agricultural policy is to<br>safeguard wealth and variety in the cultivated landscape and main-<br>tain biological diversity. Valuable aspects of the natural and cultural<br>landscapes are also to be protected. There will be a three-year<br>subsidy of SEK550 million for nature conservation.</p>
<p>Nutrient leaching from agriculture is to be reduced by half be-<br>tween 1985 and 1995. Ammonia emissions are to be reduced by<br>25%, as a first step, by 1995. A number of measures have already<br>been implemented, and supplementary measures are now being<br>proposed to make it possible to achieve these goals.</p>
<p>The cadmium content of artificial fertilizer must be restricted. A<br>special Commissioner will be appointed to determine, inter alia, the<br>need of a tax system for cadmium in artificial fertilizer.</p>
<p>The use of pesticides has been cut back by half in the last five<br>years and will now be reduced by an additional 50% by the mid-<br>1990s.</p>
<p>A review of the forestry policy has been initiated, and will include<br>the detailing of an environmental objective for forestry policy.</p>
<p>The Government is proposing allocation of reserve funds of<br>SEK58.1 million for environmental protection measures in agricul-<br>ture. The Government is also proposing the introduction of an<br>environmental tax on liquid ammonia. The Nature Conservation<br>Act is to be made more stringent in terms of regulations on dewater-<br>ing.</p>
<h6>4.2.1 Introduction</h6>
<p>The focus of agricultural policy was changed in the decision passed by the<br>Riksdag during the spring of 1990, with minor modifications in relation to<br>the Government Bill on Agricultural Policy. The parliamentary decision<br>was preceded by many years of intensive commission work, one of the<br>aims of which was to develop an agricultural policy bringing the demands<br>of the contemporary consumer for healthful, inexpensive food into line<br>with a rational, environmentally-adapted agricultural system. The deci-<br>sion of the Riksdag contained three main points. Price Controls and export<br>subsidies will be lifted as of 1 July 1991. Border Controls are to be reduced,<br>to be compatible with the projected GATT agreement. Measures oriented<br>towards the individual farmer will make it possible to fulfil certain general<br>goals on the free market. These include issues of environmental awareness,<br>contingency readiness, and regional distribution of agricultural produc-<br>tion. The objectives of the new agricultural policy are to safeguard the<br></p>
<p>Prop. 1990/91:90</p>
<p>77</p>
<p>variation and wealth of the cultivated landscape, maintain genetic vari- Prop. 1990/91:90<br>ation and biological diversity and minimize plant nutrient leaching. The<br>wealth and variety of the cultivated landscape is a key factor for preserving<br>the flora and fauna. For these reasons, environmental protection and<br>nature conservation have been emphasized in the new agricultural policy.<br>The open landscape is to be maintained in areas where it is considered<br>important from an environmental point of view.</p>
<p>Throughout the centuries, agriculture in Sweden has shaped the rural<br>landscape and contributed to its openness. Agriculture has also impacted<br>on the changes in, and sometimes the expansion of, the numbers of<br>species. However, in recent decades, the increasing mechanization of<br>agriculture and the intensive use of Chemicals has brought a number of<br>negative environmental effects in its wake. For example, the use of pesti-<br>cides poses a severe threat to animals and plants in the cultivated land-<br>scape. Implementation of measures previously adopted by the Govern-<br>ment means that the use of pesticides is decreasing today. The use of<br>artificial fertilizers and farmyard manure has led to increased nutrient<br>leaching to watercourses and ammonia evaporation to the air. Increased<br>large-scale farming and drainage of wetlands is resulting in depletion of the<br>biotopes.</p>
<p>In 1988 the Riksdag passed regulations to reduce nutrient leaching from<br>farming, pursuant to the Government Bill on Measures to Improve the<br>Environment in Agriculture, etc. Most of these measures dealt with re-<br>quirements of increased storage capacity for farmyard manure, more strin-<br>gent requirements for fertilization of fields, regulations for the growing of<br>catch crops, and a raising of the environmental tax on artificial fertilizer,<br>as an incentive to reduce its use. The more stringent regulations were<br>initially imposed in Coastal zones adjacent to the most severely-affected<br>sea areas. The objective was to achieve a 50% reduction of nutrient<br>leaching in highly-polluted areas by the year 2000. Additional measures<br>will, however, be necessary if this objective is to be attained, and if effects<br>on the seas are to be limited. In intemational agreements, this objective<br>has been tightened up, and there is now to be a 50% reduction of all<br>agricultural nutrient leaching by 1995, to make it possible for Sweden to<br>reduce anthropogenic emissions of nutrients by 50%.</p>
<p>The objective, as previously stated by the Government, is to reduce risks<br>to health and the environment from the use of Chemical pesticides in<br>agriculture. The first step, to attain a 50% reduction between 1985 and<br>1990, has basically been accomplished. According to the Riksdag decision<br>pursuant to the 1990 Government Bill on Agricultural Policy, the use of<br>pesticides will be reduced by a further 50% by early in the second half of<br>the 1990s.</p>
<p>It is the opinion of the Government that the agricultural reform will<br>further limit the negative impact of agriculture on the environment. The<br>reform will make it possible to better adapt agriculture to the environment<br>in the future.</p>
<p>In conjunction with the reform, crop production will be restructured.<br>The Government has allocated funding for subsidies for farmland convert-<br></p>
<p>78</p>
<p>ed to other sustained uses than agricultural production, such as the cultiva-<br>tion of energy forest or deciduous forest, or the establishment of wetlands.</p>
<p>The Government has assigned the Swedish Environmental Protection<br>Agency, in consultation with the National Board of Agriculture and the<br>Central Board of National Antiquities, the task of monitoring and assess-<br>ing the environmental impact of the new agricultural policy. They have<br>also been assigned to evaluate the effects, demand for and scope of subsi-<br>dies for nature conservation, as well as the form they should take, and to<br>review the application of parts of the Act on the Maintenance of Agricul-<br>tural Land.</p>
<p>Cultivation of bio-fuels in plains areas and establishment of wetlands<br>contribute to reduction of nutrient leaching from agricultural soil. An<br>“establishment subsidy” may be granted for planting deciduous or energy<br>forest. Subsidies for cultivation of bio-fuels in plains areas is to be struc-<br>tured so that nutrient leaching from agriculture is reduced and valuable<br>natural and cultural aspects of the landscape are retained.</p>
<h6>4.2.2 Nutrients, etc.</h6>
<p>Agriculture is still one of the main sources of Swedish inputs to the<br>nutrient load on the seas, the surface water and groundwater. In some<br>areas with intensive agriculture, it may even be the main source.</p>
<p>The regulations on storage and management of farmyard manure imple-<br>mented to date, in conjunction with the increased environmental tax on<br>artificial fertilizers, have already begun to be effective. Yet they are not<br>sufficient to achieve a 50% reduction in nitrogen emissions. The restruc-<br>turing of agriculture is also expected to contribute markedly to decreased<br>nutrient leaching.</p>
<p>The Government has determined that stipulations are to be issued<br>including stricter requirements for autumn and winter crop raising, which<br>is one of the most cost-effective means of reducing nutrient leaching. The<br>Government is proposing that funds be earmarked for information and<br>pilot projects on autumn and winter crop raising.</p>
<p>Another major source of the nitrogen load is ammonia emissions. These<br>emissions are basically a national problem, as ammonia disseminates<br>across far smaller areas than, for example, nitrogen oxides. Some 40% of<br>the ammonia deposition comes from Swedish sources, primarily from<br>agriculture in conjunction with farmyard manure management. Measures<br>can be taken to limit ammonia evaporation to air originating from manure<br>handling. Development of manure spreading equipment technology will<br>lead to additional improvements. The initial objective is to limit ammonia<br>evaporation by 25% before 1995, in relation to current levels. The poten-<br>tial for limiting emissions by 50% before the year 2000 is being investigat-<br>ed.</p>
<p>A supplementary program for limitation of nitrogen emissions from<br>agriculture to the soil, water and air is being drawn up by the National<br>Board of Agriculture in consultation with the Swedish Environmental<br>Protection Agency. The Government is proposing allocation of an addi-<br></p>
<p>Prop. 1990/91:90</p>
<p>79</p>
<p>tional SEK58.1 million for environmental protection measures in agricul- Prop. 1990/91: 90<br>ture. This funding is for testing and development of manure management<br>techniques and other measures to reduce ammonia emissions, as well as<br>the development of methods for type approval and serial testing of fertil-<br>ization equipment.</p>
<p>Another means of reducing nitrogen leaching would be economic instru-<br>ments to reduce use of artificial fertilizers. The total quantities of fertiliz-<br>ers used in agriculture in the last five years has decreased by 12%. The<br>Government is proposing an environmental tax on liquid ammonia corre-<br>sponding to the tax already levied on other artificial fertilizers. In conjunc-<br>tion with the lifting of the price control on artificial fertilizers, the Govern-<br>ment will consider whether an environmental tax is a cost-effective means<br>of achieving further limitations of nutrient leaching from excessive use of<br>artificial fertilizers.</p>
<p>The cadmium content of artificial fertilizer must be sharply limited,<br>primarily owing to its effects on human health. A Government Commis-<br>sioner is being appointed to investigate the need for a tax on cadmium in<br>artificial fertilizer. His assignment is also to present a proposal for a<br>maximum permissible cadmium content in artificial fertilizer.</p>
<h6>4.2.3 Nature conservation</h6>
<p>Many measures have been taken to protect the cultivated landscape in<br>Sweden. A special subsidy for the conservation of the cultivated landscape,<br>referred to as the NOLA subsidy, was introduced in 1986. In 1987 the<br>National Board of Antiquities was allocated funds for the implementation<br>of measures for maintenance of the cultural landscape. The 1990 decisions<br>on agricultural policy included the introduction of a new subsidy for such<br>conservation, of roughly SEK55O million for three years.</p>
<p>The Act on Maintenance of Farmland stipulates that before farmland,<br>including pasture, is taken out of production notification must be submit-<br>ted to the County Administrative Board. In cases where this land is of key<br>interest from the point of view of the natural or cultural environment, an<br>agreement may be entered between the farmer and the State that the farmer<br>will be reimbursed for continuing to farm the land. It is also possible to<br>enter into similar agreements about adjacent land when, in the assessment<br>of the County Administrative Board, such land is important in creating the<br>holistic view of the landscape required from the point of view of the<br>natural or cultural landscape. Conservation of this kind can only be<br>meaningful if there are economically self-sustaining farms. The authorities<br>have special funds for nature conservation. Reimbursement for landscape<br>conservation, in combination with the instruments made available pursu-<br>ant to the Nature Conservation Act and voluntary measures implemented<br>by the municipalities, etc. all mean that there is good potential for ensuring<br>the maintenance of valuable aspects of the cultivated landscape for the<br>future.</p>
<p>80</p>
<h6>4.2.4 Pesticides</h6>
<p>Prop. 1990/91:90</p>
<p>The Govemment is proposing that the environmental tax on pesticides be<br>restructured in conjunction with the transformation of price Controls to<br>environmental taxes. It should be adapted to the structure of the current<br>price Controls, which would mean that the tax would be levied in a dose-<br>related fashion, depending on the risks associated with the agent, rather<br>than being levied per kilo used.</p>
<p>The Chemicals Inspectorate is to be authorized to investigate the possi-<br>bility of establishing differentiated taxes in relation to the hazardous<br>properties of the pesticides and the risks associated with their use. This<br>would facilitate steering developments in the direction of the environmen-<br>tal objectives, both in terms of a transition to pesticides with fewer risks<br>and through less use of pesticides. The point of this restructuring is to be<br>able to achieve the required 50% reduction in use of pesticides between<br>1990 and the early part of the second half of the 1990s.</p>
<p>At present there is a ban on the use of growth regulation agents, with the<br>exception of use for rye cultivation. The use of growth regulation agents<br>makes it possible to increase the amount of nitrogen used without increas-<br>ing the risk of lodge stands, but it increases the risk of plant nutrient<br>leaching and pollution of aquatic systems. As there are no types of rye<br>available today which yield acceptable crops and qualities without growth<br>regulation agents, however, rye will be exempted from the ban in the<br>future as well.</p>
<p>Biological pesticides containing naturally-occurring organisms are used<br>to some, but to date only a very limited, extent in Sweden. One inhibiting<br>factor to the introduction of biological pesticides has been competition<br>from the well-established, relatively inexpensive Chemical agents. In recent<br>years, however, the picture has changed, owing to the criticisms levelled<br>against Chemical agents, developments in genetics, etc. If biological pesti-<br>cides are preferable from the point of view of health and the environment,<br>they may become an important alternative to Chemical agents. The intro-<br>duction of biological pesticides may, however, imply risks to the environ-<br>ment. For this reason, a system for prior inspection of biological pesticides<br>will be introduced.</p>
<h6>4.2.5 The need for agricultural irrigation</h6>
<p>In restructuring crop production and the cultivation of energy crops, it is<br>particularly important to take access to water into account. Energy crops<br>may require more water than the crops currently being cultivated. Today,<br>agriculture is already the third largest source of water consumption in<br>Sweden. There has been competition for water in many parts of Sweden<br>during the dry summers of recent years. Existing conflicts and problems<br>have often been brought to a head over water shortages in the summer,<br>especially with the increased demand for water in recent years. In areas<br>with intensive agriculture, it is now essential to adapt crop cultivation to<br>the existing availability of water, and to ensure that, when necessary, water<br>will be collected and stored.</p>
<p>81</p>
<p>6 Riksdagen 1990/91. 1 saml. Nr 90. Main proposals</p>
<p>In light of the above, the Govemment intends to assign the National Prop. 1990/91:90<br>Board of Agriculture the task of examining in detail the future demand for<br>irrigation in agriculture, and to propose Solutions to solving the problem of<br>access to water where needed.</p>
<h6>4.2.6 Forestry</h6>
<p>The current Swedish forestry policy has been in effect since 1979. It<br>emphasizes, for example, the need to take interests of nature conservation<br>into account. Since that time, many aspects of forestry have changed,<br>including the importance of forestry to the Swedish economy and energy<br>supply, as well as the intemational situation. Our forests are also now<br>under threat from various air pollutants, including sulphur and nitrogen<br>oxides. We also have greater awareness today of the need to maintain<br>biological diversity in nature, and to allow our forestry activities to build<br>on their natural prerequisites. In view of all this, the Government has<br>appointed a parliamentary committee to reconsider the objectives and<br>instruments of our forestry policy and propose the necessary amendments<br>to it. One of the tasks of the committee is to present a detailed environ-<br>mental objective for forestry.</p>
<h6>4.2.7 Wetland drainage</h6>
<p>One particular problem noted in both agriculture and forestry is protection<br>of wetlands. Wetlands contribute effectively to the prevention of nitrogen<br>runoff, as well as being the natural habitat of a large number of animal and<br>plant species, many of which are threatened with extinction. Totally speak-<br>ing, approximately one-third of the wetlands in Sweden have been drained<br>since the early nineteenth century, and 25% of this land has been used for<br>forestry. In some farming areas 90% of the wetlands are gone. Some 15,000<br>hectares are dewatered annually for forestry purposes, and another 30,000<br>hectares are ditched.</p>
<p>This development must be stopped, as wetlands are amongst the most<br>important parts of the forest landscape and are a highly significant means<br>of reducing nutrient leaching to the sea. Wetland restoration is vital both<br>in terms of nature conservation and to reduce plant nutrient leaching. The<br>Government is proposing amendment of the Nature Conservation Act,<br>and introduction of the possibility of prohibiting ditching of areas where,<br>from a nature conservation point of view, it is especially important to<br>maintain wetlands. Pursuant to this proposal, the County Administrative<br>Boards are to be notified of all ditching. It is possible to grant the new<br>establishment subsidies passed by the Riksdag for restoration of wetlands<br>from agricultural land.</p>
<p>82</p>
<h5>4.3 Traffic</h5>
<p>Prop. 1990/91:90</p>
<p>Summary:</p>
<p>Hazards to health are to be drastically reduced by the early part of<br>the coming century. The environmentally-disruptive effects of traf-<br>fic are to be sharply limited. The Govemment expects the environ-<br>mental effects caused by Swedish traffic to be done away with by the<br>year 20 i 0. The effects of traffic on climatic change are to be limited<br>in accordance with the strategy for reducing climatic impact.</p>
<p>Responsibility for the cost of traffic is to be reviewed. Invest-<br>ments in the infrastructure are to increase in order to reduce envi-<br>ronmental damage and to increase accessibility. A programme<br>aimed both at reducing the environmental impact of traffic and at<br>improving accessibility is to be implemented in Sweden’s three<br>largest cities.</p>
<p>The Government is prepared to allocate SEK5,500 million for the<br>financing of measures in the large city areas.</p>
<p>Intemational cooperation is to be intensified. The Government<br>intends, within the framework of the EEA (European Economic<br>Area) process, to work towards limiting the exhaust emission re-<br>quirements for cars, light trucks and buses as soon as possible and<br>not later than 1996. The Governmenfs ambition is also to introduce<br>stricter regulations concerning the sulphur content of fuels used in<br>ferries and other vessels through wide-ranging Nordic cooperation.<br>Intemational exhaust emission requirements should be introduced<br>for aviation.</p>
<p>Measures are to be taken to reduce emissions from individual<br>vehicles. Such measures include the introduction of an environmen-<br>tal classification system aimed at providing economic incentives for<br>more environmentally sound vehicles. An environmental classifica-<br>tion system will be introduced for cars, buses and trucks from the<br>1993 model year. The environmental classification of diesel fuels is<br>to be made more distinct.</p>
<p>A requirement for environmental impact assessments in the plan-<br>ning of new roads is to be imposed. Environmental impact assess-<br>ments are also to be drawn up when projecting new track-bound<br>systems. In road planning, environmental impact assessments are to<br>be introduced at the planning stage.</p>
<p>In the Govemment Bill on Energy Policy, the Government is<br>proposing that SEK30 million per year be allocated for four years<br>for the testing and development of motor alcohols.</p>
<h6>4.3.1 Introduction</h6>
<p>Access to transport and Communications has been a cornerstone of the<br>development of societies throughout the ages. It is through communica-<br>tion between people and places that societies are formed, survive and<br>develop.</p>
<p>83</p>
<p>Throughout history, the development of transportation has gone hand in Prop. 1990/91: 90<br>hand with the development of society in other respects. The technical and<br>economic conditions which have restricted access to transport at different<br>stages of development have also imposed clear limits on what could be<br>achieved in other areas of society, severely restricting the ability to meet<br>various material, social and cultural needs.</p>
<p>The overall objective of transport policies is to offer the nation’s citizens<br>and trade and industry in all parts of the country satisfactory, safe, healthy<br>and environmentally sound transportation at the lowest possible cost to<br>the nation. One of the important goals of traffic policy is thus to contribute<br>to a good environment. The objective should be to radically reduce harm-<br>ful emissions from the transport system.</p>
<p>There may be conflicts between the environmental goal and other goals<br>of traffic policies. When the cost of a trip increases, the possibility for<br>people to travel is reduced and with it their access to places of work, for<br>instance.</p>
<p>The objective of future work on the environmental adaptation of traffic<br>is to achieve a balance between the need to develop the transport sector in<br>order to meet the transportation requirements of the 1990s and the need to<br>sharply reduce the sector’s impact on the environment.</p>
<p>The responsibility for the cost of traffic is an important point of depar-<br>ture in this context. It implies that all types of traffic and all vehicles are to<br>bear their own cost to the nation’s economy. As a further step towards this<br>objective, the Riksdag decided in connection with the Government Bill on<br>Transport Policies in 1988 to make certain increases in the petrol tax and<br>kilometre tax. Environmental taxes have, for instance, been introduced for<br>road traffic and aviation in conjunction with the tax reform. A review of<br>responsibility for costs is currently being carried out.</p>
<p>The environmentally-motivated measures that were adopted during the<br>70s and 80s concentrated to a large extent on individual vehicles. Other<br>measures such as reduced speed limits on certain roads and increased<br>requirements for the environment to be taken into consideration in invest-<br>ment planning have also been implemented, however. These measures are<br>now beginning to show results. Emissions of lead from road traffic have<br>declined sharply. The results of measures taken to restrict emissions of,<br>among other things, nitrogen oxides, carbon monoxide and hydrocarbons,<br>mainly from cars but also from trucks and buses, have also begun to<br>emerge. In order to achieve the long-term goals, the Govemment is pro-<br>posing further measures.</p>
<p>At the same time, other problems are receiving increasing attention.<br>This applies mainly to the transport sector’s emissions of carbon dioxide.<br>Only a few years ago, the significance of these emissions was not realized,<br>but they are now receiving a great deal of attention. Another example<br>consists of emissions of sulphur and nitrogen oxides by the shipping<br>industry, which are considerably higher than was previously estimated.</p>
<p>The City Traffic Commission has also shed new light on the problems<br>caused by traffic in the large cities. The harm caused to human health by<br>emissions from traffic is particularly important in this context.</p>
<p>84</p>
<p>Far-reaching measures will be required in order to solve these problems Prop. 1990/91:90<br>and to achieve existing objectives. Efforts will be required in the transport<br>sector, as in other sectors. The Government is therefore proposing that<br>environmental objectives in the traffic sector should be as follows:</p>
<p>• Effects on health are to be sharply reduced by the beginning of the next<br>century. This means that measures must be taken in the large cities,<br>alongside measures to reduce emissions of particulates from diesel-<br>driven vehicles and stricter exhaust emission regulations for other vehi-<br>cles.</p>
<p>• The environmentally detrimental impact of traffic is to be sharply<br>limited. The Government considers that effects such as acidification<br>and eutrophication caused by Swedish traffic can be drasticially reduced<br>by the year 2010. The emissions of nitrogen oxides, sulphur dioxide and<br>hydrocarbons from Swedish traffic can be sharply reduced through<br>stricter fuel and exhaust emission requirements.</p>
<p>• The contribution of traffic to climatic change is to be limited in accor-</p>
<p>dance with the climate strategy.</p>
<p>There is thus a pressing need of measures, which requires a strict<br>ordering of priorities. The Government considers that work should con-<br>centrate on measures aimed at traffic in the large cities, investments in the<br>rail network and stricter requirements concerning vehicles and fuel. Closer<br>cooperation with Western Europé is making coordinated effort of this sort<br>possible.</p>
<h6>4.3.2 International cooperation</h6>
<p>Sweden has performed significant work through the Stockholm Group,<br>which was formed in 1985 on the initiative of Sweden. The group includes<br>all the EFTA countries except Iceland, together with Denmark, Germany,<br>the Netherlands and Canada, and has worked out agreements on car<br>exhaust emission regulations which provide the basis for the national<br>regulations introduced by each individual country.</p>
<p>International interest in work to limit the impact of traffic on the<br>environment is now increasing sharply. In November 1989, for instance,<br>the permanent European Conference of Ministers of Transport, ECMT,<br>adopted a special traffic and environment resolution. This resolution<br>underlines the need of taking further action in order to improve environ-<br>mental adaptation and the use of energy in traffic. A special intemational<br>hearing with the world’s car and fuel industries was arranged in the<br>autumn of 1990. At Swedish initiative, traffic and environmental issues<br>were taken up at the joint EC/EFTA meeting of Environment Ministers in<br>November 1990. It is crucial to success in this area that the governments of<br>Europé work together for stricter requirements regarding all emissions of<br>harmful substances. The EC is considering proposals on the introduction<br>of stricter exhaust emission requirements for cars from 1993.</p>
<p>The Government considers that Sweden should play an even more<br>active part in achieving intemational agreements in this field in the future.<br>The chances of success in such work have been improved by virtue of the<br></p>
<p>85</p>
<p>closer cooperation which is emerging in Western Europé. New opportuni-<br>ties are emerging to further environmental work and to improve the<br>possibilities of counteracting the regional and global environmental prob-<br>lems caused by the transport sector. The demands for joint action together<br>with other EFTA countries and with the EC which this implies can and<br>must be developed in order to improve the environment.</p>
<h6>4.3.3 Large cities and urban areas</h6>
<p>The expansion of motor traffic has entailed increasing hazards to the<br>environment and health and deteriorating accessibility on roads and<br>streets, particularly in the major city areas. Traffic is now without doubt<br>the greatest source of environmental damage. The worst aspects of this<br>consist of air pollution and the locally high levels of noise along main roads<br>and streets with heavy traffic.</p>
<p>The Government has appointed special negotiators for the three large<br>city areas. Their task has been, together with local and regional actors, to<br>negotiate programmes of measures in order to tackle the environmental<br>and accessibility problems in each region. The Government is prepared to<br>allocate SEK.5,500 million as a contribution to the financing of measures<br>agreed by these “metropolitan negotiators”. The proposal is presented in<br>the Government Bill on Industrial Policy for Growth.</p>
<p>The special environmental project groups for Göteborg, Sundsvall-<br>Timrå and western Skåne which the Government has previously initiated<br>have all described a need for determined measures in order to limit health<br>and environmental problems from traffic in these regions. The material<br>produced by the project groups is to provide the basis for work on further<br>measures in this region. A special coordinator will be appointed to go on<br>working with proposals for the Communications network in the Sundsvall-<br>Timrå region.</p>
<p>It is clear that further measures are necessary in order to tackle problems<br>associated with traffic, the environment and health, particularly in the<br>large city areas. The Government considers that the recommendation<br>concerning low-emission heavy urban vehicles which has been drawn up as<br>a guideline for purchasers of such vehicles should be followed as closely as<br>possible. The Swedish Environmental Protection Agency and the National<br>Road Safety Office should, together with the Swedish Chamber of Com-<br>merce —taking account of developments within the EC —draw up propos-<br>als concerning special requirements for diesel-driven vehicles used in<br>urban traffic in terms of extremely low levels of exhaust emissions and<br>noise. Problems caused by traffic noise in urban areas should receive<br>increased attention.</p>
<p>Accessibility for public transport and distribution traffic is to be im-<br>proved as a result of the measures now being implemented pursuant to the<br>proposals of the metropolitan negotiators.</p>
<p>The Government expects SEK40,000 million to be invested in the traffic<br>systems of the major cities during the 90s. This will include investments in<br>modern public transport systems, clean vehicles and by-passes. The pro-<br></p>
<p>Prop. 1990/91:90</p>
<p>86</p>
<p>posal is discussed in the Government Bill on Industrial Policy for Growth. Prop. 1990/91:90<br>Municipal and regional planning should take advantage of the potential<br>for improving the basis of public transport. Plans should include clear<br>impact assessments regarding traffic and the environment. The municipal-<br>ities should be given the legal means of limiting environmentally-hazard-<br>ous traffic in town and city centres.</p>
<h6>4.3.4 Vehicles and fuels</h6>
<p>The most important element in the strategy for achieving an environmen-<br>tally-adapted transport system is to consist of measures aimed at all types<br>of vehicle and fuel, for use in all types of traffic.</p>
<p>Guidelines for reducing emissions from motor vehicles were laid down<br>by virtue of the 1988 decision on environmental policy. Stricter exhaust<br>emission requirements for cars came into force as of the 1992 models. For<br>light trucks and buses, the stricter requirements are compulsory from the<br>1992 model year. The new requirements were introduced on a voluntary<br>basis, with fmancial incentives as of the 1990 models. Stricter require-<br>ments for heavy trucks and buses will apply as of the 1993 model year.</p>
<p>The fuel properties, combustion characteristics, exhaust purification,<br>rolling resistance and wind resistance of a vehicle are all parameters that<br>can be altered in order to reduce exhaust emissions. Development to date<br>shows that comparatively little has been done in terms of fuel properties.<br>Successive improvements have been made in terms of combustion tech-<br>nology, rolling resistance and air resistance. The most important improve-<br>ments during recent years, however, have been achieved by way of direct<br>purification measures such as the three-way catalytic converter.</p>
<p>In future, environmental requirements on vehicles should continue to be<br>neutral in terms of technology and competition. This means that the<br>environmental requirements should not State the technology to be used or<br>how development work should be divided between measures concentrat-<br>ing on fuel, combustion, or purification, etc. The requirements should<br>instead State acceptable emission levels. As regards fuel, however, there is<br>reason to introduce certain requirements which State the lowest acceptable<br>level of quality.</p>
<p>The development towards the increased use of unleaded petrol is one<br>positive example in this area. The Govemment does, however, see reason<br>for further measures to promote development in this respect and is there-<br>fore proposing that the tax on unleaded petrol be reduced, and the tax on<br>other petrols be raised. The use of more environmentally sound diesel fuels<br>can lead to a significant reduction in hazardous emissions. The Govern-<br>ment is therefore proposing that the environmental classes for diesel fuel<br>be changed so that the grades of diesel fuel in Classes 1 and 2 are cleaner.<br>In addition to this, the maximum permitted sulphur content of diesel fuel<br>should be reduced in cooperation with the EC.</p>
<p>Environmental benefits can also be achieved if traditional fuels —mainly<br>petrol and diesel —are replaced by alternative fuels such as motor alcohol,<br>gas and electricity. In order to promote the development of alternative<br></p>
<p>87</p>
<p>fuels, the Govemment will be proposing, in the Bill on Energy Policy, that Prop. 1990/91:90<br>SEK30 million be allocated per year for four years to support pilot projects<br>concerning the testing and development of motor alcohols.</p>
<p>As a result of voluntary agreements, several ferry companies have begun<br>to use more environmentally sound low-sulphur bunker oil. In general,<br>however, the fuel used by shipping contains large quantities of sulphur and<br>other pollutants. This causes technical problems in combustion and leads<br>to major emissions of pollutants to the air. Through the Intemational<br>Maritime Organization, IMO, Sweden is therefore working to prohibit<br>additives of Chemical substances which are harmful to the environment.<br>The Governmenfs ambition is to introduce limits, in broad cooperation<br>with the other Nordic countries, on the maximum sulphur content of fuels<br>used by ferries and other vessels which frequent Swedish ports, mainly<br>Swedish ferry traffic. Bilateral agreements could be reached as a first step<br>with the objective that all Nordic ferry traffic should be included in the<br>agreement on maximum sulphur content at a later date. Emissions of<br>nitrogen oxides from shipping should also be reduced. Measures should be<br>proposed by the relevant authorities during 1991.</p>
<p>As regards the emission of nitrogen oxides, hydrocarbons and carbon<br>monoxide from vehicles, existing technology is able to fulfil today’s emis-<br>sion requirements. This is clear from tests of existing vehicles, and from<br>the fact that in other parts of the world — particularly in California —<br>stricter regulations are in force with respect to emissions from vehicles.</p>
<p>The Governmenfs ambition is, together with other countries in Western<br>Europé, to introduce stricter exhaust emission requirements for cars, light<br>trucks and buses as soon as possible, and from 1996 at the latest, to meet<br>the levels introduced by the federal authorities in the USA as of the 1994<br>model year. The environmental impact will be greatest if such require-<br>ments are introduced earlier and in coordination with other countries in<br>Western Europé. The Govemment therefore intends to work actively<br>within the framework of the EEA process towards stricter limits in EFTA<br>and the EC as soon as possible, and not later than 1996.</p>
<p>The Governmenfs ambition is, together with other West European<br>nations, to make requirements concerning exhaust emissions and noise<br>from heavy vehicles stricter as of 1996, so that they correspond roughly to<br>the federal requirements in the USA for the 1994 models. The Govern-<br>ment feels that there is good potential for achieving this in coordination<br>with EFTA and the EC.</p>
<p>In order to hasten the introduction of more environmentally-adapted<br>vehicles, the Government will be proposing that a new system of environ-<br>mental classification be introduced for new vehicles as of the 1993 models.<br>A system of this sort will promote the introduction of vehicles with good<br>environmental properties.</p>
<p>In aviation, certain improvements have taken place in combustion<br>technology as a result of the environmental charges that were introduced in<br>conjunction with the 1988 decision on traffic policy. The development of<br>aircraft engines has not yet progressed to the point that emission require-<br>ments can be imposed for the early 1990s. However, the aviation industry<br></p>
<p>88</p>
<p>is currently engaged in interesting development work and it is likely that<br>technology will be available by the end of the 90s to permit considerable<br>reductions in emissions, particularly of nitrogen oxides. Sweden is calling<br>for stricter emission requirements for aircraft not later than the end of the<br>90s.</p>
<p>Emission requirements for diesel-driven locomotives are being drawn<br>up in conjunction with the development of new light rail motor coaches,<br>particularly for passenger traffic. The Governmenfs ambition is to intro-<br>duce these requirements jointly with other European countries.</p>
<p>To date, no limits have been set for emissions from utility and off-road<br>vehicles, which have been found to make a relatively high contribution to<br>emissions of nitrogen oxides, among other things. Together with the other<br>authorities concemed, the Swedish Environmental Protection Agency is<br>therefore to draw up proposals concerning exhaust emission requirements<br>for these vehicles. The Government intends to work towards the introduc-<br>tion of coordinated requirements for tractors and construction site ma-<br>chinery whithin EFTA and the EC from 1995. An environmental classifi-<br>cation should also be introduced for this type of vehicle.</p>
<p>The ambition of limiting emissions of carbon dioxide also requires<br>measures in the transport sector, which is responsible for over one-third of<br>emissions. It is for the Swedish Environmental Protection Agency, in<br>cooperation with the Swedish Chamber of Commerce, the National Board<br>for Consumer Policies and the other authorities concerned, to look into<br>the possibilities of introducing limits on carbon dioxide emissions from<br>road vehicles, taking into account developments in the EC.</p>
<h6>4.3.5 Infrastructure</h6>
<p>All types of transport and traffic system are associated with emissions of<br>air pollutants and other environmental damage. This takes place in the<br>form of environmental impact in the construction, operation and mainten-<br>ance of traffic systems, as well as through the fact that they affect the flow<br>of traffic and the distribution of transport among different types of traffic.</p>
<p>The rail system is to be extended in order to provide a competitive<br>alternative both for passenger and for freight traffic. The road system must<br>also be successively modified from the environmental point of view. The<br>Government has already proposed to the Riksdag that allocations for<br>investments in rail traffic be increased beyond the national budget during<br>the coming ten-year period from SEK 10,000 million to SEK 15,000 mil-<br>lion. It is proposed that a special infrastructure fund be set up, and that a<br>total of SEK20,000 million be put into this fund during the 1990s. It is to<br>be used for joint financing of railways, roads and public transport systems.<br>The Government expects that SEK30,000 million will be invested in<br>railways during the 1990s.</p>
<p>In the planning of new rail systems, as in extensive rebuilding of such<br>systems, environmental impact assessments are to be carried out. Environ-<br>mental impact assessments are to be introduced at the planning stage of<br></p>
<p>Prop. 1990/91:90</p>
<p>89</p>
<p>road projects. The Board of Civil Aviation should draw up plans for Prop. 1990/91:90<br>environmental measures at the major airports under its responsibility.</p>
<h5>4.4 The energy supply</h5>
<p>Summary:</p>
<p>The environmental goal is to have an energy system without nu-<br>clear power, while sharply reducing the contribution of the sector<br>to acidification and climate change without developing the unex-<br>ploited rivers.</p>
<p>The impact on the environment of the production of electricity<br>and heat has decreased considerably since the mid-70s as a result of<br>successively stricter emission requirements. The economic instru-<br>ments which have already been adopted will reduce emissions fur-<br>ther.</p>
<p>Limits for emissions of sulphur will become stricter as of the<br>beginning of 1993 in the large cities and in southem Sweden.</p>
<p>The guidelines for emissions of sulphur and nitrogen oxides from<br>large new combustion plants are to be made much stricter.</p>
<h6>4.4.1 Introduction</h6>
<p>Significant steps have been taken towards an environmentally-adapted<br>energy system. The environmental effects of the production of electricity<br>and heat in Sweden declined considerably during the 70s and 80s. Emis-<br>sions of sulphur from this sector have declined by approximately 70% and<br>nitrogen oxide emissions by approximately 35% since 1980. Carbon diox-<br>ide emissions have declined by approximately 35% during the same peri-<br>od. The sector has contributed to an improvement of the air in our urban<br>areas, less acidification and reduced effect on the global climate.</p>
<p>Further action is required, however, in order to reduce the environmen-<br>tal effects of the production of energy and heat. None of the main methods<br>of energy supply at a global level —fossil fuels, nuclear energy or the<br>burning of wood in developing countries —are sustainable in the long term.<br>A change in the world’s energy systems will require far-reaching measures<br>and the industrialized countries must be at the forefront. The future<br>conversion and environmental adaptation of the Swedish energy system<br>should be seen in this light. The environmental goal is to achieve an energy<br>system without nuclear power, while sharply reducing the contribution of<br>the sector to acidification and climatic change and without developing the<br>unexploited rivers. This would take time and will demand intemational<br>cooperation.</p>
<p>The Govemment has already (see 2.1.2) presented a Consolidated strate-<br>gy aimed at reducing effects on the climate. The way in which electricity<br>and heat are produced will play a major part in securing the success of this<br>stragety. The Government intends to introduce guidelines for energy poli-<br></p>
<p>90</p>
<p>cy in the near future. In the following pages, the Government presents its Prop. 1990/91:90<br>view on stricter emission requirement, measures against emissions from<br>small boilers and the siting of wind power.</p>
<h6>4.4.2 The environmental impact of electricity and heat production</h6>
<p>The quality of air in the urban areas has been improved through the<br>expansion of district heating networks and through the transfer to low-<br>sulphur fuel and more efficient combustion plants. In Stockholm, levels of<br>sulphur dioxide have declined by about 80% since 1970. The levels of soot<br>in Göteborg and Stockholm have been halved during the same period.<br>Combustion in boilers in private houses, particularly older wood-fired<br>boilers without modern combustion technology, can contribute locally to<br>emissions of hazardous pollutants, however. The burning of unsuitable<br>materials such as impregnated timber can cause emissions of extremely<br>carcinogenic substances.</p>
<p>Emissions of sulphur will decline further as a result of stricter require-<br>ments and the sulphur tax. The sulphur tax, which was introduced on<br>January 1 of this year, is alone expected to lead to reductions of emissions<br>in this sector by a further 10,000 — 25,000 tonnes of sulphur by the year<br>2000, compared with what they otherwise would have been.</p>
<p>Nitrogen oxides from this sector have also declined. The nitrogen oxide<br>charge which is to be introduced on January 1, 1992 is expected to reduce<br>emissions by a further 3,000 — 5,000 tonnes per year.</p>
<p>Emissions of carbon dioxide from the generation of electricity and heat<br>have declined by over a third since 1980 and by almost 60% since 1970.<br>The main reasons for this are improved energy efficiency, increased use of<br>renewable fuels and the use of electricity based on hydro-electric and<br>nuclear power in order to replace fossil fuels in the generation of heat. The<br>carbon dioxide tax introduced at the tum of the year is expected to be of<br>great significance in limiting the emission of carbon dioxide from heat<br>production.</p>
<h6>4.4.3 Measures to reduce environmental impact</h6>
<p>In the Bill on Energy Policy, the Government is presenting proposals<br>concerning the future strategy for energy. The Government has previously<br>stated its intention to change the Ordinance on Fuels Containing Sulphur<br>so that the emission limits are made stricter, starting in 1993 with Southern<br>Sweden and the counties in which Sweden’s three major cities are situated.<br>The change is to have been implemented throughout Sweden not later than<br>1997. This means that the date has been brought forward by two years. The<br>new requirements mean that the annual average emissions of sulphur from<br>large plants will be 50 mg sulphur/MJ of input fuel and 100 mg sulphur/MJ<br>input fuel for smaller plants. The emission limits are to be applied as an<br>average for all the combustion plants in a district heating network or<br>power station or for several boiler units in an industry.</p>
<p>Consideration of permit applications pursuant to the Natural Resources<br></p>
<p>91</p>
<p>Act and the Environment Protection Act has shown in recent years that Prop. 1990/91:90<br>emissions of sulphur from major new combustion plants can be reduced<br>further. As a guideline for consideration of permit applications pursuant to<br>the Environment Protection Act, it is now being stated that emissions<br>from new combustion plants with a power input of over 500 MW may not<br>exceed 30 mg/MJ of fuel, as an annual average.</p>
<p>The emission of nitrogen oxides from new combustion plants with an<br>input exceeding 500MW should not exceed 30 mg/MJ input fuel, calculat-<br>ed as an annual average.</p>
<p>Requirements concerning emissions of sulphur and nitrogen oxides are<br>to be based on the best available technology. Taking technological develop-<br>ment into account, this may mean that in certain cases the requirements<br>are set lower than the guidelines stated above.</p>
<p>Noise from energy generation plants is not to exceed the levels stated in<br>the Swedish Environmental Protection Agency’s external industrial noise<br>guidelines for new industrial facilities.</p>
<p>Residual products that must be disposed of as a result of the burning of<br>oil and solid fuels are to be limited. Residual products that cannot be<br>utilized are to be deposited in such a way that the leaching of pollutants is<br>minimized. Ash from the combustion of bio-fuels should be handled in an<br>ecologically sound manner.</p>
<p>Continued work on reducing the environmental impact of electricity<br>and heat generation, in addition to the measures presented by the Govern-<br>ment today, is primarily to be aimed at limiting climatic impact and<br>reducing emissions from small boilers. It is important to study the possi-<br>bilities of reducing emissions from boilers in private homes. This includes<br>analysing the possibilities of introducing eco-labelling, considering sys-<br>tems of compulsory certification, systems of emission declarations and<br>measures leading to better operation and maintenance. This work falls<br>within the sphere of responsibility of the Swedish Environmental Protec-<br>tion Agency, after consultation with the authorities concerned.</p>
<p>It is important to utilize the good potential for wind power that exists in<br>our country. More detailed possibilities for large-scale wind power should<br>be taken into account in the physical planning of the municipalities.</p>
<p>92</p>
<h5>4.5 Industry, etc.,</h5>
<p>Summary:</p>
<p>A programme for a review of the conditions for discharges by<br>environmentally damaging activities is being implemented in con-<br>junction with the renewal of permits pursuant to the Environment<br>Protection Act. The objective is to limit discharges from industry by<br>the year 2000 to such a level that no harm is done to the environ-<br>ment.</p>
<p>The pulp and paper industry is being given priority in the review<br>plan. Emissions of chlorinated organic substances are to be further<br>limited, in order to reach a level at which the environment is not<br>noticeably affected by the end of the century.</p>
<p>Emissions of sulphur and nitrogen oxides from industry are also<br>being limited.</p>
<p>At municipal treatment plants on the coast, a nitrogen reduction<br>of at least 50% is to be introduced.</p>
<p>The Government is proposing a change to the Environment Pro-<br>tection Act to make it quite clear that the operator of environmen-<br>tally hazardous activities is obliged to produce the material required<br>when reconsidering permit conditions.</p>
<h6>4.5.1 Introduction</h6>
<p>Swedish industry constitutes the foundation of the nation’s material wel-<br>fare. Because of dependence upon exports, Swedish industry must take the<br>intemational market into account to a high degree. Improved environmen-<br>tal properties in a product can represent a competitive advantage today,<br>but this has not always been the case.</p>
<p>In the long term, no area of Swedish trade and industry will remain<br>unaffected by the increased environmental requirements. The structural<br>change that took place during the 70s and 80s was accompanied by high<br>environmental ambitions. Extensive changes that can affect current pro-<br>duction and employment are also expected in the future. At the same time,<br>much new business potential will arise. Production that is tenable in the<br>long term will also prove to be an advantage in business terms.</p>
<p>Industrial production in Sweden still leads to extensive disruption of the<br>ecological system. Even so, extensive and successful environmental work<br>has meant that emissions of pollutants from the main point sources —<br>industry, combustion plants and sewage treatment plants —have declined<br>sharply. The reasons for this are to be found in the Environment Protec-<br>tion Act of 1969 and the environmental demands that could subsequently<br>be made with the help of the Act, partly in the form of a structural change<br>in which older plants were closed. The work within companies on improv-<br>ing processes and converting to processes that use less energy and re-<br>sources has been of major significance to improvements in the environ-<br>ment. In many industries, it has been possible to increase production at<br></p>
<p>Prop. 1990/91:90</p>
<p>93</p>
<p>the same time as reducing discharges and the consumption of raw materi- Prop. 1990/91:90<br>als. One example of this is that it has been possible to increase the<br>production of bieached pulp while drastically reducing the amount of<br>chlorine used in the bleaching process.</p>
<p>The work of limiting emissions from Swedish Processing industry must<br>continue in order to bring them down to levels which do not give rise to<br>noticeable effects on health and the environment. This means that a<br>programme for the review of current discharge conditions is to be started.<br>The environmental effects of the use of goods and the generation of waste<br>must also be limited to a level that is compatible with long-term sustain-<br>able development. This means that environmental consequences are al-<br>ready to be taken into account in the development of production and that<br>the environmental impact of the entire life cycle of a product is to be<br>considered from the very beginning.</p>
<h6>4.5.2 Environmental protection work</h6>
<p>The quality and ambitions of environmental work vary considerably be-<br>tween different branches of industry and different plants. Many companies<br>are working actively on the training of personnel and on technical develop-<br>ment in order to reduce discharges and avoid infringement of their permit<br>conditions. Other companies do not have the same degree of foresight and<br>lack knowledge of the environmental consequences of their production.</p>
<p>The provisions of the Environment Protection Act with respect to indi-<br>vidual permit consideration can in certain cases mean that similar envi-<br>ronmentally harmful operations have different permit conditions in terms<br>of protective measures. Such differences may depend upon when the<br>operations came under consideration. Competent and fair consideration<br>by the authorities is an important part of work to achieve future environ-<br>mental goals. In addition to this, a control programme is required for the<br>operations in question. This must be designed in such a way as to provide<br>support both for the company and for the supervisory authority.</p>
<p>A company applying for permission to pursue environmentally hazard-<br>ous operations is obliged to submit the study required for the permit<br>application to be considered. The Environment Protection Act lacks ex-<br>press provisions, however, as to who is required to carry out the study<br>when permit conditions are to be reviewed. The Govemment considers<br>that the Environment Protection Act should be supplemented to make it<br>quite clear that it is also the operator who is required to perform the study<br>when permit conditions are under review. This will improve the position<br>of the Swedish Environmental Protection Agency and the County Admin-<br>istrative Boards when handling such reviews.</p>
<p>The Government is giving the Swedish Environmental Protection Agen-<br>cy the task of drawing up a ten-year programme for an overhaul of the<br>conditions for industrial discharges through reviews of existing permits.<br>The purpose is to systematically introduce permit conditions in order to<br>meet national and intemational environmental goals and to eliminate<br>regional environmental problems. When reviewing the conditions for a &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;94</p>
<p>given branch of industry, priority should be given to plants with high levels Prop. 1990/91:90<br>of discharges, particularly those where clear environmental goals exist, as<br>well as to sensitive receiving waters. The regional environmental analyses<br>of the County Administrative Boards may be used when drawing up<br>priorities concerning needs and measures. In addition to industries, the<br>programme should also include other important point sources such as<br>power plants and municipal waste water treatment plants.</p>
<p>Any operator of environmentally harmful activities who possesses a<br>permit pursuant to the Environment Protection Act is obliged to provide<br>an annual environmental report to the supervisory authority. It is up to the<br>operator to ensure that the report is complete and correct. It should thus be<br>possible to use the reports as documentation when determining permit<br>review priorities.</p>
<p>In the on-going follow-up work, it is important that companies and<br>authorities both work as efficiently as possible in order to maintain dis-<br>charges at a low level in the future.
