This requires well-developed internal<br>Controls at the operations concemed, in combination with effective exter-<br>nal Controls on the part of the authorities. The work that has been started<br>on internal environmental audits in industry is one step in the right<br>direction.</p>
<h6>4.5.3 Limitation ofdischarges</h6>
<p>The main source of persistent organic pollution consists of discharges of<br>chlorinated organic substances from the pulp and paper industry. The<br>guidelines for reducing these discharges were stated in the 1988 Govem-<br>ment Bill on Environmental Policy. As a result of the measures now being<br>implemented, discharges will be limited by 60 — 70% from the 1985 levels.<br>Discharges will then amount to 1.5 — 2 kg of organically bound chlorine per<br>tonne of bieached sulphate pulp.</p>
<p>With the Processing and treatment technology available today, the dis-<br>charges can be further reduced to 0.5— 1 kg of organically bound chlorine<br>per tonne of pulp. The pulp and paper industries should therefore be given<br>priority in the review plan drawn up by the Swedish Environmental<br>Protection Agency. In the review, the conditions imposed should take the<br>best available technology into account. In individual reviews, considera-<br>tion must also be taken of the production of the individual company and<br>the possibilities of reducing discharges.</p>
<p>In conjunction with the review of pulp and paper plants, other dis-<br>charges of environmentally hazardous substances from the manufacture of<br>both bieached and unbleached pulp are also to be dealt with. The goal is<br>that discharges from the pulp and paper industry should be reduced by the<br>beginning of the next century to such a level that the environment is not<br>noticeably affected. The implication of this in terms of the extent of<br>discharges must be clarified through continued research and environmen-<br>tal monitoring.</p>
<p>Discharges of persistent organic substances should also be limited from<br>other branches of industry. The Swedish Environmental Protection Agen- &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;95<br></p>
<p>cy and the Chemicals Inspectorate should continue their work on identify- Prop. 1990/91: 90<br>ing new sources and initiating measures against discharges from such<br>sources.</p>
<p>Industrial emissions of volatile organic compounds primarily come<br>from refmeries, the organic Chemical industry and surface treatment<br>plants. In these cases, a reduction of emissions has only started during<br>recent years. Discharges from Processing industries are being limited<br>through the use of equipment which is better sealed, together with better<br>monitoring in terms of identifying leakage and emissions to the surround-<br>ing area. Emissions of solvents, etc., are also to be limited, primarily by<br>way of a transfer to solvent-free processes where possible. Otherwise,<br>emissions are to be limited through the installation of recycling or purifica-<br>tion equipment.</p>
<p>Disused mine waste deposition sites are the major source of discharges<br>of a number of metals into water. There are also considerable discharges<br>from current mining operations and from certain industries which release<br>metals. Diffuse discharges from landfills are another source which may<br>increase in significance.</p>
<p>Discharges of metals have declined sharply since the early 70s. In order<br>to attain the goals in this respect, further measures must be taken to limit<br>emissions, primarily to the air. A number of measures have already been<br>taken, and through the on-going work on supervision and issuing of per-<br>mits it should be possible to halve discharges of the most important metals<br>during the 1985—1995 period.</p>
<p>As one of several measures to minimize the discharge of mercury,<br>measures are to be taken at the chloralkali plants that use mercury cells.<br>Mercury-free technology is available and is already applied by two plants.<br>The 1988 Government Bill on Environmental Policy already stated that<br>mercury-free technology should be introduced in the long term. The Gov-<br>ernment now considers that a plan should be laid down for the introduc-<br>tion of mercury-free technology at all plants. Mercury discharges from<br>other sources, such as iron, Steel and metalworks, are to be reduced by the<br>imposition of conditions when considering permit applications pursuant<br>to the Environment Protection Act. A plan for phasing out mercury is<br>presented below. The Government considers that these measures taken<br>together will lead to a reduction of mercury discharges by 70% between<br>1985 and 1995.</p>
<p>Industrial processes are responsible for a large part of the Swedish<br>emissions of acidifying substances, although total emissions have declined<br>sharply during recent years. About 40% of the emissions of sulphur come<br>from industry. This proportion will increase when the sulphur tax that has<br>been adopted leads to a reduction of emissions from other sectors.</p>
<p>The emission of sulphur and nitrogen oxides from industrial processes<br>must be reduced further in order to meet the environmental goals that the<br>Riksdag has formulated. The guidelines for consideration of permit appli-<br>cations are that measures are to be taken amounting to a cost of at least<br>SEK30/kg of sulphur and SEK40/kg of nitrogen oxides. This will impose<br>the same demands on industrial processes as on other sectors of society.</p>
<p>96</p>
<p>Discharges of nutrients should be limited from certain industries and<br>particularly from municipal treatment plants. Many of the municipal<br>treatment plants have both biological and Chemical purification today.<br>However, most of them still lack satisfactory nitrogen treatment. The<br>Govemment considers, as a guideline when considering permits pursuant<br>to the Environment Protection Act, that the limit should be reduced by at<br>least 50% for the major treatment plants. Initially, measures should be<br>directed at the treatment plants that are located on or near the coast in the<br>most affected sea areas. This includes the entire south and west coast of<br>Sweden and the Baltic coast up to and including the Stockholm archipela-<br>go. In certain severely affected areas, such as the bays of Laholm, Skälder-<br>viken and Hanö, and Öresund, a higher degree of purification is required.</p>
<p>Many municipalities have old and out of date sewage systems. The result<br>is that large quantities of groundwater leak into the systems and cause<br>overflows and other disruptions in the treatment processes. In many cases,<br>waste water can also leak out and pollute groundwater. All this means that<br>sewage systems in many of the country’s municipalities must be modern-<br>ized or replaced as soon as possible. This investment responsibility rests<br>with the municipalities.</p>
<p>The content of metals in the residual sludge from municipal treatment<br>plants has declined during recent years. Levels of metals and persisent<br>organic compounds can, however, still be so high that the sludge can only<br>be used as a fertilizer under certain conditions. As a result of the measures<br>that are currently being taken, it should once again be possible to spread<br>the sludge more generally not later than 1995.</p>
<p>Emissions of nitrogen and phosphorus from individual sewage plants<br>and small treatment plants in spacely populated areas also require atten-<br>tion. An information campaign to persuade people to transfer to phos-<br>phate-free detergents would contribute to reducing the discharges of phos-<br>phorus.</p>
<p>7 Riksdagen 1990/91. 1 saml. Nr 90. Main proposals</p>
<p>Prop. 1990/91:90</p>
<p>97</p>
<h5>4.6 Goods and Chemical products</h5>
<p>Summary:</p>
<p>Environmental awareness must permeate the design of all the goods<br>and products we use in society.</p>
<p>Chemical monitoring efforts are increasing in order to reduce the<br>supply and use of substances and products that are hazardous to<br>health and the environment. Regulations for the prior notification<br>of new Chemical products are being introduced and the product<br>register of the Chemicals Inspectorate is to be expanded. The<br>authorization of the Chemicals Inspectorate and the Swedish Envi-<br>ronmental Protection Agency to prohibit the import and handling of<br>hazardous Chemical substances and products will be increased.</p>
<p>The Government proposes that a new law be introduced requiring<br>the prior inspection of biological pesticides.</p>
<p>Plans to phase out ozone-depleting substances are being brought<br>forward and extended in scope. The Govemment is proposing that<br>the Riksdag approve the annex to the Montreal Protocol on ozone-<br>depleting substances.</p>
<p>New phase-out plans are being approved for chlorinated solvents,<br>mercury and lead. The use of cadmium is to be further restricted.</p>
<p>Intemational cooperation is to be sought, particularly within<br>Western Europé.</p>
<p>Incentives are to be introduced for the return of used nickel-<br>cadmium batteries. The Government intends to raise the environ-<br>mental charge for nickel-cadmium batteries.</p>
<h6>4.6.1 Introduction</h6>
<p>The production of goods always entails the utilization of natural resources.<br>Effects on the environment may arise in the extraction of raw materials,<br>the transport of input goods and goods at the production stage, during<br>consumption and, later, when the product becomes waste after its use. An<br>extremely large number of substances and Chemicals are used in different<br>products. A number of these substances may cause damage if their spread<br>in the environment is uncontrolled.</p>
<p>As has been stated previously, it is therefore becoming increasingly<br>important to impose stricter requirements on different goods and Chemical<br>products in order to attain the environmental goals that have been laid<br>down. By designing products in an environmentally sound manner, envi-<br>ronmental problems can be reduced in all sectors of society. Vehicles with<br>fewer and cleaner exhaust emissions would reduce pollution from the<br>transport sector. By removing asphalt from brake linings and mercury<br>from Circuit breakers, etc., emissions can be avoided during production<br>and when the cars are scrapped. Less dangerous pesticides and fertilizers<br>with lower levels of cadmium will limit the effect of agriculture on the<br>environment. By replacing hazardous substances in detergents, paints and<br></p>
<p>Prop. 1990/91:90</p>
<p>98</p>
<p>glues, professional users and consumers can be spared health risks (aller- Prop. 1990/91:90<br>gies, nerve damage) when using them, and the diffuse discharges of hazard-<br>ous substances into the environment via sewage systems and landfills can<br>be reduced. At the same time, the working environment can be improved<br>for those who manufacture these products and for those who use them in<br>the industrial manufacture of other goods.</p>
<p>The Govemment considers that a strategy should be developed for the<br>environmentally-adapted production of goods, i.e. production in which<br>environmental awareness and impact are taken into consideration at all<br>phases of the life-cycle of the product, from raw material to waste and<br>recycling. A working group under the Ministry of the Environment will<br>draw up such a strategy. As regards measures to tackle the problem of<br>building materials containing volatile substances, the Government intends<br>to present a Bill to the Riksdag later this year. This will deal with various<br>measures to improve the indoor environment.</p>
<p>It is particularly urgent to limit the use of Chemical substances which are<br>hazardous to health and the environment. The annual input of environ-<br>mentally hazardous substances in goods and stationary facilities far ex-<br>ceeds the current emissions into the environment. This implies an increas-<br>ing accumulation of environmentally hazardous substances which sooner<br>or later risk being leaked into the environment via landfills. This repre-<br>sents a major threat to the environment in the future.</p>
<p>Efforts are required on the part of a large number of actors in order to<br>ensure successful environmental adaptation in the production of goods. By<br>including the substitution principle in the Act on Chemical Products,<br>whoever handles or imports a Chemical product has a fundamental respon-<br>sibility for replacing hazardous substances and products by less dangerous<br>ones.</p>
<p>Consumers and professional users must be aware and well informed in<br>their choice and handling of products and Chemicals. Like well-developed<br>monitoring of Chemicals, this represents an important factor in ensuring<br>that the responsibility for replacing hazardous substances and products<br>really is laid at the door of producers and suppliers in practice.</p>
<p>The system of eco-labelling is one step towards improving the consum-<br>er’s ability to exert an influence. Eco-labelling is being coordinated be-<br>tween the Nordic countries with the purpose of stimulating the sale of<br>more environmentally sound products, indicated by a label showing a<br>swan.</p>
<p>Better training, particularly by professional users, and further develop-<br>ment of the requirements concerning compulsory classification and label-<br>ling of products which are hazardous to health and the environment are<br>other ways of improving the possibilities of the consumer and the profes-<br>sional user to influence product development.</p>
<p>One important step is the introduction of compulsory environmental<br>hazard warning labels on Chemical products. Classification, labelling and<br>registration of Chemicals have hitherto mainly concerned dangers to<br>health. Criteria for dangers to the environment have also been drawn up in<br>Nordic cooperation. The EC has laid down criteria which in principle<br></p>
<p>99</p>
<p>accord with those of the Nordic countries. In the Nordic Area, moreover, a<br>system of classification, labelling and product information sheets for envi-<br>ronmentally hazardous Chemical substances and products has been drawn<br>up on the basis of the new criteria for environmental hazards. Discussions<br>with the EC are under way in order to harmonize these requirements.</p>
<h6>4.6.2 The monitoring of Chemicals</h6>
<p>The monitoring of Chemicals is to be improved through the expansion of<br>the Chemicals Inspectorate. Prior notification and good documentation<br>will be required for new Chemical substances, and the product register is to<br>be expanded. Better inspection of and information on Chemical substances<br>and products constitutes the basis for improved monitoring of Chemicals,<br>which in turn is a prerequisite for preventive measures against environ-<br>mental problems, by limiting or phasing out substances and products that<br>are environmentally hazardous.</p>
<p>Prior notification implies that manufacturers and importers must report<br>new Chemical substances before such substances are marketed in Sweden.<br>The notification should be followed by documentation of the effects of the<br>substance on health and the environment. This is basically the same as the<br>system which is already in existence in the EC. The Govemment is<br>authorizing the Chemicals Inspectorate to work out the application regula-<br>tions required for the introduction of the system.</p>
<p>The Chemicals Inspectorate’s product register is to be expanded, and<br>will require special information about environmentally hazardous sub-<br>stances, better information about carcinogens and allergens and informa-<br>tion on all the main components of a product.</p>
<p>In various intemational contexts, Sweden has called for better and more<br>reliable analyses, information and documentation concerning Chemicals.<br>Sweden has also worked towards the limitation of hazardous substances.<br>Considerable progress has been made within the framework of the OECD’s<br>work on Chemicals. By the end of 1993, information is to have been made<br>available on the properties of a total of 147 substances and their impact on<br>health and the environment. The well-organized allocation of work be-<br>tween countries will make it possible to produce comprehensive documen-<br>tation in a relatively short time and, at the same time, promote agreement<br>on the assessment of the danger of the substances to health and the<br>environment. This is of major significance in deciding if and when protec-<br>tive measures are to be taken.</p>
<p>Chemical pesticides have been regulated for some time through a system<br>of prior inspection and approval. The Government is now proposing that<br>biological pesticides be inspected in the same way. A new law is proposed<br>which is to be applicable to biological pesticides. Approval will be required<br>from the point of view of health and the environment before a biological<br>pesticide can be sold and used. This approval will be obtained through<br>prior inspection by the Chemicals Inspectorate. The Inspectorate is<br>authorized to issue the regulations and precautions required for the pro-<br>duction and use of biological pesticides.</p>
<p>Prop. 1990/91:90</p>
<p>100</p>
<p>It is also proposed that other aspects of biological pesticides be handled Prop. 1990/91: 90<br>by the same authorities as handle the Chemical agents. It is proposed that<br>the cost of prior inspection of biological pesticides be covered through<br>charges according to the same principles as apply to Chemical pesticides.</p>
<h6>4.6.3 Phase-out plans</h6>
<p>Work on phasing out the substances which are most dangerous to health<br>and the environment is entering an increasingly intensive stage.</p>
<p>The use of ozone-depleting substances must cease. Global phase-out<br>plans for such substances have been drawn up in the form of the Montreal<br>Protocol. Over 60 States have signed the protocol, which lays down mini-<br>mum phase-out requirements and also encourages individual countries to<br>make faster progress.</p>
<p>In the environmental decision of 1988, Sweden was the first country to<br>reach a decision on the complete phasing out of CFCs. This stimulated the<br>development of alternative technologies, which has facilitated internation-<br>al work. The Government is now proposing that the phasing-out plan for<br>CFCs be extended in scope and that the use of all ozone-depleting sub-<br>stances be discontinued or sharply limited.</p>
<p>The Government will be introducing a system for recovering discarded<br>refrigerators and freezers which contain CFCs. The municipalities will be<br>made responsible for disposing of the CFCs they contain. The increased<br>costs are to be financed with the help of the sanitation charge.</p>
<p>The Government intends to introduce a ban on halons in portable fire<br>extinguishers and in fixed installations from 1 July 1991. Sweden has<br>notified GATT and EFTA of this measure. Use of halon gases in existing<br>installations in trade and industry should be phased out not later than<br>1998. Recovery and destruction of halon gases is also being introduced.</p>
<p>Chlorinated solvents have extremely good solvent properties and are not<br>flammable. These properties, combined with extreme volatility, are the<br>reason for the extensive use of the substances during recent decades. The<br>most important areas of application are for de-greasing and the removal of<br>paints in the engineering industry, for cleaning in the electronics industry<br>and in the pharmaceutical and Chemical industries, for the removal of<br>graffiti and for dry cleaning.</p>
<p>Chlorinated solvents are carcinogens and affect the central nervous<br>system. It is also suspected that they cause direct damage to vegetation.<br>Certain of the fractions into which these solvents decompose are persistent<br>and are stored in organisms.</p>
<p>The Government is therefore of the opinion that chlorinated solvents<br>should be phased out. As a first step, the sale of consumer products<br>containing chlorinated solvents which are hazardous to health and to the<br>environment is to be prohibited as of 1 January 1993. The use of these<br>solvents is to cease entirely by 1995 with certain exceptions.</p>
<p>The use of certain hazardous additives in plastics, including chlorinated<br>paraffins, flameproofing agents containing bromine, phtalic compounds<br>and organutin compounds, is to be limited sharply. The goal is that the use &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;101</p>
<p>8 Riksdagen 1990/91. 1 saml. Nr 90. Main proposals<br></p>
<p>of additives that have a negative effect on health and the environment is to Prop. 1990/91:90<br>be discontinued. The Chemicals Inspectorate and the Swedish Environ-<br>mental Protection Agency are to draw up a joint proposal concerning<br>limitations. Work is to concentrate on rapid phasing out of the substances<br>in the groups that are most harmful to the environment. Use of nonyl-<br>phenol epoxides should also be phased out.</p>
<p>There is good reason to view the heavy metals mercury, cadmium and<br>lead particularly seriously. The Govemment is now to approve the phase-<br>out plan for mercury proposed by the Swedish Environmental Protection<br>Agency and the Chemicals Inspectorate. By 1995, 25% of current use is to<br>have been phased out, and 75% by the year 2010. The objective is that use<br>is to cease entirely. A number of measures are to be implemented. Since 1<br>February 1990, the sale of batteries with a mercury and cadmium content<br>exceeding 0.025 per cent by weight has been prohibited. Medical ther-<br>mometers containing mercury should be prohibited from 1992. Other<br>thermometers containing mercury, together with Circuit breakers, medical<br>instruments and industrial measuring equipment should be prohibited<br>from 1993. Mercury in fluorescent lamps and other lamps is to be phased<br>out successively. The use of mercury in laboratories is to be restricted<br>through the dissemination of information. The discharge of mercury from<br>point sources is to be reduced sharply, through the imposition of new<br>conditions when permits are reviewed pursuant to the Environment Pro-<br>tection Act. The National Swedish Board of Health and Welfare is to be<br>given the task of investigating the possibility of phasing out amalgam in<br>dental care.</p>
<p>The use of lead should also be discontinued in the long term. As has been<br>stated above, a greater tax differentiation is to be introduced between<br>leaded and unleaded petrol. All laying of lead-sheathed underground ca-<br>bles is to have ceased by 1995. The transfer from lead shot to more<br>environmentally sound shot for hunting is to be achieved through informa-<br>tion campaigns and voluntary undertakings early next century. Authorities<br>are to implement measures for the reduced use of lead in, among other<br>things, different consumer products.</p>
<p>The Riksdag has recently approved the Governmenfs proposal concem-<br>ing a programme of measures to deal with batteries containing lead.<br>According to this programme, alternative types and alternative starting<br>systems should be developed to replace lead batteries. The recovery of lead<br>batteries is to be made permanent and nationwide information campaigns<br>are to be carried out. The programme is to be financed by a charge to be<br>paid by manufacturers and importers of lead batteries.</p>
<p>The use of arsenic and chrome compounds in wood impregnating agents<br>must be reduced sharply. If the regulations issued by the Chemicals Inspec-<br>torate with respect to wood impregnating agents do not lead to a sufficient<br>reduction, the Government will consider whether to introduce an environ-<br>mental tax in order to reduce the use of these substances.</p>
<p>The use of cadmium is also to cease. Sweden has previously introduced<br>restrictions on major areas of application. The main areas of application<br>are now in batteries. Cadmium also occurs as a contaminant in fertilizers<br></p>
<p>102</p>
<p>containing phosphates. As has previously been mentioned, the possibilites Prop. 1990/91:90<br>of limiting the cadmium content in artifical feritlizers is to be looked into.</p>
<p>The cadmium content of fertilizers used in Sweden is to be sharply<br>limited through the use of available technology. The Government intends<br>to investigate the needs, possibilities and consequences of introducing an<br>environmental charge on cadmium in fertilizers when the current price<br>control system ceases. Proposals are also being looked into concerning the<br>highest permitted levels of cadmium in fertilizers</p>
<p>The use of cadmium in rechargeable nickel/cadmium batteries repre-<br>sents more than half of the cadmium used in Sweden and is also increasing<br>rapidly. A system for recovering such batteries is to be introduced in order<br>to prevent their spread in the environment. An incentive should be intro-<br>duced for the return of used batteries. The Government intends to raise<br>the environmental charge on nickel-cadmium batteries to SEK0.30/g bat-<br>tery weight. A charge will also be payable for fixed re-chargeable batteries.<br>The charge is to finance collection, disposal, information campaigns and<br>incentives. Fixed re-chargeable nickel-cadmium batteries are to be prohib-<br>ited as of 1994. Corresponding regulations will then be introduced in the<br>EC.</p>
<p>International coordination plays an important part. The concrete meas-<br>ures proposed in these phase-out plans are to be coordinated insofar as is<br>possible with other EFTA countries and the EC, and are to be implement-<br>ed after the normal notification. The authorities are systematically to<br>continue their work on identifying substances which should be restricted.<br>They are also to take the measures required in order to implement the<br>restrictions in practice. The Government intends to extend the authoriza-<br>tion of the Chemicals Inspectorate and the Swedish Environment Protec-<br>tion Agency pursuant to the Act on Chemical Products under this Act.</p>
<p>At Swedish initiative, a project has been started in the OECD in order to<br>identify the substances whose use should be strictly limited or completely<br>phased out. Five substances have to date been identified for possible risk-<br>reducing measures, i. e. mercury, lead, cadmium, methylene chloride and<br>flame-proofing agents containing bromine.</p>
<p>Agreements have also been reached at the Third North Sea Conference<br>in order to limit the use and discharges of the substances which have<br>already been identified as so hazardous that they should be phased out.</p>
<p>103</p>
<h5>4.7 Waste</h5>
<p>Prop. 1990/91:90</p>
<p>Summary:</p>
<p>Economic instruments can be used as an incentive to source separa-<br>tion. For this reason, the Government intends to give the munici-<br>palities should have the right to impose diflerentiated waste charges<br>in order to stimulate source separation of waste.</p>
<p>The programme for reducing the volume and hazardous nature of<br>waste and increasing source separation, recovery and recycling is<br>being implemented according to the decision of the Riksdag. The<br>municipalities have been given increased responsibility for the<br>handling of waste.</p>
<p>The Govemment is also proposing that the Riksdag should ap-<br>prove the ratification by Sweden of the Basel Convention on the<br>Control of Transfrontier Shipment and Final Disposal of Hazardous<br>Waste.</p>
<h6>4.7.1 Introduction</h6>
<p>In May 1990, the Riksdag approved the Governmenfs proposed waste<br>management programme. Overall goals in the programme are that the<br>volume and hazardous nature of the waste must be limited and that the<br>treatment of the waste that does arise should be improved. The generation<br>of environmentally hazardous waste is to be avoided by reducing the<br>content of harmful substances in products and goods. The problem can be<br>solved effectively through preventive measures.</p>
<p>Manufacturers and importers of goods and products have the ultimate<br>responsibility for the environmental impact and mismanagement of re-<br>sources that can result from manufacture, use, final disposal or recycling.<br>During the 1980s, it became increasingly clear that purification technology<br>or recycling technology is inadequate as the prime means of limiting the<br>detrimental effects of waste. Measures are required which are aimed at<br>preventing the generation of waste and pollution. The highest priority<br>must be given to changes in products and processes that make the products<br>environmentally sound at all stages of their life cycle and which make it<br>possible to reduce the generation of waste and to reduce the content of<br>hazardous substances in the waste. The generator of the waste is also to<br>bear the cost of handling the waste.</p>
<p>The volume of waste constitutes an increasing problem in modern<br>society. The Riksdag has previously passed a three-year programme with<br>an overall framework of SEK87 million to support research into a society<br>with low levels of waste. The research is to be directed both at environ-<br>mentally sound product development and at the handling of waste. The<br>Government has established a new authority, the Research Programme<br>Council for Waste Minimizing in Society, which is to allocate funds for<br>environmentally sound product development.</p>
<p>The waste management programme means that the municipalities are to<br></p>
<p>104</p>
<p>be given increased responsibility for the handling and planning of waste Prop. 1990/91:90<br>disposal. All those who conduct commercial operations that generate<br>waste are to provide their municipality with the information required for<br>waste planning. This is intended to provide a better overview and im-<br>proved information, at the same time as ensuring that the most suitable<br>treatment methods are used for handling the waste.</p>
<p>As of 1994, source separation is to be developed with the aim that all<br>waste should be sent to appropriate final treatment from the point of view<br>of the environment and resource management. The goal is that inciner-<br>ation and deposit of unseparated waste is to have ceased by the end of<br>1993. The programme also means that the municipalities will also have the<br>right, from 1 January 1991, to require source separation with the support<br>of the law. At the same time, the Swedish Environmental Protection<br>Agency has been given the role of central supervisory authority pursuant to<br>the Refuse Collection Act. This will provide the municipalities with sup-<br>port in their work and enable coordination at a national level.</p>
<p>However, the Government considers that the waste programme should<br>be complemented with economic instruments. In the opinion of the Gov-<br>ernment, it should be made completely clear that the municipalities have<br>the right to differentiate waste charges as an incentive to source separation<br>of waste. Further instruments are under consideration.</p>
<h6>4.7.2 Environmentally hazardous waste</h6>
<p>Alongside the work of limiting hazardous substances in goods and pro-<br>ducts, work must continue on reducing and dealing with the hazardous<br>waste. The Government has appointed a commission to investigate how<br>the flow of hazardous waste is likely to develop during the 1990s on the<br>basis of different assumptions. The commission is also to clarify the<br>various possibilities and costs of handling such waste. The work of the<br>commission is to have been concluded by the end of 1991.</p>
<p>The recovery of hazardous batteries has meant that approximately four<br>tonnes of mercury and over three tonnes of cadmium have been prevented<br>from entering the environment each year.</p>
<p>During the autumn of 1990, the Government also tightened up the rules<br>for the export of hazardous waste. The change meant that the Swedish<br>Environmental Protection Agency is to require information on how<br>hazardous waste exported from Sweden is to be disposed of in the receiv-<br>ing country and to ensure that waste is disposed of in the agreed manner.<br>At the same time, it is made clear that hazardous waste may only be taken<br>out of the country if it can be demonstrated that the waste will be finally<br>disposed of in a way which is acceptable from the point of view of health<br>and the environment in Sweden. From now on, all exporters, including<br>Svensk Avfallskonvertering AB (SAKAB) must apply to the Swedish Envi-<br>ronmental Protection Agency in order to be permitted to remove hazard-<br>ous waste from the country.</p>
<p>The Government is proposing that the Riksdag should approve the Basel</p>
<p>Convention on the Control of Transfrontier Shipments and Final Disposal &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;105<br></p>
<p>of Hazardous Waste, which will then be ratified by Sweden. The Conven- Prop. 1990/91:90<br>tion includes regulations aimed at protecting developing countries from<br>the dumping of poisons. Sweden will also take the lead so that more<br>countries may follow in ratifying the Convention. We should also work to<br>ensure that the Convention is observed and strengthened. The Convention<br>particularly needs strengthening in terms of the follow-up of destruction<br>measures abroad.</p>
<h6>4.7.3 Packaging, etc.,</h6>
<p>In order to tackle the environmental problems generated in the area of<br>packaging, the Government has appointed a committee with the task of<br>proposing, among other things, measures to promote return systems. The<br>committee is to submit its report not later than 1 September 1991. The<br>Government intends to instruct the committee to draw up outline propos-<br>als which will give manufacturers, distributörs and the retail trade full<br>responsibility for return systems and the recycling of packaging.</p>
<p>The proposed Recycling of Beverage Packaging Act is currently before<br>the Riksdag. The proposal entails that as of 1 July 1991 bottles made of<br>PET plastic containing beverages for direct consumption may only be sold<br>if they are subject to a return system.</p>
<p>Glass is used in many different areas. Some important product cate-<br>gories are packaging glass, plate glass, glass fibre and glass wool. Pilot<br>projects concerning municipal glass collection began in 1970. The number<br>of municipalities that collect glass and the amount of glass collected have<br>increased significantly in recent years. The amount of glass recovered has<br>increased over the years. The municipalities are responsible for invest-<br>ments in bottle banks, emptying, and intermediate storage. The reason for<br>recycling glass is to contribute to better management of society’s energy<br>and raw materials resources. It also contributes to a reduction in litter and<br>reduced volumes of waste, reduced risk of injury to refuse collection<br>personnel, lower wear in machinery and equipment and less slag in the<br>waste incineration plants. Glass in the waste handling process entails<br>considerable cost.</p>
<p>The Govemment considers that glass recovery is important and should<br>be increased. The producers should bear an increased responsibility for the<br>recycling of glass and for designing systems that are profitable.</p>
<p>Interest in recycling paper has increased markedly in Western Europé<br>during the past 15 — 20 years. Recycled paper has also become an increas-<br>ingly important raw material for Swedish paper milis. Of the paper which<br>is consumed in Sweden, about 44% is recycled. The use of recycled paper<br>has increased by a factor of three since the beginning of the 70s. An<br>estimated one million tonnes of recycled paper were used in the pulp<br>industry in 1990 and the forecast for the next five years indicates a<br>continued sharp increase, particularly for newspapers and the like. The<br>increase in the use of recycled paper has been made possible by the pulp<br>and paper industry investing in recycled paper plants at the same time as<br>the collection of used paper has developed positively.</p>
<p>106</p>
<p>The possibilities of finding uses for recycled glass and paper vary. It is Prop. 1990/91:90<br>important that existing systems for source separation and subsequent<br>collection for reuse or recycling can continue to function.</p>
<h5>4.8 Restoration measures</h5>
<p>Summary:</p>
<p>The Government is proposing further funds for the liming of lakes<br>and watercourses. The programme is being increased by SEK40<br>million for the coming budget year.</p>
<p>A further SEK4 million is being allocated in order to protect and<br>restore valuable monuments that have been damaged by air pollu-<br>tion.</p>
<p>SEK25 million per year is to be reserved for the clean-up and<br>restoration of polluted areas. This is a five-year programme and will<br>be evaluated towards the end of the period.</p>
<h6>4.8.1 Measures in the environment</h6>
<p>Alongside the limitation of effluents, measures such as liming are required<br>in the environment to stave off acidification. Liming can also contribute to<br>reducing the levels of mercury and radioactive caesium. Liming of lakes<br>and watercourses may be required for a long time.</p>
<p>The decisions reached to date in Europé concerning limitation of acidi-<br>fying emissions are not enough to reduce loads to the critical limits for<br>precipition of acidifying substances in the sensitive areas of Scandinavia.<br>Even if the countries of Europé succeed in limiting discharges considerably<br>more than is now planned, it will take decades before the effects of reduced<br>discharges are seen in land and water systems. Liming will therefore have<br>to continue for several years, particularly in lakes and watercourses.</p>
<p>There is an extensive body of information from the liming of lakes and<br>watercourses which shows that the measures taken have been positive and<br>effective. To date, State grants have been provided for over 5,500 lakes and<br>about one hundred watercourses.</p>
<p>The Government is now proposing that the liming programme be<br>stepped up considerably. The main objective should be to handle all the re-<br>liming and to increase liming in the inland of Norrland and the mountains.<br>The rebuilding of treatment plants for lime precipitation should also<br>continue. The extended liming programme can also mean that the levels of<br>caesium in fish will decline.</p>
<p>The need for liming is most pressing in the inland of Norrland, where<br>watercourses and mountain lakes, several of them classed as being of<br>national scientific interest in terms of nature conservation, have become<br>acidified.</p>
<p>Alongside the liming of lakes and watercourses, measures also need to be<br>directed at the effects of air pollution on monuments and cultural objects.<br></p>
<p>107</p>
<p>The damage that is taking place today, particularly to sandstone and Prop. 1990/91:90<br>limestone ornaments on buildings in the older town centres, must be<br>halted. Other groups of materials, such as rock-carvings, runestones, stone<br>sculptures in mediaeval churches and the like are rapidly being destroyed.</p>
<p>In order to tackle the damage in the long term, the emission of sulphur and<br>nitrogen pollutants must be reduced.</p>
<p>Direct protection and conservation work on the most important groups<br>of valuable monuments is also required if the damage is not to be too<br>extensive. The Govemment is proposing that further funds be allocated<br>for the protection and restoration of monuments.</p>
<p>Pilot activities involving liming and fertilization in order to re-vitalize<br>acidified woodlands are to be completed. The Forestry Policy Committee<br>has been instructed to look more closely into this matter.</p>
<h6>4.8.2 Clean-up and restoration of polluted areas</h6>
<p>There are old waste deposit sites, polluted soils and polluted bottom<br>sediments in many places in Sweden. These areas represent a threat to<br>health and the environment, since the risk of hazardous substances leach-<br>ing out and spreading in the environment is very great in many places.</p>
<p>Two years ago, special funds were allocated in the State budget for<br>measures against environmental damage. The funds were to be used for<br>clean-up measures in cases where no other body was responsible for<br>carrying out such measures. The main rule is otherwise that the polluter<br>should also be responsible for restoration. Concrete clean-up action has<br>been started with regard to mining waste, fibre deposit sites and disused<br>impregnation facilities. Special funds have also been allocated for similar<br>measures in the Dalälven River catchment area. The most important<br>measures in this respect are to limit the leaching of metals from disused<br>mining waste sites. The load of metals on the Baltic from Swedish sources<br>is to a large extent attributable to old mining waste in the Dalälven River<br>catchment area.</p>
<p>In municipal planning it is important to highlight the need of restoration<br>measures in urban and adjacent areas, considering the potential for utiliz-<br>ing the land for new and appropriate purposes in the construction of the<br>community.</p>
<p>The Government considers that the work already started on existing<br>environmental damage should continue. The Government is therefore<br>proposing that further funds be allocated for restoration measures. It is<br>one of the duties of the Swedish Environmental Protection Agency to be<br>responsible for ordering priorities and implementing clean-up projects in<br>cooperation with the municipalities and industries concerned.</p>
<p>108</p>

<h6>Varornas miljöpåverkan</h6>

<h5>Sammanfattning av statens naturvårdsverks rapport Hav 90<br>Aktionsprogram mot havsföroreningar</h5>
<p>HUR MÅR HAVET?</p>
<p>Vi har i flertalet länder runt våra havsområden, och inte minst i Sverige,<br>under flera decennier genomfort åtgärder mot och åstadkommit betydan-<br>de begränsningar av utsläppen av olika föroreningar. Trots detta mår<br>havsområdena runt Sverige idag inte särskilt bra. Vi, och andra länder, har<br>allt for länge belastat havet med for stora mängder av olika föroreningar.<br>Sedan början av 1900-talet och till för några år sedan ökade utsläppen av<br>näringsämnen och metaller. Sedan mitten av 1900-talet har vi haft samma<br>utveckling for olja och, framför allt, for organiska miljögifter.</p>
<p>Våra omgivande havsområden är sinsemellan mycket olika. Salthalten<br>varierar kraftigt från Bottniska vikens utsötade vatten till Skagerraks rent<br>marina karaktär. Känsligheten inom olika havsområden mot miljöpåver-<br>kan är också olika. Vattnets uppehållstid varierar från flera decennier for<br>Östersjön till enstaka månader for Öresund.</p>
<p>Bottniska viken är relativt näringsfattig och i första hand känslig for<br>tillförsel av organiska miljögifter och toxiska metaller. Föroreningarna till<br>havsområdet kommer till största delen från Sverige och Finland, även om<br>en del också kommer från Östersjön och Finska viken med havsströmmar-<br>na.</p>
<p>I egentliga Östersjön är övergödningen idag det klarast uttalade proble-<br>met, men de tydligt förhöjda halterna av organiska miljögifter utgör en på<br>sikt allt allvarligare miljörisk. Föroreningarna tillförs från flera länder runt<br>Östersjön, framför allt genom stora utsläpp av otillräckligt renade avlopps-<br>vatten från städer och industrier i det östeuropeiska tillrinningsområdet<br>till Östersjön. Det svenska bidraget är som regel tämligen litet.</p>
<p>Även i Kattegatt är övergödningen det tydligaste problemet, men det<br>finns lika stor anledning som for Östersjön att uppmärksamma miljöhoten<br>från de organiska miljögifterna. Vartefter man kommer ut i Skagerrak och<br>närmar sig öppna Nordsjön, blir atlantvattnets påverkan, främst på grund<br>av de naturligt höga närsalthalterna, allt mera påtaglig. Stora utsläpp av<br>föroreningar sker till södra Nordsjön. Dessa föroreningar transporteras<br>delvis upp mot våra västra havsområden.</p>
<p>Prop. 1990/91:90</p>
<p>Bilaga 2.1</p>
<p>MILJÖMÅL</p>
<p>Övergripande mål for svenska och angränsande havsområden bör vara att<br>där</p>
<p>— skall i havsområdena naturligt förekommande arter kunna vidmakthål-<br>la livskraftiga, balanserade populationer;</p>
<p>— skall den naturliga flora- och faunazoneringen eftersträvas;</p>
<p>— skall områden med av människan orsakad, störande syrebrist i bot-<br>tenvattnen ej förekomma;</p>
<p>— skall fiske kunna bedrivas uthålligt;</p>
<p>— skall fisk och skaldjur kunna utnyttjas som föda utan hälsorisk;</p>
<p>— skall föroreningar i och på vattnet icke utgöra en begränsning av<br>havsområdenas rekreationsvärden.</p>
<p>De åtgärdsstrategier vi utformar måste karakteriseras av uthållighet och<br>långsiktighet. Detta beror inte minst på att de naturliga variationerna i<br>våra hav är så stora att det tar lång tid innan vi med säkerhet kan fastställa<br>att en förändring skett och åt vilket håll den går. Våren 1988 hade vi t. ex.<br>den mycket allvarliga blomningen av giftalgen Chrysocromulina. Den<br>därpå följande sommaren var från algblomningssynpunkt mycket gynn-<br>sam, med endast små blomningar. Havsbotten återhämtade sig förvånans-<br>värt snabbt i de tidigare drabbade områdena. Trots detta har hotbilden<br>inte förändrats mellan de båda åren, och åtgärder är fortfarande lika<br>angelägna.</p>
<p>NÄRSALTER</p>
<p>Det svenska belastningsbidraget av närsalter är numera jämförelsevis litet,<br>och ensidiga begränsningsåtgärder vid svenska källor torde ha liten bety-<br>delse för miljösituationen i stort i öppna havet.</p>
<p>Genom internationella överenskommelser, i Helsingforskommissionen<br>och Nordsjökonferensen, har det tidigare (i det första aktionsprogrammet<br>mot havsföroreningar) angivna målet om en halvering av närsaltbelast-<br>ningen på våra havsområden till sekelskiftet flyttats fram till att gälla år<br>1995. Med denna förändring kvarstår målet som ett delmål på vägen mot<br>de övergripande miljömålen som redovisats ovan. Vid sidan av skyldighe-<br>ten att genomföra åtgärder som överenskommits internationellt och Sveri-<br>ges ambitioner att gå före och visa på tekniska lösningar, måste de regiona-<br>la och lokala förhållandena i våra egna kustzoner bli styrande för de<br>nationella åtgärdskraven.</p>
<p>Jordbruket står fortfarande för den dominerande tillförseln av närings-<br>ämnen från Sverige till våra havsområden. De åtgärdskrav som redan lagts<br>på jordbruket håller nu på att genomföras. Mycket talar för att effekten på<br>lång sikt kan bli betydligt större än den reduktion på 15-20% som ur-<br>sprungligen beräknats. Lantbruksstyrelsen räknar med att det, med de<br>åtgärder som redan beslutats och som nu föreslås, går att komma en god<br>bit på väg mot 50-procentsmålet.</p>
<p>För de kommunala reningsverken är det i första hand fråga om att<br>fullfölja det program som tidigare lagts fast. En detaljerad genomgång har<br>gjorts av 85 kustförlagda reningsverk, som betjänar omkring 4,5 miljoner<br>personekvivalenter. Behovet att praktiskt prova ut lämplig reningsteknik<br>för kväverening och de stora behoven av konstruktions- och byggkapacitet<br>kan innebära svårigheter att få hela programmet genomfört fullt ut till<br>1995. Problemanalysen pekar vidare på att det fortsättningsvis är mer<br>angeläget att åtgärda läckande ledningssystem och s. k. bräddning på nätet<br>än att ytterligare trappa upp reningskraven i själva reningsverket.</p>
<p>När det gäller de diffusa källorna pekas i första hand på behovet av att<br>förbättra reningen av avloppsvatten från de många fastigheterna i glesbygd<br>som inte är anslutna till samlade kommunala avloppsnät, samt att införa<br></p>
<p>Prop. 1990/91:90</p>
<p>Bilaga 2.1</p>
<p>10</p>
<p>tvättmedel med lågt eller inget fosfatinnehåll i områden där effektiv fosfor-<br>rening av avloppsvatten inte finns.</p>
<p>I det internationella arbetet med havskonventionerna utarbetas hand-<br>lingsprogram för närsalter, som för samtliga länder avses ge en minskning<br>med ca 50%. De internationella åtgärderna är desamma som finns i vårt<br>nationella program.</p>
<p>STABILA ORGANISKA ÄMNEN</p>
<p>Det långsiktiga målet är att eliminiera all tillförsel av antropogena (av<br>olika samhällsaktiviteter orsakad) stabila organiska miljögifter till havs-<br>miljön. Detta mål kvarstår oförändrat sedan den första havsaktionsplanen<br>och framstår idag som allt angelägnare att förverkliga. Som ett delmål har i<br>Helsingforskommissionen och Nordsjökonferensen överenskommits att<br>tillförseln av sådana ämnen till havsmiljön skall halveras till 1995 jämfört<br>med 1987 respektive 1985. Arbetet att definiera vad detta beslut konkret<br>innebär och att peka ut vilka industrier, övriga samhällssektorer och<br>kemiska ämnen/produkter som i första hand bör åtgärdas pågår både<br>nationellt och internationellt. Arbetsområdet är komplext och mycket<br>omfattande.</p>
<p>Principen att överallt vidta de förebyggande åtgärder som över huvud<br>taget är möjliga är särskilt viktig när det gäller arbetet med organiska<br>miljögifter. Överlag krävs en betydligt restriktivare hållning mot använd-<br>ningen av svårnedbrytbara ämnen. Det praktiska genomförandet av ett<br>sådant program måste dock ske stegvis.</p>
<p>Betydande metodologiska svårigheter föreligger, främst vad gäller att<br>precist definiera vad som egentligen inryms under begreppet svårned-<br>brytbar, samt hur man skall kunna bestämma toxicitet och risk för bio-<br>ackumulation för komplexa produkter och utsläpp. Internationellt intresse<br>finns för de olika åtgärds- och utvecklingsprogram som för närvarande<br>drivs i Sverige.</p>
<p>Sedan den första aktionsplanen har möjligheterna att begränsa de tidiga-<br>re så stora utsläppen från skogsindustrin ytterligare studerats. Branschen<br>kommer att klara det mål om utsläpp av klorerade organiska ämnen som<br>sattes upp. Det bör också vara möjligt att omkring sekelskiftet ha påbörjat<br>åtgärder vid samtliga fabriker för att nå en utsläppsnivå motsvarande 25 %<br>av den som fastställdes i den första aktionsplanen. För detta krävs dock en<br>viss utveckling av tekniska metoder, som ännu inte är klar. Med den tid<br>som står till buds bör detta inte vara något avgörande hinder.</p>
<p>En viktig fråga i detta sammanhang är att de åtgärder som skogsindu-<br>strin genomför inte bara kommer att förändra den totalt utsläppta voly-<br>men, utan även utsläppets egenskaper. Parallellt med att utsläppsbegräns-<br>ningarna genomförs är det därför nödvändigt att ta reda på bl. a. om (och i<br>så fall hur) andelen stabila organiska ämnen i utsläppet ändras samt hur<br>miljöegenskaperna hos avloppsvattnet i övrigt förändras (kemisk samman-<br>sättning samt toxicitet och ackumulerbarhet).</p>
<p>Att närmare precisera vid vilken tidpunkt det kan vara möjligt att nå<br></p>
<p>Prop. 1990/91:90</p>
<p>Bilaga 2.1</p>
<p>11</p>
<p>ännu längre på väg mot målet att helt eliminera utsläppen är idag inte<br>möjligt, eftersom någon teknik för detta inte finns.</p>
<p>Vad gäller utsläppen från övriga industribranscher kan konstateras att<br>det påbörjade arbetet med att identifiera och åtgärda utsläpp av stabila<br>organiska ämnen från den kemiska industrin pågår. Inventeringen av<br>användningen av kemiska produkter inom ett antal industribranscher,<br>med syftet att göra utbyten mot miljövänliga alternativ, har kommit igång,<br>men mycket återstår. Det är ett kunskaps- och resurskrävande arbete med<br>starka kopplingar till produktutveckling och internationell harmonisering.<br>Framstegen tar tid.</p>
<p>Arbetet med att minska tillförseln till havet av stabila organiska ämnen<br>från den allmänna kemikalieanvändningen i samhället har kommit igång,<br>och listor med förteckningar över olika kemiska ämnen, som i första hand<br>bör undantas från användning, har tagits fram i samarbete mellan kemika-<br>lieinspektionen och naturvårdsverket. Flera olika åtgärdsprogram pågår,<br>exempelvis för avveckling av PCB, klor, paraffiner i verkstadsoljor och<br>1.1.1-trikloretan.</p>
<p>METALLER</p>
<p>Metaller är naturligt förekommande ämnen i miljön som dock kan vara<br>toxiska vid allt för höga koncentrationer. Det långsiktiga målet för tillför-<br>seln av metaller till våra omgivande hav bör anges som ett procentuellt<br>påslag på den beräknade naturliga bakgrundstillförseln. Det ”tillåtna”<br>procentuella påslaget varierar för olika metaller och också beroende på till<br>vilket havsområde utsläppet sker, men torde normalt ligga i området 50 —<br>200%.</p>
<p>För metaller som är toxiska och kan bioackumuleras finns genom Nord-<br>sjöarbetet och i Helsingforskommissionen internationellt antagna mål att<br>minska tillförseln till havsområdena med 50%. Vid den tredje Nordsjö-<br>konferensen fattades dessutom beslut om att höja denna ambitionsnivå till<br>70% för metallerna kvicksilver, kadmium och bly, samt för dioxiner. De<br>åtgärder som genomförs i olika samhällssektorer i Sverige, bl. a. ett särskilt<br>åtgärdsprogram för kvicksilver, beräknas leda till att detta mål uppfylls.</p>
<p>Kvicksilver och kadmium bedöms vara de metaller som generellt bör<br>prioriteras högst i åtgärdsarbetet. Dels sprids de snabbt i miljön, både med<br>havsströmmar och som luftspridning, dels kan kvicksilver anrikas i fisk i<br>halter som begränsar fiskens användbarhet som livsmedel (svartlistning). I<br>Sverige har redan kraftiga utsläppsbegränsningar genomförts, vilket bl. a.<br>lett till att antalet svartlistade områden längs våra kuster minskat. Sverige<br>bör i framtiden lägga ökad vikt vid att få till stånd åtgärder i andra länder,<br>inte minst med hänsyn till lufttransportens stora andel av tillförseln.</p>
<p>Utöver kvicksilver och kadmium bör särskild uppmärksamhet, åtmins-<br>tone inom vissa havsområden, ägnas åt zink och arsenik.</p>
<p>För övriga metaller bör den svenska åtgärdsnivån bestämmas av den<br>regionala eller lokala föroreningssituationen.</p>
<p>Prop.1990/91:90</p>
<p>Bilaga 2.1</p>
<p>12</p>
<p>OLJA</p>
<p>Sedan det första aktionsprogrammet mot havsföroreningar har ett förbätt-<br>rat underlag när det gäller olja och oljeförorening tagits fram. Det visar att<br>kontinuerlig tillförsel av olja till ett havsområde, om än i förhållandevis<br>små mängder per tidsenhet, har väl så allvarliga effekter som ett större<br>engångsutsläpp.</p>
<p>De viktiga vägarna för denna oljetillförsel till havet är flod- och luftde-<br>position. Beräkningarna är ännu osäkra, men tyder på avsevärt större<br>tillförsel än tidigare bedömningar. Såväl omfattningen av denna tillförsel<br>som källorna behöver utredas ytterligare.</p>
<p>Oljeutvinningen i Östersjön är idag mycket begränsad, men kan under<br>de närmaste decennierna komma att öka väsentligt. Mycket strikta krav på<br>utsläppsbegränsningar vid en sådan exploatering har ställts inom ramen<br>för Helsingforskommissionen. Det är viktigt att denna stränga kravnivå<br>verkligen uppfylls i framtiden. Som lika viktigt framstår att försöka över-<br>föra motsvarande höga kravnivå till den oljeutvinning som pågår i Väster-<br>havet och Nordsjön. De utsläppsnivåer som där fortfarande accepteras<br>ligger betydligt högre, samtidigt som oljeutvinningen där har en mycket<br>stor omfattning.</p>
<p>BEREDSKAP INFÖR AKUTA MILJÖHOT MOT HAVET</p>
<p>Händelserna i Västerhavet 1988 med giftalgblomning, säldöd och en<br>mycket omfattande syrebristsituation aktualiserade på ett påtagligt sätt<br>behovet av en ökad beredskap.</p>
<p>Från beredskaps- och larmsynpunkt bör man särskilja tre olika typer av<br>händelser som kan tänkas inträffa:</p>
<p>— Händelser som orsakas av storskaliga förändringar i miljön, t. ex. eut-<br>rofiering med algblomning och syrebrist som följd. Hit kan också<br>räknas säldöden, även om något miljösamband ej påvisats.</p>
<p>— Händelser som orsakas av någon akut form av olycka eller haveri med<br>fartyg med olja eller kemikalier.</p>
<p>— Händelser som orsakas av någon akut form av olycka eller haveri vid<br>fast anläggning såsom större industri, lagringsanläggning, anläggning<br>för energiproduktion eller avloppsreningsverk.</p>
<p>Det är framför allt inom tre områden som beredskapshöjande åtgärder<br>kan sättas in:</p>
<p>— Intensivare kustmiljöövervakning.</p>
<p>— Fastare bevaknings- och ledningsorganisation.</p>
<p>— Förbättrad informationsverksamhet.</p>
<p>Prop. 1990/91:90</p>
<p>Bilaga 2.1</p>
